It was once a most brilliant game which encouraged you to play more and also gave ya plenty room to encourage you to purchase some roster slots aside from getting plenty of free ones through missions or getting lucky at that gold draw or even towards your allliance slots for new members untill they started changing things...alot of things. first started with just a no health gain which started quite a bit of commotion and also drastically decreased the amount of time people put into the game from hours to mere minutes decreasing its overall popularity. It seemed like a small thing being nothing big was changed after that cept new heroes with downgraded abilities of their older selves that were far weaker. Apparently they didn't stop there to roll in the cash and decrease amount of players and customers to their list. They took it much farther and it gets worse with each update they make. They then started taking away heroes abilities then went along to replacing them with weaker and less effective abilities including replacing alot of other heroes abilities that did quite well, but not over powered, to something entirely new that did little to nothing now. After all the excessive deep changes were made they caused alot of players to play less or even quit. They then decided in order to hopefully lure more people back or new ones into the game they released Deadpool and a huge event that gave ya a chance to enjoy Deadpool and get one of your own which kinda worked for a time but didn't last for long. They downgraded alot of abilities some more on some heroes especially focusing on the starter ones which were strong enough to help new players along the way towards better ones. They keep compensating it with more chances at new heroes that they release from time to time but was it enough? Apparently not being now its hardly worth working towards when most can't afford to keep in the game long enough to get them unless you pay your heart out for the luck at the draw which is rare you get anything different or better unless its towards the better draws which cost round $40-$50+ to get a slightly better chance which has proven to make little difference which even the normal draws are quite pricey if you don't get free ones from every day rewards. Sadly the game was reduced to nothing but rubble and another facebook game as most referr to it now as and even now stands little to impress new and old players to try or continue playing much or at all. If your looking for a good experience look the other way cuz this game has long lost it and the magic it brought to games that made it wildly popular when it started making itself more at home. The game no longer revolves around skill but more along of power, money, and luck and has no tactics that works like it used to so sad to say I conclude this thorough review saying that I would no longer reccomend this game to anyone unless they insisted on something to kill just a little of their time.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 15, 2014
												A lot of people say this game is Pay to Win, but it's a bit misleading. Sure, if you're willing to drop trucktons of money into the game, you'll get access to stuff a lot faster than you would normally, but that holds true for nearly every single free to play game. I personally don't consider this a Pay to Win game.  I'm writing this review to shed some light on this. To do so, I'll go into some further depth of how the resources and the game works. Beware, as there will be a lot of things I touch upon here. I'll leave a short summary at the bottom.You have two main resources in this game - ISO-8 and Hero Points.   ISO-8 is primarily used to level up your characters and can be obtained easily and reguilarily, sometimes in very large quantities. Think of it as your common resource, you'll always need more and it is also the most available.Hero Points are much less common. Hero Points are used for a number of things, and could be compared to a premium resource, if you will. It is used to increase the maximum amount of characters you can have at any given time aswell as purchasing new characters and their powers. Hero Points can also be used to purchase additional Health Packs and to Shield yourself in PvP Events (more on both later).  It is available in limited supply from story missions - often enough to get you started - but the main source of Hero Points tend to be from the events that happen regularily. Events work similiar to the main storyline missions and the main PvP, except they have a set time limit. After the time is up for any event, you will receive rewards based on your placements in the rankings - Rewards consist of a combination of specific Covers (unlocks characters or upgrades their powers), Booster packs (contains random Covers), Hero Points and ISO-8. Apart from the rewards you get for your ranking, there are also progression rewards in most events that reward you at set intervals with ISO-8, Hero Points, Covers or Boosters.Next I'll go into health packs. Normally as your characters take damage in battle, they will slowly regenerate that health back (real-time) when they are not in battle. If a character is downed (in-game definition of a character running out of health) in battle, they also need a certain amount of time to recover from that on top of the time to regenerate their health. However, you can use Health Packs to instantly revive and fully heal any character. Health Packs naturally regenerate up to a stock of 5, but you can purchase additional health packs for Hero Points. You are also relatively regularily awarded Health Packs from missions, daily rewards and progression rewards.Next up we have Shields. Normally in PvP Events, you lose/gain points in the event whenever you are attacked by another player. Shields can be purchased with Hero Points to protect you from point loss due to other players attacking you for a limited time - I do not know if it also disables points gains from defensive victories. Attacking any player while a shield is active will prematurely end the effect.Last but not least are combat boosts. These are regularily and randomly dropped after any kind of combat, as mission drops aswell as progression rewards and come in different flavors. They are generally simple, providing small bonuses to specific areas - more damage or starting AP for powers (AP is generated by matching colored tiles), though there are much larger bonuses available that are far more rare (+150% damage vs specific kinds of enemies). You can purchase more of these bonuses for ISO-8 (and possibly Hero Points, I do not know since I haven't used any rare boosts).  Personally I very rarely use boosts, I have only been using a few in some of the more difficult PvE battles, and they are by no means necessary to stay competetive.Covers are generally what you are ultimately after. They unlock the character in question when you obtain your first one and either unlocks or increases levels of their powers with further ones. They come in four rarities shown by stars, from 1-star covers to 4-star covers. They are obtained regularily, most commonly from Boosters which in turned are awarded as mission rewards, progress rewards, event prizes and a few other sources. Your covers determine the strength of your characters' powers, but most importantly determine the maximum level you can level your character up to. The maximum level possible for a character is based on their rarity and actually leveling up characters uses ISO-8.  Boosters will give you a random cover, with a minimum rarity based on what kind of booster it is. There are two generic boosters that can give you pretty much any character in the game, but there are regularily "specialized" boosters available during events that contain one cover randomly chosen from a specific poll of characters, usually characters involved or powered up during the event. You can also purchase additional boosters in the in-game store for ISO-8 (only the basic booster) or Hero Points.  Events prizes and progress rewards will often grant you specific character covers. Event prizes tend to be covers ranging from 2- to 4-star covers, depending on your final rank (along with Hero Points and ISO-8), while progress rewards can reward you with anything from 1- to 4-star covers  (though 4-star cover progression rewards are usually practically impossible to reach within the timeframe of an event).In short, these resources are all either awarded regularily no matter what area of the game you play (Health Packs, Boosts and ISO-8) or regularily as rewards in event prizes and progression (Hero Points, ISO-8, Covers, Boosts and Boosters). The only exceptions are Shields, but they are not much of a resource to begin with.I have spent a lot of time on this game, and while I have paid some money to get more Hero Points (I regularily support Free to Play games that I like), I spent most of it up until now playing for free. From my own experience I can honestly tell you that you can easily stay competetive in the event rankings as a free player, provided you know what you're doing and are willing to sink some time into that particular event. Even with little effort you can generally get a decent ranking (enough for a 2-star cover, a 2-star booster) aswell as a reasonable amount of progression rewards. You never *need* Shields in PvP events to get a good placement, it just makes it easier.  You'll gradually get stronger as you play. At first you'll be using mainly 1-star covers, and as you gradually unlock 2-star covers you'll be switching over to mainly using them. In time you'll have enough 3-star covers to get them up to the level they need to be in order to be useful. 4-star covers are far more rare and are generally reserved as first place prizes for events and can also very rarely be obtained from boosters (I have one cover for each of the two existing 4-star characters, both obtained through boosters), but they shouldn't be your immediate goal to begin with. SummaryIn short, the bottom line is that this is a progression game where you'll gradually unlock new characters and level them up to be even stronger. Nothing a paying player can accomplish is unaccomplishable by any free player, a paying player can just get there faster and/or easier, which from my experience describes nearly all free to play games currently out there. I can say this though, it is a LONG progression you walk. You cannot expect to take the top spots in event rankings when you're fresh into the game, but eventually you'll be competing with the best.Finally, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. There is no doubt in my mind that this game will not appeal to most people, but if you seem to enjoy the premise of this game after giving it a try and can imagine spending a lot of time in it, it can be very enjoyable. Simply, I would very much recommend this game to the right people.

content:
18, 2015
												Match 3, Marvel, but.... Microtransactions.The game's mechanics of a match-3 to initiate fights is far from new anymore - but its complicated by the need to "heal" injured combatants either by waiting or buying health packs.That's the first clue. The next is leveling up the characters. You do gain some of the upgrade materials and items from missions, certain ones earned at certain stages - but to make your team strong you need to further upgrade the skills, then upgrade the character, and repeat. There is a relative cap, but the distance from what the free to play model gives you and the time it would take to get there is absurd compared to just paying for it. It scales up the higher you go. Pay for more to get less and so on.Hence the microtransactions. Lots and lots of microtransactions.I wouldn't have an issue if it was possible to gain a decent team of your favorite heroes easily, just to enjoy the story, or possible to upgrade them relatively well without spending a fortune... but this game takes it to a whole new level.Be wary, this is a Pay to Win game, and boy you could pay in spades with the level of microtransactions here.Players beware. The lure to pay to win here is way too much for it to be worth it.Other than that, its a standard Marvel-oriented game following the mainstream stories on their own minor twist with the ISO-8 junk I first saw years ago with the Facebook varaint. The story is alright, the game itself is okay. The over-abundance of microtransactions to make you pay a fortune is not really making this game worth it.

, 2015
												<<< Matching colors addict - Updated as of May 15, 2016 - Some new and cool changes in the last few months! (read near the bottom of the review for info on them)If you have been reading negative reviews in regards to P2W (pay 2 win) then they are biased. This game is free but real fans will spend money on it because they want to collect as many characters as they can and level them up fully. If you don't put effort into this game then you won't get too far and you will be discouraged. It takes patience and time to get anywhere. For fans and people who enjoy this type of build up with RPG elements this game is great! It gives you something to check everyday and play for a short while. Any fan of the Marvel Universe should get this game, especially since it is free. Players who pay will have an advantage in the sense that they can level up their character cards faster and buy more slots to recruit new characters, but once you get a bit further you can compete in daily competitions/leaderboards to win new characters and powers, crystals for levelling and gold coins for buying new character cards and extra slots. pros - A good chillin game, just need a mouse       - Made for fans of Marvel (obviously) and matching puzzle games with RPG elements       - Lots of super heroes and villians to collect ranging from one star* to four stars**** and now      with the new update new five star***** characters are available that can be levelled up to 450!       - A lot of strategy is required if you want to win difficult matches against higher level enemies.       - Collectable/usable power-ups and character power cards (usable once in a battle)!       - You can join or create an alliance and there are competition and leaderboards for your crew to compete in for prizes like new character cards, coins, crystal and 2-3 star cards from either the vault which is a random card generator that you stop yourself or a hero card that gives u a random 2-4 star character.       - Light on the PC       - Developers are active always updating the game, adding new characters periodically and creating new competitions and battles daily. cons - Addictive         - If you are color blind you might want to avoid this game        - Random character card received when purchasing new cards        - You will get many doubles which you can sell...but it can get annoying. Back to pros - UPDATE! - You can now max out your character level and pay an extra amount of crystal to make the maxed out character a legend. This allows you to use extra cards (that before would be useless and sold for crystal) to continue leveling up your character. One level per character card. Every level gives you a reward as well. like Command points, crystals, other character cards and coins.                - Command points are used to obtain **** 4 and ***** 5 star character cards. 20 for classic and 25 for modern. These command points are also used for upgrading characters if one can never find the one card they need for one of their characters.Overall score: 8.0/10Chance of becoming an addict (playing it daily) score: 7.0/10

number of helpful: 66 of 119 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												I'm going to start by saying I rarely write reviews but this game has such a bad rep due to people not really taking the time to play the game before posting a negative response. I wanted to try and fix this. If you look at the reviews for this game you will see hundreds of people saying "pay to win; don't play." This is what angers me, the game is actually pretty generous to free players. These bogus reviews are from people who launch the game, see the possibility for microtransactions, and post a bad review purely on that.I've been playing this game since its steam release and have never spent a cent. My first two days playing I was able to place in the top ten of a pvp event. Since then I've competed in many events and have never come away without atleast one 3-star or better.I was also able to complete the story within 2 week of downloading the game. It is true that the story rewards and pvp rewards are rather limited, but the amazing rewards for events make up for them.Also for those who thought about the "pay to win strategy," you are wasting your money. It's HARD to get a significant advantage from paying! The amount of money each upgrade costs would require hundreds of dollars to be spent to make a significant difference. About $10 to level up a skill even though you can get the cover to do so by doing events for free.In summary the microtransaction option makes the game daunting to free to play people but if you are willing to put just a little time into the game(2-4 hours a day), you can do better than most paying players within a week. So please take it from someone who plays a lot of free to play games and has never spent a cent on any of them, this is one of the most generous free games you will ever find. Try it before you complain about microtransactions.Update: Marvel Puzzle Quest has changed a lot since I wrote this review. Mostly for the worse. While I do still enjoy playing the game it is largely because I already had a decent force before a lot of the changes were made. The company repeatedly ignores their fan base and makes changes that make the game increasingly hard to play without paying and really expensive if you do pay. I'm going to list the notable changes since this review was originally posted.The Good:1. The ever increasing roster size keeps collecting covers interesting and gives reason to come back to the game.2. PvP seasons: The company recently introduced PvP seasons. These are month long event that keep track of players as they partake in PvP events. The top rated players get fantastic rewards.The Bad:1. Shields: In Marvel Puzzle Quest PvP events run on a points system. At first glance it is simple and  fair. In fact it used to be fair but shields have all but ruined the accessability. For every round you win you gain points. If you lose a round you lose points. This is fine. Being that PvP is actually Player vs. AI player people must be able to challenge computer versions of other players. When a computer version of yourself wins or loses you also gain/lose points according. This has always been annoying but for the most part fair. However, shields allow a player to spend a decent sum of money in order to protect themselves from point loss. In otherwords free players quickly lose points from their AI losing but they can't make those who pay lose any points. This makes it very hard for free players especially when first starting off.2.Gold Characters: Gold characters are enhanced versions of other characters. This essentially means the developers got lazy and wanted to release a new character but didn't feel like designing new character powers. While that alone is annoying it is tolerable. What isn't tolerable is taking a character and nerfing him because he is "overpowered" and then release a stronger version of the character right after. For anyone who joined late and doesn't know this is exactly what they did with Thor.3. Boost Changes: Boosts were an easy way to allow free players to stand a fighting chance. A player could buy boosts with Iso(in game currency) in order to assist a strategy using what are otherwise weak characters. However, boosts have changed so that in order to buy the useful ones you must spend hero points(premium currency).4. Healing Changes: In Marvel Puzzle Quest you have always needed to wait for your characters to heal after battle. How long you have to wait varies depending on character level. You have also always been able to pay in order to heal instantly. While this has always given paying members an advantage, it wasn't outrageous because within a couple hours your characters would heal. However, the company has recently made it take longer for heroes to heal making the game even harder to play for free.The Ugly:1. Pay to Enter Tournaments: These are occasional tournaments that have an entry fee. The prizes to be won in said tournaments are outstanding. The winner gets one of every cover in the game. While I like the idea of large tournaments that have a little risk to them I don't like how these particular tournaments are set up. I'm fine with an entry fee but the fee should be in iso. I personally think there should be an entry fee somewhere along the lines of 5000-10000 iso. This is a decent amount of currency so there is a big risk for the players but it is entirely in-game currency so it is accessable to everyone if they are willing to save up for a while. Unfortunately the tournament entry fee is in hero points, so it once again favors those who pay fairly significantly.2. Alliances: Alliances, are this games version of a clan. All events have alliance rankings in addition to individual rankings. All members of the top ranked alliances get prizes. Alliances had the potential to be a great addition to the game. having a community to play with and talk to as well as getting additional prizes for doing so is fantastic. Where the game went wrong is in Alliance sizes. An Alliance starts with 5 player slots. However, the alliance leader has the option to buy additional slots up to 20. Of course to buy these slots you have to spend Hero points. So only the alliances who pay ever win events because they have a larger player base. Adding an additional slot to a guild isn't cheap either; additional slot cost as much expanding you roster size post 20 heroes.So would I recommend this game now? Maybe, it is really hard to say at this moment due to the fact that I started out so early. I do believe it is possible to do decently well while being a free player but I am rather biased because I already had a large army. Furthermore, at the rate which D3/Demiurge are ruining the game within a month it will likely be totally inaccessable to any new free players and possibly even veteran free players.

												Ok so Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign. A somewhat port from a IOS game. And it is notable. Few options, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ UI, some bad graphics and animations. Lacking even the basic options, like turning off combat animations. Which can become extremely repetetive after a short time, due to the fact that each hero can have a max of 3 skills. The gameplay combine the Puzzle Quest series with Marvel universe.  If you are a fan of the puzzle quest series or marvel universe, its worth giving a shot. The free to play model they use in this game is really weird and somewhat counterproductive. The worst part being that your heroes does not heal instantly after a match. Instead they heal over time. Having a lvl 50 Iron Mand die ---> wait 3hours.I guess the idea is to have people buy health packs to resurrect/heal the heroes. Summary+ addictive gameplay+ licensed superheroes from Marvel Universe+ loads of weekly/daily/hourly tournaments where you compete with other peoples heroes for prizes+ long and challenging campaign+ dont have to invest any money to be able to do well ingame- Bad UI, graphics, animation- Alot of our favourite Marvel superheroes is not in the game- Impending shadow of a poor free to play model- Weird gamechoices regarding leveling of powers, herolevel and healing- Bad AI (will use skills whenever they have enough resources, even tho it only hurts them)I still recommend the game to fans of puzzlequestish games, and fans of marvel. Game is very timeconsuming and I would totally play it on an IOS while taking a ♥♥♥♥. Just dont expect anything more.

content:
5, 2014
												Steam says I have more than 2000 hours in the game, but the truth is it is mostly running on the background. I'd say 500 hours is much closer to reality. Here is what you need to know about the game. It is a 3vs3 match where you bring a team of heroes/villains and try to win by making use of their abilities. You use them by spending the required resources (AP) which you get when you match tiles. The characters are divided in 4 tiers (1* - 4*) with only the 3* and very few of the 2* being useful at the moment. Most characters have 3 abilities, but there are some with only 2 because the developers have left them incomplete for months. The abilities can gain levels by buying or winning covers. The stats of the characters and the effectiveness of their abilities are increased as you level them with the use of ISO-8, an in-game currency used solely for leveling characters and buying boosts you can use in matches. The second currency is called HP (Hero Points) and is used to increase the size of your roster and to level abilities without the use of covers.The good: Fast game / doesn't require too much thinking which makes it ideal for short gaming bursts / you get to use your favorite heroes / very simple rules.The bad: Several incomplete characters with no plan to finish them in the near future / a turn from F2P to P2P since March 2014 / Inconvenient event end times for Europeans / success depends heavily on playing close the end of an event / several exploits are reported which allow cheaters to roam free in the game / market prices for in-game currency are the worst I have seen in a game.Advices:1. Use HP only to buy roster slots. At least until you have 30-35 slots. Never buy tokens (they give random covers). The % to get a specific 3* hero is less than 1% in most cases. You have better results if you level the abilities directly with HP. 2. Never use ISO-8 to buy 1* tokens. You will need it to level your heroes and it will always, ALWAYS be in short supply.3. Always take part in Lightning Rounds since they are the most efficient source of ISO. Try to get to 100 points. 4. Don't max a 3* hero unless you have a diverse roster with at least 3-4 more heroes with levels 85+. When you do, the levels of the teams you fight will also increase a lot.Epilogue: I will not tell how to spend your money, but you have to know that the game has made a turn into a more P2P model after March 2014. The changes in late June change how healing works in the game and restricts your ability to play since there is practically no way to heal heroes unless they have an innate regeneration ability. Heroes heal over time, but with most of them taking 2-4 hours to fully heal. healing packs are your only alternative and they cost HP which is relatively rare. The market prices are ridiculously unreasonable. To fully level a 3* hero you will need ~170k ISO which costs ~$300. The game is quite addictive so be warned. I would advice against letting young children play with it. I bet they can find better things to do and you should encourage them to spend their time doing something more creative. So do I recommend this game? After the changes in the last 2-3 months, I do not.

content:
r 22, 2016
												This is a clever variation on match 3 puzzle games; you control a team of characters, and you beat up the other team by making matches. Each character does different amounts of damage from different colors, and every character has three unique abilities which mesh to create the gameplay.The problem is that this is a free to play game, and it is one of those free to play games which is constructed entirely around exploiting the darkest parts of the human psyche. It is all about addiction, trying to get you to keep playing to keep getting more slots for your heroes, and it is just a tremendously addictive exerience as you're always short of having enough slots for all your characters - and if you don't put your characters into a slot, you lose them.This is designed to compel you to keep playing, and manipulate you into playing far more than the game actually warrants.The core gameplay is decent enough, but if you have any addictive tendencies at all, this game will chew you up and spit you out.

content:
r 10, 2015
												Update 11/11/16:  Yep, still negative. If you like games you can play in small bits and want an active player community, this delivers both. If you don't mind massive amounts of time and moeny being burned to progress, you'll do well.BUT if you insist on playing, DON'T play it on Steam. Play it on iOS or Android. The devs continue to offer better rewards to mobile players via in-game advertising and Facebook integration. They say Steam API will not support these features .... and offer NO compensation. If you play on Steam you will be one of a small minority, competing against an ocean of better-compensated mobile players.That's this year's disaster. See below for last year's "high" point.______________________Short version: Stay away.Longer version:Gameplay is fun but very, very shallow. Content, in the form of characters to burn resources chasing, is continually expanding, while new story content or gameplay expansion remian few and far between. It's extremely repetitive and grindy.This game launched in an anemic and hilariously unbalanced form, and has come a long way in 2 years. It's growing and being proted to consoles. Great.It does still have a fun tightknit community that can be accessed via the dev's forum. That's the best thing about the game, the other people playing it, not the game itself. Hmmm.It is probably the prettiest match-3 game around .... that isn't saying much. The game mechanics, after 2 years of bolt-ons, are held together by baling wire. Unintended results abound and are discovered the hard way by players.Play it casually for awhile and then move on. God help you if you allow it to become a habit. (See those hours logged? There but for the grace of the gods go you.)The worst is the dev's inept attempts at communication. Spectacularly bad. Here is a great example ... This week is the game's 2-year anniversary. It centers on a new event, a battle against Galactus. The blance of the event is laughably out of whack; the ONLY way to win is to make use of exploits (which the inept developer failed to catch ...). Other events running concurrently are suffering from various bugs, and the anniversary rewards have been found to be WORSE than the normal in-game rewards (Happy anniversary!)After the event runs for a day, and the online community is thoroughly hacked off, the producer posts the below. Judge it for yourself._____________________Hey all,Wanted to share a few things about how Galactus works and what we're expecting versus what we're seeing.To start, it seems like a lot of people are on a basic disconnect here, looking at the boss battle similar to how Ultron ran in terms of how things work. Meaning that Ultron should be going down pretty regularly. He's powerful, but his real power lies in the fact that killing his body doesn't stop him. You need to crush every one of his drones and main bodies to win. So winning rounds is a pretty regular occurrence. Game-wise, what this means is that players won fairly easily against Ultron and took their lumps against the drones. The stopping timer there was health packs based on when the drones finally wore you down. What this also meant is that the higher end Alliances would chew through the entire Event in about 12 hours and let it kinda sit for 3 days.Galactus is different. The "minion" fights against the villains are relatively simple. They're there as minor hazards but relatively easily winnable. Galactus on the other hand is a massive threat. He's not going to be stopped by gnats. Iron Fist punching him in the toe isn't very painful. So he gets bored and swats them away. In game terms, this means that players are going to be beaten. Winning a round against Galactus is an achievement. You're supposed to lose. Every time you do, you're still chipping away at his life. It's an exercise in damage in aggregate. Over the 3.5 days, hitting him over and over to finally bring down the big bad is somewhat slow, but certainly effective.Overall, most of the higher end Alliances are in Round 6 or knocking on the door to Round 7. Which is actually slightly faster than we were expecting people to get just based on the math. So everyone's doing pretty darned well in terms of progression. There are some teams rockin' the Winfinite, other teams that are pushing through with some interesting strategies (who woulda thought OBW would be a rock star against Galactus?). Not many Alliances are getting anywhere near full clears. Which is actually intended. You're supposed to lose your Health Packs on Galactus, rather than against the minions like on Ultron. It's also why we changed up the play method for this round too so that it's not just a flip flop between Ultron and minions till you win. There's a set number of times you can hit Galactus before you need to take a break to let minions refresh. That break means that you have plenty of times for Galactus drained Packs to refresh while you can go in and get some Black Vortex in. Or play Simulator (up soon). Or get your Devil Dino on when that starts up. It's a different design than the rush of Ultron where that was pretty much all players did while it was open.Long story short, you all are doing really well against Galactus. Yes, the gameplay is different. I'm sure most of you aren't used to going into a battle with the idea that you may well lose. But given that you're still pulling out wins with pretty strong regularity, I don't see any reason this wouldn't continue into Rounds 7 and 8, and on to Cyclops awesomeness.At the outset, going into the boss battle, you're looking at winning like normal. After all, it works elsewhere in the game, and it worked against Ultron. So suddenly getting rocked by Galactus is a shock. Keep at it. If things are really going to go poorly, we'll look at doing refresh timer changes and the like that we can do server-side as a quicker band aid style fix for run 1. After that, we'll figure out what we want to do for difficulty on run 2 (and any other runs that we do in the future, of course).

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2016
												I literally can't think of another game with more hooks to try to get you to spend money than MPQ.There are *multiple tiers* of in game currency that you can pay for.If you want more characters ("covers"), you have to buy them. If you want to reliably upgrade the abilities of characters you do have, you have to purchase the upgrades. If you want to level up those characters without a crazy grind, you have to pay. If you want more character slots, you have to pay. If your characters take too much damage and you want to keep on playing, you have to pay for a heal. If you want to compete in PVP you have to pay for boosts.Sure, *some* of those things you can grind for, but the results are often unpredictable. For example instead of an upgrade to an existing character you might get a new character cover. But if you don't have enough character slots you have to buy more. You can try to grind for enough currency to unlock more slots (prices for new slots increase depending on how many you already have), but you have a time limit on your covers, so if you can't unlock a new slot fast enough, the new character you earned just disappears. This is a deliberate time pressure to try to get you to just buy the slot.You spend a bunch of time and currency investing in a character just to find out he has a level cap because he is a lower-tier character, and if you actually want to progress in the game you need higher tier characters. You can try and grind for the (exceedingly rare) chance to get a rare cover to drop, or you can spend money to get one as a sure thing. Again, the game is trying to pressure you into buying ♥♥♥♥.You can try to unlock more rewards by competing in PVP and PVE events, but as soon as you get anywhere near the top bracket you'll find it is impossible to progress and get the real rewards without paying money because the other people at the top are paying for heals and boosts so if you aren't doing the same you can't possibly compete with them, so even the "free" rewards are effectively locked behind a paywall.There is absolutely no skill involved in this game, it's all about how much money you are willing to spend. It's probably the most disgusting example of pay to win mechanics and "gambling" hooks in something purporting to be a video game I have ever seen.

content:
2016
												Marvel Puzzle Quest easily recommended to anyone who enjoys the match 3 genre or simply wants a good 'zen' game.  The gameplay mechanics are fantastic and the game itself has taken HUGE strides to become more and more free to play friendly over time. Anyone who gets invested in this game might be surprised to learn that it has a healthy and welcome community attached to it through the forums and primarily through the LINE app.  This interaction with other players turns MPQ into more than just a game I pick up and play on occasion. As an extremely hardcore player of Marvel Puzzle Quest I can easily see a lot of the games flaws as they pertain to character balance issues, reliance on lucky cover draws, the feeling that your roster improves and yet you continually face more challenging content rather that 'get ahead', becoming overwhelmed by characters but not enough room to keep them all, and the fact that competitive play demands far too much time from the player.   Those negatives aside the game at it's core is still fantastic to play and well worth recommending. A solid 8/10 experience that can easily hook you if you let it.

content:
0, 2016
												Downloading the Steam version, previously I've only played the Android version.The game is a good time-sink. For those calling it pay-to-win; certainly you can buy most of the meaningful resources in the game, but you're not getting good value for your money, and you're kind of missing the point of the game.  $10 will save you, eh, maybe 5 hours of in-game effort, and because of the way the game groups people for the in-game competition, you don't get any actual advantage; you have better characters, but so does the group you're competing with.Which does imply something of the issue: The whole game is a Red Queen's Race.  Enemies level up with your strongest three characters (as best as I can tell), so "Easy" missions will always be easy, and "Difficult" missions will always be difficult.  The RPG elements are mostly an illusion; mostly, because characters are separated out by their "Star" power, and each star-level has a power cap.  So once you develop a two-star roster, your one-star characters stop being useful (mostly); after you get a three-star roster, your two-star roster is less useful, and your one-star roster becomes, outside very specific situations, completely worthless.  If you're spending money to advance your characters, you're wasting your money.Because the point of the game isn't to "win" - there is no winning.  It's a time sink, and a well-designed one; you'll be tempted to spend money every now and then to increase the size of your roster (which can be done without spending money, but more slowly and deliberately), to avoid having to make a painful choice between selling a new powerful character, or selling an old favorite character to make room.  If opportunity cost is painful for you, you probably shouldn't play this game; you'll be spending a lot of money.  (Disclosure: I've personally spent $20.  Not because I couldn't not, but because I like the game and like supporting developers.)If, on the other hand, you're accustomed to trade-offs, this game could be a very satisfying way of spending free time.

content:
ber 15, 2015
Cons outweigh pros by FARToo many things about this game make it painfully frustrating and totally not worth playing.The worst thing is how often I'm forced to sit back and watch uncountable cascades or other nonsense because the tile drops are not random. The algorithm they use not only identifies the chosen characters in order to set tiles on the board but also identifies how many of which tiles are on the board before selecting which tiles to drop after a match. Watching which tiles drop a few times lets you quickly begin to predict which tiles are likely to drop next. Being able to predict should help your strategies but, as you quickly learn, it does not.Equivalently to this problem, you are forced to play on the developers terms:You must endlessly grind the same match to get 1/4 rewards.You must begin a fight just to view inventory of boosts AND you must manually de-select the boosts from a previous fight.When you gain hero tokens you must decide whether to open the token (for an incredibly rare chance to gain something you actually want) or keep the unopened token indefinitely. Once you open the token you must then choose whether to sell the hero for ISO, swap the hero for another hero already on your roster (if you don't have enough Hero Points to open a slot for them), or let the hero expire and receive nothing.On mobile devices, you're forced to endure 100+MB updates every other week. Which brings up another crucial point: almost every update adds a new character. Pretty cool, right? Keeps things dynamic by adding fresh meat. Well, aside from EVERY update causing new bugs (oh, crashes cause an infuriating problem I'll get to next), at the beginning, the first 4 slots to add new characters to your roster are free. However, as you keep adding characters, the cost of the slots keep going up. Here's what they cost after the first 4:  Roster Slot Hero Pts   5 25   10 200   24 300   29 400   37 500   45 600   53 700   61 800   69 900   77+ 1000 It's like the devs punish you for collecting a full roster. How does this make any sense? Meanwhile, if you're enough of a sucker to throw hundreds of dollars at these developers, you must still be able to work ... uhh play(?) on the game's schedule just to compete with anyone for the rewards you want... but if you've got that kind of time & money to throw at one single fremium game, what rewards do you need that you couldn't buy outright? Oh, that's right--you can't. There are only 2 things you can definitively buy (which are both outrageously priced): ISO and Hero Points. Game Crashes: Many poorly programmed games are prone to crashes and this one is no exception but D3 adds some twists to this back-alley gut-stabbing. The game may randomly crash while you are in the middle of a match and that's not the worst part. When the crash occurs, the game treats your sudden exit as if you have chosen to retreat which damages your team! Forget that retreat damage is asinine to begin with but now devs add 'injury' to insult by doing nothing about game crash damage. Want to re-initiate the game and try to replay the match with your ideally chosen team? Tough luck! They're either dead or half dead!There is a whole other side of this 'game' which allows players to 'fight' each other (you only play against A.I. on any part of the game) that I won't go into. I've played it only enough to realize how utterly futile it is. If you check out the D3Go forums you'll see the extent of frustration that people have for the multitude of flaws in 'versus' mode.Beyond all that, I see many people rate it high then say "It's great BUT..." or recommend it and say it's addicting as though being an addict is a good thing.If I could, I would only recommend this title to people I hate.

content:
13, 2016
												Bottom line: Very slow and grindy from the get-go.Don't get me wrong I know exactly what I'm in for when I download something with the tag "free to play". I know that eventually I will come to point in the game where the progress slows down and I have to decide whether to commit my time or my money. I do not expect every f2p game to be PoE or DOTA2. But the thing that disappointed me with this game was how soon I got to that point.In my experience these sorts of free to play games, the good ones, tend to be pretty fast paced at first to get you hooked and learn the ropes. Then as the pace of progression gradually slows down you can start to really appreciate and understand what you can accomplish long term, either through play or through paying. But Marvel Puzzle quest sort of just gives you one semi-fast prologue chapter and then says "now we grind".I haven't even beaten the second prologue chapter yet and my best character (Iron-man) takes over an hour in real time to heal up to full health if he’s downed. The battles even against normal goons take a long time now. Even if the battle isn't hard they usually damage my heroes so much that I can't use them for a good while. And the reward for beating them are sometimes just these consumable boosts that do not progress your characters in any way which makes it feel like you won nothing for such a long battle.My most dominating thought is "if it's this grindy in the prologue how bad will it be when I actually get to play the main PVE/PVP modes?" I don't know, maybe it's admirable how upfront this game is about what it is (i.e. a typical f2p game) but it's a huge turnoff for me and I guess for others as well.I see the potential in this game, it has some pretty cool ideas and the Puzzle Quest match 3 battles are fun, but it got grindy way to fast. I enjoyed the previous puzzle quest games and hoped this could become my new "play a quick session every once in a while game". But it gives such a bad early impression that I’m pretty much done with the game, which is a shame honestly.

content:
11, 2014
												Three months ago when I started this game, I loved playing it. I truly enjoy three-match puzzles and this also introduced me better to the Marvel universe. There are regular events with witty dialogue and the more I played, the more I felt rewarded.Then I had two characters leveled to 85 (the current max level at the time for Thor and Storm) and that's when hell was unleashed. Oh dear.Even though there is PVP in the game, you never play against an actual person. Instead their three characters are controlled by the computer. And since the computer is dreadful at this game, the only way the computer can win is by having victory magically handed to them. Every single day I see the exact same cheating tactics and that is what makes me angry about the gameplay. The opponents gets everything they need for their abilities magically apearing on the top row, they get deadly cascades of nodes dropping endlessly and I have seen them clear one row only to have it replaced completely with nodes of a color they need.I finally had enough of this game. I don't enjoy playing a game where victory is handed to the opponent, when there obviously was no nodes to ensure their victory when I ended my turn.2015 updateOne year after writing the review originally, I decided to see if things have changed for the better. Some things are better, while others have the exact problems as last year.Improvements- Many new heroes. Easier to collect some heroes that were concidered "rare" last time I was playing. - Updated abilities for older characters, making some of them better to use. - City nodes are replaced with team-up nodes. You have three team up cards (which can be given to you by your alliance and found randomly) that can be used with team up points. These are far better than the city nodes and have actually helped me win some games.- A daily quest which gives you a chance to get rare heroes or plenty of resources. Things that still are flawedOpponents still cheats horribly. Anytime I try to play anything that isn't 50 levels below me, the cheating AI will kill my team with no effort. They get cascades (nodes endlessly falling and matching), you move one node and they get a perfect 4 or 5 on their next turn and they color starve you, to force you to play "bad" while they get what they need through the toprow.Anytime you loose, the game gives you horrible advice how to win. Let's analyze why this doesn't work anymore:Put down protection nodes to decrease incoming damage. Reality: The AI's will clear your nodes within a few turns. The first time I put down Invisible Womans bubble that shields a character from all damage, it was cleared instantly by the computer getting a cascade.Keep your weakest characters in the back to shield them from damage. Reality: The game deliberately forces you to only move certain nodes, which forces your weakest characters to the front. Kill the strongest opponent firstReality: You have to kill whichever character has a cascading ability or the least amount of point to charge their ability. One of the most difficult opponents in the game is Juggernaut, because he combines both of these. His 2 abilities cost very little (6 points). One cascades, the other deals a little damage to himself and a lot to you. So he cascades, deals damage to you, cascades, deal damage to you. The sad thing is? Juggernaut is one of the weakest characters you can recruit on your team, being only a 1 star character. But for AI events, he is buffed up and kills you easily.Prevent the enemy from collecting colors their need.Reality: Either the AI are teamed up with another AI that gives them free points or they simply cascades and get the points they need from the toprow.Collect colors you need for your strongest abilitiesReality: The game forces you to only move certain nodes. Whenever 2-star Storm is on my team, I only need 11 blue nodes to charge her ability. There is very rarely a single blue node when she is on my team. Most of the time, you are only allowed to collect pink nodes, which is one of the weakest colors in the game. And then watch the AI get the colors they needed through the toprow. Other problems with gameplay- Enemy AI usually have few colors to collect, which makes it easy for them to make a lot of damage in little time. Ninjas and thugs usually have abilities that cost 4 mana, they get free mana because they aren't allowed to move nodes and the countdowns are just 2-3 times long. Unless you are really lucky, it's very difficult to clear those nodes in time. Because you rarely have anything to match them with. - The "match node helper" will regularly point out a bad move while ignoring a 4-5 match. - Because cascades happen so regularly, you need to waste health packs often. You never know if your character will survive with only half of their life.ConclusionThere's no strategy in this game. You win if you are lucky. Even though technically my characters are 50 levels above the other team and should massacre them.  I feel dumbed down when I play, because I always look for a good move and still loose because my characters can't match colors they need.

												The game concept is very fun and interesting. There are many events happening all the time. It would have a lot of potential if not for...- Money grab tactics to progress. Forced to spend Hero Points (hard to earn unless you spend money) just to buy slots to have +1 character. These slots get more expensive with each few slots you buy, until it gets out of hand expensive.- If you want to play for free and win some good characters and Hero Points, you need to schedule your life around the game's events starting and ending time. (EDIT: this seems to have been addressed.)- PvP system is implemented in a way that forces you spend to spend Hero Points to be competitive.- The game seems to progress nicely in the beginning until you hit several deadends which will tempt you to spend money.Try it out if you wish, DON'T spend money at all until you played for at least 2 or 3 months. You will regret it. It has potential, if you don't mind spending money on a game every week and have no real life commitments, this may be a game for you.

content:
, 2014
												Long story short:This was a viable puzzle game.  While it had some issues, these were not too severe.  Loosely based on the Marvel comic event Dark Reign, you did the usual match 3 gameplay to beat up the Dark Avengers ..... over and over again.  Before the most recent patch, this was probably the worst part of the game as there are only so many times you can defeat the same five characters repeatedly.Then the healing nerf hit.D3, in a fit of absolute greed and the worst show of judgement, decided to patch the game so that any and all healing buffs were now "False healing" in order to force the player to buy more healing packs in order to continue to play past two or three matches.  This nerf not only crippled the healing characters, it has made characters such as Sentry unplayable.  By eliminating the low-level hot dog stand healing, even people who are just starting out are affected negatively by this change.In the end, there are better Free-to-Play or even match-3 puzzle games to invest your time in than this misuse of the Marvel License.

content:
4, 2014
												You'll see plenty of reviews that tackle what the developers have done to absolutely bend over their once-loyal players. But, I'll still add my voice to that camp.The game starts out deceptively fair for a Free-to-Play. But I've spent money because I wanted to support it, I absolutely love match-3 puzzle games, and MPQ began very strong. I expected to get more out of my real money and time invested. But in the end, the microtransactions carry some of the most ludicrous price tags I've ever seen. Especially once you realize how shafted you are. If you max out a hero's level capacity (Each hero has a maximum level directly proportional to its rarity) you can spend ISO (a f2p resource earned from playing) to level them once the right number of 'covers' (item drops that level up 1 of 3 abilities a hero has) has been obtained.The developers are just NOT providing the level of return investment quality in their microtransactions. And they know it. You have to spend a STAGGERING amount of money or a nigh-impossible amount of game time to acquire competitive max-level high rarity heroes. Look at my total time played. I legitimately have 3 maxed out uncommon heroes and a handful of level 15-50 uncommon and rares. When I look at the amount of hours invested, I'm not upset. It's a great distraction at my relatively low-demanding job, but at the same time, I don't feel the devs have spent nearly as much time developing meaningful addons, GRAPHICAL IMPROVEMENTS (ffs this game is a goldmine) or a truly diverse lineup of Marvel originals.All in all, give it a try if you like puzzle games, but honestly, there are more rewarding ones out there. I'm turning my back on it and putting my disposable income on something else.

												I wanted to like this game.  Puzzle Quest is one of my favorite time killers, and this borrows heavily from that game and adds a neat three on three dimension that I found cool.  But the leveling up system is stupidly complicated and based on a degree of luck that sucks all the fun out of it.  You're HP is not restored to full power after each match, which means you either have to wait around half the day for it to regenerate or you can purchase the in-game currency that will let you restore it immediately.  After getting frustrated as hell with MPQ: DR for a couple of weeks, I deleted it from my library.  Save yourself the trouble and don't bother trying it.  Go buy the sequel to Puzzle Quest instead, or maybe Galactrix.  Don't get sucked in just because it features Marvel superheroes.

content:
9, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign ReviewA game titled Marvel Puzzle Quest has a lot to live to up to. Not for the Marvel part, but instead due to the deserved respect and love that Puzzle Quest received for successfully creating a hybrid RPG/Bejeweled-style match-three game. Marvel Puzzle Quest has taken the idea of a puzzle game with with a strategic/role-playing element overlay, and turned it into an intricately crafted, remarkably deep experience.In Marvel Puzzle Quest, you control three superheroes who fight against up to three other supervillains/heroes (or goons, in some of the plot missions). When matched, the six colors of gems on the board grant energy that can be used for special moves, like purple matches helping Hawkeye use “Take Aim,” a skill that ensures a critical hit. Every match also serves as an attack, but the amount of damage depends on individual characters' affinity with the color – which also gives combo attacks a nice superhero fight feel to them, where Iron Man lands a punch and then Black Widow jumps in. Meanwhile, skills that offer buffs to defense/strength, or do damage over time, manifest as changes to tiles on the board, which can be matched and eliminated. Thus, the board becomes amazingly tactical – there are up to half a dozen potential considerations beyond “best match” at any given point.Unfortunately the game ended up being a pay to win game with overpriced micro-transactions.

												This is a great game completely ruined by the mobile phone game business model. Energy, timers, grinding leveling, this game has it all. It's basic concept is really fun, but overshadowed by what I just mentioned. It's basically a match 3 game mixed with a RPG type battles. This part of the game is actually really fun. 5, 2016
												Wow, I admittedly downloaded this game because I was rather made eager by the Marvel and Free package, and whats more it seemed to not be like the crummy Marvel games of yore that make you pay to do anything more than hop.  But alas through my initial enjoyment of the game I realized when the AI takes over for other players, and better yet when you are playing only AI, the odds are drastically in the AI's favor that the select colors they need will drop.  This is okay, I thought, all it means is my time in this game will be a bit more challenging.  Then I saw changes as the game kept updating, the AI still was favored, but now things would happen like my entire team dropping dead on my turn (the first turn) when no match was made and no power fired.  I sent an email looking for an explanation, thinking maybe it was an accidental bug, I got a computer generated impersonel response that was not even pertinent to my query.  I decided to grin and bare it, it actually got better after the next update.  After some time though suddenly it started getting worse, the AI was using powers it had no way of using (no AP) and often dealing 2-3x the damage it should have been, the only improvement from before is I no longer watched my whole team die on turn one, now it was turn five.I finally decided to delete the game and send a carefully worded letter to the techs, this was and is the only Marvel game I ever actually liked, and even was pondering spending money on it.Edit: The email I was awaiting from the game people finally arrived, titled "Our Friend" and in German.  I never told them I spoke what little German I do, so this seems like another generic, "we will make you happy" attempt.

												Whenever i see someone call this a game i can't help but laugh for at least a minute because in reality it is just a shameless attempt of a money making scheme, with the most serious offence being the health logic.It has a health carry over after each fight, alongside a health pack limit of 5 and generating 1 every half hour (unless you have no value of money and can pay for more.) Meaning you have to stop playing after a few battles. Seriously, who in their right mind thought that limiting play time would be a good thing!Trying to level up the powers of rarer characters is pretty much out of the question if you're avoiding spending money on them, which is ridiculous...The story plummets after the first chapter (not that it was particularly interesting to begin with) and becomes a series of pointless fights with goons and soldiers.Downloading this game as a Puzzle Quest installment or a Marvel game will only lead to disappointment. And do not mistake this as a free to play as you will find this game increasingly impossible the further you go.

content:
ber 6, 2016
												I really can't recommend this game even though I am still playing it and have lots of hours invested.  It really is a solid match 3 game but the meta game is the problem.  If you do not invest money (probably lots), you will progress at a snails pace.  There are so many heroes, and for the most part you will get them at random meaning you will end up with lots and lots of poorly covered heroes.  The higher the rarity, the bigger the problem.  Also you will need roster spots to even recuit the heroes you have won.  These can only be bought with premium currency (which you do get from playing) which means you will often have to sell your hard earned covers or pay real money for roster spots.  This is especially bad early in your career.  Heroes are added every two weeks, so the problem is only getting worse with time, not better as you would hope.The biggest problem with the game though, is lack of new content.  I could live with the above problems if new, fun stuff was coming out, but I am playing almost the same game as I was almost 2 years ago.  Boss battles were added, but they are rare and alliance based (so not much fun if you aren't on a good alliance).  There have only been 2 or 3 stories added since I started (not counting rare, short events that are only seen once or twice a year).  That means 75% of the stories are against the Dark Avengers which means you are fighting the same villians over and over.  And to compete in these events?  You need to beat each pin (battle) 4-6 times.There is also PvP but that is against AI controlled player rosters.  As the heroes are not the most balanced in the world you tend to see certain teams and heroes a lot there.  And they almost always be of similar strength which makes it feel very grindy.  And both PvP and PvE are time based, there is no content that you can play at your own pace other than the short introductory stories that you can only play once.  So to get the good prizes you need to devote lots of time to them.  Whether a paying player or not.So bottom line, don't play this.  The match 3 is fun and can get some people hooked.  Do yourself a favor and don't let that happen.  At least until they address the problems above which isn't likely to happen.

												When I saw the other user reviews I thought that their playtimes were ridiculous and that you can't jugde it based on 0.3 hours but when I tried it I found you can judge it on 0.3 hours, the "tutorial" doesn't tell you anything about all the numbers popping on screen, it doesn't bother eplaining them, fortunately it's kind of obvious what they mean. It gives off the impression that it's a basic match 3 game but NOPE it's not, it's got various mechanics that might have actually been cool. However they don't bother explaining these until you have already figured them out, with the exception of the powers they do tell you about those.   Speaking about the powers, the ones they start you off with at first seem cool with Iron Man's repulsor blast dealing like solid 63 damage but later on the enemies have so much health it begins to suck. Also the story, I can't say I payed much attention to it because it was dumb but the writing was horrible it was cheesy and boring, not even cheesy and funny just boring and and the beginning they start off with Iron Man, yeah fine whatever but then they throw in Storm, for no reason at all just because why not, lets throw in a completely unrelated character to team up with Iron Man to take down some lame ♥♥♥ bad guys and the enemies have unoriginal names, like soldier and sniper. There is probably a pay to win aspect but I couldn't play it long enough to notice, oh wait yes I could in the first 5 minutes they tried to force me to use some healing thing to heal my hero which wasn't even badly damaged, if you don't heal your heroes they can't fight no matter how much health they have, they could be only 5 hp short and you'd just have to wait for them to heal or use up one health pack if your lazy and eventually enemies deal enough damage to prevent you from playing for a minimum if 4 minutes if you don't use the health pack, how do you get more health packs? You either play missions which you can't do because your hero is injured or you buy them. Don't waste your time with this go play Bejeweled on your phone or something instead.

												Not even gonna lie this game is dope.This game is a black hole of time, but at least for me I don't mind, I often have fun with the game when I  play it, and I look forward to the daily rewards. Despite being a "match 3 game for kids and soccer moms", I think that it is an enjoyable game, and way more in depth than anyone cares to give it credit for. That being said there are a lot of times where I think "man, this game really is all about luck", whether it is the rolling for covers or cascades.+Fun and enjoyable, plain and simple.+Love the Marvel tie in, and often adds new awesome characters. (shout out to the silver surfer)+It is not a very attention heavy game, it is something that you can do while doing other things if you want to.+The characters and abilities give a depth to the game that adds to the experience.+There is not time limit on matches, or idling.-Embarrassing when your friends see you playing.-Largely luck based.-IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO HAVE TWO ACCOUNTS ON ONE PC.-No ability to share accounts across platforms.-A little bit of a slow start roster-wise.As for the common freemium complaint, for the most part I am free to play, only putting in a few dollars to get one extra space, or trying the VIP program. I see no reason to complain about the features, since it is a free game, and real green dollars are not outright needed to progress. In all I have gotten more enjoyment and time out of this game than some retail AAA titles, and have spent less. It is nice to be able to help and support something that is free and also as a bonus be rewarded.I hit up the Deadpool Daily everyday, and I will keep playing it and enjoying it. I am excited for the new characters and features, and recommend this game to anyone who wants a low commitment daily game to play.

content:
er 28, 2016
												Remarkably, this game has gotten worse and worse regarding stability over the last three years. This game was a hidden gem three years ago, was an excellent game two years ago, and was a pretty good game last year.  Now the game has become so bad that they recently lost their community manager, and the forums are overrun with valid complaints and frustrated people who are giving up the game.Customer support for this game is worse than nonexistent. If the game is buggy, expect to impact you negatively. If you have technical difficulties around an item not showing up in your inventory, do not expect any help.Recent "innovations" include such gems as "view a commercial for this in game reward", and new game mode start being introduced are so broken but the game will choose not to award any points for a boss if you do not allow the boss to at least hit you first.The game continues to raise the level of characters introduced, which means in game currency inflation has gone wild, but the long time entrenched players are still the only ones that stand a chance of winning any of the major prizes.The game has an alliance concept, which means that in order to get the best rewards, you have to join an alliance with very active players. In a completely non-fun meta game, you can go around forums and find which alliance you should join to maximize your game time ROI.At one point this was a five star game for me, albeit with bugs, balance and alliance issues. At that time, there was a community manager who intervened when I had some unpleasant customer support issues, and the game was reasonably balanced, fresh, and fairly bug free. People who didn't want to pay to win could still have a lot of fun.In its current format, the game is trying to milk as much money out of the new players, and as many ad use out of everyone, as possible. The new VIP system means that for $10 a month you can (maybe) be remotely competitive in this free to play game.In short, stay away.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												So I have very mixed feelings about this game.  I have to say, it's worth avoiding so-called "Free to Play" games, as they intentionally abuse game design and put it not in the service of telling a story or making a compelling experience or whatever, but rather in the service of getting microtransactions out of the player.  It don't think it's possible to avoid that, save for doing a shareware model where you're playing an extended demo for free.I assumed the above before playing any "free to play" games, and I'm more certain of it after sinking time in to quite a few over the past year or two.All that said, Marvel Puzzle Quest is the best of them I've yet seen, and there's a lot of fun to be had from it...but at the same time, it would be a better game were it designed like the mainline Puzzle Quest games that you just purchase and play.  There doesn't appear to ever be an endgame here...it's basically just repeating story elements that ultimately are trying to get you to pay money, but never really lead anywhere.  I've seen stories in this repeated a half dozen times now, sometimes slightly mixed up, sometimes the same storyline/quest has repeated literally twice in a row.And it's a shame, because a lot of what's here is actually great.  I played Puzzle Quest 2 while playing this, and I actually like the basic "puzzle combat" gameplay here better.  The art is generally fantastic too (and looks better and the screen layout is much better on PC than on iOS/Android).  This is the most fun I've ever had with the basic mechanics of a single screen action puzzle game.The adaptation of characters' powers to the gameplay is well thought out-they're clearly trying and mostly succeeding in making it work.  I won't lie, it's a lot of fun to collect and power up your favorite characters and have them beat down your opponent.  But it gets frustrating when you realize it’s really towards no end…there’s no endpoint, just that endless repetition of mostly identical story elements recycled again and again.  The most egregious way they try to get you to spend (a lot) of money on it is for slots to hold characters.  They give you a very small number at the start, and since both for gameplay reasons and because it’s cool to have them, you’ll quickly want/need vastly more slots than they give you.  You technically earn the resources to buy slots within the game, but that’s a VERY slow process that’s not very practical-I think since I started playing they’ve made that worse too.  You’re pretty much forced into paying real-world money to be able to have the slots you’d want and need to actually continue playing.So would I recommend this?  There’s so much fun in it, and it’s so well done in many ways…and yet at the same time, there’s no ending.  There’s no resolution to the story.  It’s just a fancy treadmill to get you to pay more, and it’s a shame that this same effort wasn’t put towards making this a “real” game.  Even an MMO model might make more sense for it (as it is actually an MMO in many respects).  I'm putting thumbs down because Steam forces me to thumb it up or down.  I'd rather just leave that blank, and I’d probably give it 3 Stars on the Netflix model because so much is fun and works, and yet so much doesn’t by the nature of what it is…  (And yes 3 stars is positive and thumbs down negative, but...I don't know, I couldn't quite give it 2 stars, were that an option, and yet I also don't feel like I can exactly recommend it...)

content:
er 18, 2013
												A "free-to-play" puzzle quest with Marvel characters. If that's all it was, it might have been a fun game. There are a lot of issues working against it though. You're supposed to collect cards, but since you only have a very limited roster, you only want to keep the most powerful cards you can find or just stick with the main couple cards you start out with because they're the ones that level up. If you don't make room for them in your roster, new cards disappear. There's no way to measure your roster's progress on leveling up; when you do level a card up, you have to spend the crystals to actually increase the level. Most of the puzzle rounds have multiple rewards (I guess to push "replayability") but evidently the rewards are randomized so that you could play a single round dozens of times but never get all 4 rewards. I don't mind that the cards must "heal" when they take damage during a round, but the more powerful the enemies, the more damage, the longer time they have to heal. Eventually you can only play 2 or 3 rounds before your entire roster is down. So you have to grind for rewards but can't grind because your team's down. If this was a tablet game, it wouldn't be a big deal; on the PC, why play a game only as long as it takes to start it up? Of course, this is all not a problem if you're fine with paying lots of real money for the tokens.

content:
8, 2014
												I would love to recommend this game, but at it's current state it's a mixed bag. The puzzle element is really solid and damn addictive, I will go more in to the flaws at the end of the review,but if you want to enjoy it(without spending money) there are some tips.1. Use most of the iso you get for training your heroes instead of buying covers, at least in the beginning, it is slow to grind with low level heroes on missions that you have already gathered all the iso from. Also focus on three heroes at the start, so you have at least one team that can defeat more difficult opponents. 2. Use the hero points for roster upgrades, the game limits how many heroes you can have and you very quickly fill all your slots.3. You can't really reset your progress, so a bad start can really destroy enjoyment.4. Start slow, you get some reward daily and they help you progress5. Take part in events, they are really difficult at the very beginning and often require heroes you might not have. but they offer nice rewards and are generally entertaining. More so when you've played the game for a little longer.What I hate about the game.1.Monetization, while not bad as a concept, this game has ridiculous prizes for it's currency, and as usual the more valuable resource is very limited ingame without paying. Events feature heroes that are powered up in them, and if you want to buy them quaranteed, it costs about 20 euros, hero slots start at about 1€ a spot but quickly double that. You get heroes at random, and if you want a copy of specific cover to level up power and also the level cap of the hero, you can spend money for that, 1 star hero is about 1€ per cover, 2 star is about 5€, 3 star cover is closer to 10€ and 4-star cover is about 25€.You also can't buy new select covers for heroes, the powers have to be unlocked via randomly acquired cover or event prize. And after the power is unlocked the power could be upgraded by paying.2.Difficulty on campaign ramps up pretty fast, creating a paywall of some level that feels that appears very early, more so if you had a bad start.3.Campaign length. You start with a tab Prologue, that has 5 maps, each with about 15 battles. the difficulty really ramps up at the 4th one. Then when you finally clear the prologue, the campaign at least so far is over. After that there are only the events and pvp against other player teams that are controlled by AI. so the game becames more of a gotta catch them all, with no other real goal and that is handicapped by monetization.4.LevelingThe whole leveling up system seems to have been designed with monetization in mind. You need iso to level up, the cost get higher and the rate at which you get it becomes slower when there are no new missions to play and old missions give almost negligible amounts. You hero's maximum level is capped by how many covers for him/her you have, and how rare the hero isSome random numbersGraphics 7. They are nice, not groundbreaking, but feel very fitting for this gameGameplay 9. Very addicting once you get the hang of it, AI is kind of stupid at times which i guess just happensWriting and sounds are decent but i mainly play on the background while doing something else so can't really rate them.Monetization 2. everything feels like it has very bad value and not much incentive to use the option. And it really hurts the gameOverall 4. The actual gameplay is great, but is dragged down by lack of content, goals after the short campaign and monetization centric design.

												It's a trap! All and all don't waste your money and time on this game, it's just too random.  Play for free or only use money to unlock roster slots.   Never ever pay to upgrade one star characters.The monetization of this game is frustrating.  Unlocking characters and powers are one and the same and come from a random event called recruiting. To compete in multiplayer challenges you need rare characters who can exceed level 50.  With that said, I'm hooked, hundreds of hours.... I can't get out.

7, 2014
												I am a big fan of Marvel heroes, however this game is very tedious and monotonous. It is free to play, so the game steers you toward spending money in order to compete without spending hours on end grinding through the game, This game, overall, is bad.This is a puzzle quest game.  You start off with a few 1 star characters and either earn others by playing the game or buying a chance to get certain characters. Characters range from 1 to 4 stars. Simply match gems to attack, no skill involved. Matchs drag on and useless animations, that you cannot disable, draws out these matches needlessly.MPQ can get frustrating, and is very repetitive. When it is time for you to lose;  you will lose. The computer will cascade massive amounts of gem matches, continue to find extra turns, and color starve you until you lose. This happens often, how else would they get you to spend money to buy heals, a chance for characters, and levels.  I play on and off, but I would not recommend this game at all.

But still, after maxing you have to play against enemies - 140lvl, 240lvl - no problem with that, if you're lucky and know how to build your team for a battle. For beginners this game is now unplayable, because of level of the challenge. One of most unbalanced games I ever played.Also develepers still pushing you to pay. You have lost a battle? You need recharge( so wait hours or pay). You want to level up? you need Iso-8. You want to win anything? Just pay!You can say you get Iso from battles - yes, but how much? 100Iso as a reward of won match against deadly 240lvl enemies is piece of crap, not a reward.Also, even if you buy gold, you want to have THIS character.. no no no! That's not that easy. Still you can't buy character you want, just test your luck. You probably get a character you have maxed, and it's useless until then.TL:Dr - don't play, it's crap, pay to (maybe)win.
