content:
y 12, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign has been out on iOS and Android for a few months now, and recently came out on Steam. While being free-to-play makes it harmless enough to check out, it is not one of the better games of this model out there. Tribes Ascend and Path of Exile are just a few examples of how this model can be applied to a game with great success. Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign gets 2 out of 5 stars. While most will get some passing enjoyment out of this puzzle game’s use of strategy and RPG elements, the sluggish UI and sub-par graphics, as well as the deluge of micro transactions, makes this one hard to recommend to even the most ardent of Marvel or Puzzle Quest fans.Full review at: http://www.hbhud.com/2013/12/09/review-of-marvel-puzzle-quest-dark-reign/

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2014
												I picked this up on a lark because of how much I enjoy match-3 type games (mindless, easy to play while watching T.V., etc).  Surprisingly, I've found this game to be really fun.  It's similar to Puzzle Quest in that there is added depth to the match-3 concept, and the PvP aspect as well as repeated Events keep me coming back.I'm editing this, as I see a ton of negative reviews due to the micro-transaction concept this game introduces.  It's a F2P game, the company has to make money so I don't see a problem with them charging to play more.  I've sank about $15 into this game and played for 30 hours, which is cheaper than most other forms of entertainment and quite a bit more I've gotten out of other games for similar price.  That being said, you don't need to pay a lot of cash.  Play smart, pick your fights, and you can pace yourself and naturally heal over time if that's your thing.

content:
er 30, 2013
												This may be a "Free To Play" game, but like most of the lame flash games you see on Facebook, this game heavily revovles around micro-transactions. If you're not familar with the abusive nature of micro-transaction dependent games, then read some of the more in-depth reviews (like the ones with 4+ paragraphs) to get more details. The only positive thing this game has over the flash games on Facebook is that:1) the game doesn't lag as much as the ones on FaceBook, 2) this game won't force you to spam all of your FaceBook friends, &3) it has characters from the Marvel franchise. As for the puzzle game itself, I find it infuriating! I am not merely saying this because I am a poor loser. I get my ♥♥♥ kicked all the time in MOBA & fighting games, but I can still enjoy those games. When I make a mistake in those games, I can usually see alternative moves that could have been made & understand how the consequences of the mistake could have been avoided. In this game, when you destroy blocks, new blocks will fall down to replace the destroyed blocks, sometimes the replacement blocks will just conveniently share the same color & coinciding create a chain reaction, doing massive damage. I am not talking about the pieces that are already on the board & merely fall down. I speaking of the new pieces that weren't on the board previously. Because of this, destroying block on the bottom half of the board is usually more advantageous then destroying the block near the top edge of the board.Unlike most puzzle games, such as "Tetris", there is no preview of the new incoming blocks that appear from the top of the game board, so there is no way to prepare for them, offensively or defensively. Many times, chain combos will just happen by accident & sometimes for massive damage; sometimes for you, sometimes against you. This can be a HUGE reward that is being giving out, not for any brilliant strategy or careful planning, but just by sheer randomness. Unless one team is heavily more over-powered than the other, without a preview of the next set of falling blocks, the outcome of the match relies too heavily on luck. You might as well be playing a slot machine. I'm still gonna play this game though, just because I'm as much of a sucker as those who do play slot machines.

content:
2015
												It's simply amazing how the good old bejeweld game can be converted into a 'story based' game with a huge cash grab.Lets start with the 'story based' theme... Your own a team of Marvel heroes that need to grow in their powers. This is all done around a pretty thin story with extremely boring dialogues. Even before I was through the tutorial I kinda clicked all the dialogues away that boring are they!And that brings me to the cash grab... To level your heroes you need Iso-8 AND LOTS OF IT! I was 'lucky' to recieve a legendary level 70 hero early in the game - he really made things extremely easy for me. Leveling up my other heroes I stumbled into the upcoming payment wall (cash grab). To level from level 20 to the next stage (it hops with quite a number of levels - around 4 or 5 at this point) I need over 3K Iso-8. That's either playing a lot (you get an average of 50 Iso-8 a game) or play with your creditcard and buy the 3K Iso-8 for around $5. And that's only at level 20. Remember that 'lukcy' drop I had of my level 70 hero..? I don't even want to know how many Iso-8 I need for that one!Will I play this game for hours a day to grind for the Iso-8 I need to keep playing it..? No thanks! There are a lot better Free2Play games out there that offer a bigger variety in gameplay and are more fun. Not to mention, I do have more to do on a day than play Marvel Puzzle Quest for hours...

er 9, 2013
												This game is the utter definition of pay 2 win. With cash roadblocks at new characters, new skills, skill level ups, and healing, expect to find yourself grinding the same missions over and over hoping to make enough funny money to have a chance at earning a character that is strong enough to beat the next stage and having to wait up to a hour(at least for 30 and under) real time for your characters to heal back to full health. Since you can't level up without having more skill levels, and leveling up lower level characters is pointless anyways since their skills do not scale with the levels of HP, you're forced into this loop until you get a lvl 30 character that breaks the game for a few hours, until they are too weak as well.  Stick with the first 3 games, because this is game is a great example of what the F2P greedy cashgrab can do to a series.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
y 14, 2014
												I don't know what all the F2P haters are complaining about. In the time I've been playing it I've never been urged, coaxed, solicited or strongarmed to spend real money. This game doesn't even feature ads or constant bombardment of things they want you to buy. If you want to buy copious amounts of coins to level up your characters quicker you can but it's not necessary as this game features weekly events that reward you with the same coinage you can pay money for. Anyways, sure there's microtransactions but they're in no way disruptive or "pay to win". That being said this game isn't as good as all the other puzzle quest games. The storylines are pretty shallow but you're not going to play this game for the story. This is a nice little match 3 game in the same vein as the other Puzzle Quest games but the events keep things fresh as you can battle other players teams in the weekly tournaments or other special events. There's an array of characters to choose from/fight/win and you can quickly level up during those particular times. So you can pick it up and play a few rounds between the AI or other player's teams and kill some time in between whatever more important thing you're taking a break from.

content:
ber 24, 2015
												Edit: I should have well over 300 hours in by it now. I am in a casual do-dailies-turn-up-for-events alliance. I am on day 521 of my Rewards. I have 30 champed 3-star heroes. And I still stand by my review below. Game is great, I like the devs, changes by and large make sense. But there is still no cross-play between PC and mobile. No thumbs up for you.=======I really enjoy this Match-3 game, between PC and Tablet I've put in well over 100 hours into it. Got every single reward from the tutorials, placed well in a few Story events (which are an interesting system of different timed thematical storyline events that spit out rewards every day or three) because I have pockets of time through the day which this fills nicely. Even dabbled a bit into the Versus system, where you fight other players' teams for rank and rewards, but the AI controls the opponent teams since Match-3 gameplay doesn't lend itself well to a realtime PvP system at all.My roster's not as developed as long-time players yet, I have a bunch of 2-star heroes, a number of 3-stars with 1 or 2 powers, and a couple 4-stars from event rewards that I lean heavily on. (Star basically = rarity/power rating, with 1 stars being the lowest and 4 being the highest with a 5 now just released in an update). Enemies in story fights seems to scale according to your overall roster level, which is neat, because it allowed even my newer PC account to jump right in to a story event and place high enough to get top tier rewards.The game is F2P with microtransactions, but the MT's are so RNG based that you don't really get to P2W very effectively unless you spend a ton, I think, and even then you can win loads of the same MT items just from several hours put into the story events, or by focusing your free time into an event that you think you can do well in.Yet I hesitate to give this game a positive recommendation. I like it, but one thing really irks me. As a microtransaction-based game, it's unforgivable in my eyes that the accounts from different platforms play together but people cannot access their mobile account on PC and vice versa. If you are making a microtransaction game, especially since I noticed the mobile version already has Google+ and Facebook integration, you have to have this basic functionality since the game's pricing model is based on constantly spending money.So while I like the game, I will not give it my recommendation until this is implemented as I feel that this is a necessary step for them to earn my thumbs up. They apparently have manually merged some accounts "in the past" but have since stopped doing so for everyone else.

content:
10, 2014
												Despite a lot of negative reviews criticizing this game for the microtransactions, I highly recommend it. The microtransactions are mainly for "hero points," which is a rare currency in the game that is mainly used for increasing your roster size and letting you collect more heroes/villains. I have played for about 30 hours at the time of this review without a single penny spent and I've loved it. Now that we've covered the microtransactions, the real review.Marvel Puzzle Quest is a match three game, like Candy Crush Saga or Bejeweled. Each team has three heroes (or villains) per battle, and each match you make gives damage to the enemy team. You can earn more characters for your team by completing battles, winning PvP and campaign events, or buying them using Iso-8 (another currency which is much more common) and Hero Points. PvP Events are released frequently, which let you fight another player's team which is usually paired up with a hero from that event, like Deadpool or Wolverine. There's also a campaign mode where you fight game A.I. for Iso-8 and sometimes Hero Points.Overall, I'd say it's a really cool game and despite all the negative reviews, you should download it and check it out.

												I got into this one thinking, "Gee, if the mobile version is any indication, it would be wonderful to have a supplementary version I can switch to at will on my PC and play when I want a fullscreen experience." While waiting for the download I scrolled down to the reviews and notice not a single recommend. After playing it for more than two minutes it's clear to me why.Having played on my Galaxy SIII prior to this, I assumed (incorrectly) that there would be some way to link my accounts and resume play on the desktop version, perhaps Facebook or Google+ or such. But nope. If you played the game on your smart device, you haven't played it on PC. No such option exists, and it sends you straight through the exact same tutorials I went through on the mobile version, albeit with a rather poorly designed interface (if you can really say there's one to speak of).The horrible design I can somewhat deal with (I expected a superior version to mobile), but upon learning that there was no way to sync between my smart device and this version, complete dealbreaker. I realize people bash the crap out of D3's decision to make the game pay to win, but I actually have put money into it prior, so seeing the branding not scale whatsoever between versions is a pitiful excuse at best. If they fix this (which is unlikely, given the game seems to think you're playing it on a tablet by design and is literally a direct port of the widescreen tablet version), I would possibly love the desktop version until the end of time. As it is, I'm sure not paying money all over again for the same content.

er 20, 2013
												This is good attempt to make F2P from Puzzle Quest. There are only familiar PQ battles - no pets, no equip, no locks - only the battles. But they are quite good. And the upgrading Marvel heroes instead equip makes it interesting too. There is one problem though - the new heroes requires a new slots, and without slots you most probably will miss your special rewards. But game was quite generous to give me 7 slots from initial questing money, and later... well, I shell be able to manage it later. But if you want the many different heroes, fast, prepare to pay.As it's F2P, payment or grinding for battle wins expected, as usual. All your heroes lose life force during the battles, and it can be gained only with time - or with the health packs->donations. So if you want a long games, prepare to pay. For me and my half-hour sessions it's all right.The game have quite a big amount of NPC-grinding locations, but most challenges came from PvP battles in special events. Unfortunately, most of time (but not always) it means losing. For my non-buffed heroes one-two battles per day is manageable, but rarely more. But as rewards are much bigger than loses, nothing to complain for me. If I cannot kill today's enemies, I'll farm NPC instead.Bottom line: good PQ-like game for 20-30 minutes per day. Can be frustrating for longer.

content:
4, 2014
												As far as casual games go, this one is pretty epic in it's time-consuming...ness. I enjoy it quite a bit, but I've always been a fan of puzzle games, not excluding the 'match 3' genre. This one isn't as in-depth as say... Puzzle Quest 2 which is made by a totally different company, but I think there's still enough there if you want something more than Bejewelled. I think the best part is figuring out which heroes/villains work the best together and trying to build up their combos and such. As far as downsides go, I really don't like the weak AI, the randomness of drops and the money for power aspect. I'll go into each point by point here. The only real challenge comes from the level of your opponent, which determines how much HP they have and damage they do. When it comes to the actual gameplay, you can easily predict what they're going to do as they have certain priorities. They definitely play worse than a thinking person would. I would like it more if they made better decisions, as frustrating as that could be.As far as getting loot goes, you have very little control over what you get. Essentially you do different missions, most of which have four rewards. The first time you beat a mission, you're guaranteed one of them. Typically, you'll get ISO (the game's main currency) Hero Coins (the game's premium currency), heroes or random hero tokens, or boosts. Each time you repeat the mission, you'll have a chance to get a reward that you haven't already received or 20 ISO (which is a tiny tiny amount) This does get frustrating after a while, especially if you're trying to get a specific reward. Now, in order to get more characters, you need to either complete certain missions, trade in recruit tokens of varying quality or progress/place well enough in events (there's usually something going on every day). The problem here is with the tokens. Some guarantee a certain quality of hero, but it's still random since if there's a character you want, there's next to no guarantee you'll get them. They break down the odds on their website, but it doesn't really help. But that's not the worst thing.The worst thing is of course the bane of most free-to-play games. Paying for power. You can buy two things: ISO and Hero coins, the two currencies of the game. ISO is used to level up your characters and buy more low-quality ones. Coins allow you to buy more recruit tokens of higher quality, level up hero powers, (which aside from their actual effects, allow you to raise the character level higher) protect your characters in PvP mode (>:| ) but most importantly, buy more slots for characters. That last one is really frustrating, because you can only increase your character slots with coins, and if you don't want to spend money, you're going to have to inevitably pass up on recruiting certain characters, or get rid of ones you've progressed on in order to get new ones simply because if you don't buy coins, it's a hell of a grind to get more. The worst of the worst is that the coins/ISO are really expensive for your dollar, and I think don't really give you proper value. If you want to make this one of the only games you play it might be acceptable, but if you want to just play casually, I highly recommend not spending the money on it.Myself, I've put in a fair amount of time, so I begrudgingly purchased some coins to help open up some space for more characters on both my steam account and my iPad. ~sigh~Anyways, if you can overlook all the shortcomings, it's still a fun puzzle game, and you CAN get by without dropping any of your hard-earned cash on it. I recommend giving it a try if you're into the genre at all, especially considering it IS free.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												8/30/14 - Changed review to positive, though I imagine it still would be much more of a burden for people starting out to have to deal w/ massive downtimes when they don't have the roster to pick and choose, and remain competitive, when they run out of lives and have to wait, I still enjoy the game quite a bit.  I don't like the new healing mechanic that limits your healing to in-battle only regeneration, but, it's not as much of a game breaker as I had expected.  But again, that might be due to the depth of my roster and having multiple options to choose from in order to play-on while out of lives/regens.  Give it a whirl though, it is addictive.As you can see I have been intensely addicted to this game for months now.  And the game WAS fantastic.  However, in what I still cannot comprehend, the dev's at D3 have decided that they no longer want people to become addicted to their game.  They no longer want us telling our friends how fun it is, how they should give it a go and become MPQ addicts like we are.  No... now they have taken any sense of allowing their players the freedom to play when they want, how they want, w/ whatever characters they CHOOSE to play and have thrown it all in the garbage.  I am an AVID supporter of games and developers who show that they care for, listen to, and support the player community which gives them a job, a fan base, and a slew of addicts who advertise this game as a wonderful time-sink to all their friends/family/co-workers for free.  But apparently, FREE advertising doesn't figure into their bottom line and they would rather lose 1000's of loyal players if it means that 1-2 people w/ the fortune and freedom to invest money at will into buying extra lives every time the RNG unluckily kills off all their characters.  Loyal players who will NEVER pay for, what would be, an endless need for health-packs to keep playing at the times these players have allotted themselves to play... are GONE.  The only competition new players, or even players looking to experiment and try different character/team set-ups, will face are going to be these whales that invest so much money into the game that they are UNBEATABLE.  NO NEW PLAYER WILL STAND A CHANCE when the only competition left are those with pockets deep enough to make it utterly unfair.I will continue to log on 1x -2x a day, in hopes that the dev's will realize, acknowledge, and correct this unfathomably inept decision to cut the legs out from any player who is new, growing, learning, or trying to figure out if the game is WORTH spending real money on.  It makes 0 sense.  NONE.  AT ALL.  If this isn't fixed in a week, I will uninstall this game and move on w/ my life.  And, if you check the hours I have put into playing, I thoroughly understand the mechanics behind the game as well as the MASSIVE hindrance this change would put into my own ability to play.  And I'm not someone w/ a poor roster just wanting to get a feel for it and decide if it's worth my time and money.By refusing to let players develop their own style, experiment w/ different characters w/o the feeling that, if they lose, they'll have to wait 2-6 hours before they can play again, this product is going to plunge into the depths of being another 'free-to-play' game which is in NO WAY competitive, fair, enjoyable, or worth our time and money.  People who love this game and play it daily are already dropping out, along w/ their free advertising... New players will be faced w/ unbeatable teams funded by players w/ pockets deep enough to not care, and this MASSIVELY UNAPPEALING wall of dead-time where they can do NOTHING but sit and wait for the game to slowly heal them over a 2-6 hour period.  IT IS PURELY BAFFLING TO NOT BE ABLE TO COMPREHEND HOW AWFUL THIS WILL BE TO ANYONE WHO WANTS TO FALL IN LOVE WITH A GAME.  How do you hope to attract, entertain, and KEEP players playing when you DON'T let them play for hours on end?  NO ONE is going to pay money, to a game, that they have 0 chance of being able to jump in, experiment, and get their feet wet in competition that is so far skewed towards players who buy the best characters and level them up w/o any work cause they can afford it.  Those players, like myself, who have put in HOURS AND HOURS of time learning the game, developing strategies to be able to out-last, out play, and still remain highly competitive with those players who cheat their way up using cash are going to be GONE.  I sincerely hoped this is fixed in the next 7 days, or I will feel so dumb for having invested so much time and energy into a game which doesn't consider 90% of their fan-base when making decisions about how to move their product forward.Sincerely, A once loyal and dedicated, and HOPEFULLY FUTURE loyal and dedicated, fan and player.

content:
er 16, 2013
												I really enjoy waiting for an hour between rounds while my characters heal... It's bearable at the start when it takes a couple minutes and you can play a few rounds, but it gets steadily worse. The difficulty curve is sharp after the introduction missions, that factor combined with the RNG bejeweled style board means that you'll be watching your heal timer a lot after a failed mission. The demand for cash from D3 publisher is inescapable if you actually want to play the game at any level of efficiency you might need to throw cash at this game. The game gets a plus for having fun game play mixed with Marvel characters, but there are just too many drawbacks to make this game worth recommending. There is a loose RPG system in which you level up characters by collecting comic books, but it's marred by the fact that it too is RNG based (unless you use money).  Some iconic characters are given to you at the start of the game, but everything you get afterwards is all random and the majority of heroes I've received thus far are terrible or useless. You need to continually advance in the game if you desire better rewards, but any impression of success is stymied when you get your seventh 'Hawk-Eye' in a row or some equally as rage worthy hero thanks to the RNG rewards. This game would be much better if there was a way to slowly work towards a hero comic that compliments your roster, one that you can chose and grind towards. Success would feel much better and the grind would be worth the effort if you could finally piece together your Marvel Dream Team and smite some foes with righteous fury. Instead you're forced to use valuable experience, recruitment tokens, and gold to expand your roster never knowing who you're going to get. I've got a 5/5/- black widow and I just keep getting her comic books, it's driving me insane...The gameplay is a bit stiff in comparison to previous iterations of the PQ franchise and some attack animations are slow and repetitive. The graphics aren't anything to write home about and everything just feels slow. This game is a step backwards in almost every area and far too frustrating to be worth time or money. Just get Puzzle Quest 2 and enjoy that game, this debacle doesn't do the franchise justice and is a blemish on an otherwise amazing series of games.

content:
7, 2016
												I do like this game, in fact it is my favorite of all the Puzzle Quest and Bejewelled clone games, but I can not recommend it.First, what I love about this game. The powers. Collecting superheroes, each with their own unique powers to use during gameplay, is fun. And using said powers is easily the main draw to this game. And if that was all this game was, it would be an easy recommend to everyone. But unfortunately it's not. It will take a certain type of gamer to appreciate this game, due to the several hurdles said gamers will have to agree to live with.The cons. This is a very competitive game. As a player, you are expected to compete versus a thousand other players for any type of interesting reward. And you will fail. A lot! You would have to be willing to put in the time, LOTS OF TIME, to grow your collection of heroes, just to be able to compete. And even then, you will still lose. Mainly because winning matches is NOT the way to win the big rewards. Being the strongest (and lots of luck) is. And this is where my biggest complaint falls; this game rewards the older players. The rich get richer, while the poor struggle to survive.There are three areas of gameplay. The Prologue which is entirely single player and then there's the Stories and Versus which is where you will be spending all your time. It's probably best to choose one or the other to focus on for best results, but either way it's still very much an uphill battle. And either way it will be hours upon hours of grind to earn your tablescraps. The worst being how punishing the game can be to those who take a break from the game for severla hours (sleep, school, work, etc.) You can spend 23 hours fighting and securing a top place finish, just to have the rug swept out from under you in the last few minutes. Uncontrollably. Unless you pay.So now we get to the currency of the game. First there's ISO-8 which is fairly easy to come by and mainly used for levelling your heroes. Then there's Gold, which is much more difficult to earn and can be used for either shielding yourself in Versus Mode (which does NOT guarantee anything!) or for adding roster slots so you can collect more heroes to use. You can also spend ISO and Gold on covers (which you use to level hero powers or gain new heroes if you have the roster space.) I do NOT recommend doing so though, since you will gain more covers than you will gain roster slots, meaning a LOT of covers will be going to waste since they come with an experation date. Spend your Gold on roster spaceas and your ISO on levelling heroes and purchasing gameplay boosts to quicken battles. Also note, you will need a big roster because a lot of the Story campaigns will constantly be limitting which heroes you will be able to use.There's also in-game purchases, which I do NOT recommend. You can buy ISO-8 which would be a complete waste of money and also Gold which is much more useful, but I still don't recommend. I did purchase some Gold, but it was more due to wishing to support the game than because it was needed. There is also a new purchase called VIP which will give you daily rewards for a limited time. Browsing over the list of items didn't make it very appealing to me, though it is probably the best over-all deal. If you're looking for an early boost to your game, it would probably help. But again, NOT needed. The only real thing you can give this game is time. Lots and lots of time. A new annoyance though is the constant advertisement for the new VIP purchase though. Almost as bad as the Windows 10 pop-ups!Lastly, there are cheaters in this game. The good news is once found, they are moved to their own private servers. The bad news is before they're found, they will ruin your chances for decent rewards, collecting them for themselves (which is frustrating considering they don't need them because they can just cheat.) Almost every single Story and Versus campaign I've played, one or two of the top spots were filled with players who obviously couldn't be there by normal means. Not even with luck on their side. This is especially frustrating considering how much effort you will need to put into getting the meager spot you end up with.One last thing, this game punishes you for crashing. It doesn't matter if it's from bugs, freezing, crashing, or your internet connection. If you leave a battle it considers you a quiter and punishes you for it. I've even already won a battle, gained my rewards, and had my heroes damaged because of the game server acting up. Nothing on my end. And I've had several battles where the game forgets to shuffle the gems when there's no move, especially after a power is used. The only thing you can do is retreat and lose the battle, no matter how badly you were crushing the AI.So will I continue to play this game? Of course. I'm "invested." But don't follow my lead unless you're okay with what you're getting yourself into. This is NOT a casual, or friendly, game.

												A great game ruined by micro-transactions.Wait 3 minutes for a finished review or pay $.99An amalgamation of Puzzle Quest and Marvel works wonders.  Finding your characters through comic books is a nice touch, and the campaigns, while contrived, are enjoyable.  After all, Puzzle Quest doesn't need any extra flavoring to be addicting and fun.  Marvel just makes an already great concept better.Wait 2 minutes for a finished review or pay $.50The graphics are colorful and crisp, and just seeing screen caps of your favorite Marvel characters draw you in to your inner child.Wait 1 minutes for a finished review or pay $.25My advice is to stay away from this game.  Game studios shouldn't be rewarded for this type of micro-transaction behavior.  Build the game so you can truely play for free [no buying a victory], and enhance your experience for cash.  I would have been happy to pay $20 or more for this game, and then buy additional campaigns later on - but I don't see an end to the well they want money dropped down.  For that reason, I pass.

content:
4, 2014
												This is a fairly basic drop-down puzzle game. It lacks the scope of the mind bending Galactrix and yet remains far more addictive due to the appeal of collecting marvel heroes and boosting their "powers". It is very easy to throw money at early on and I would advise anyone considering it long-term to avoid putting too much effort into developing "one star" heroes since they will quickly become superceeded and the level restriction will eventually make them of little use. Also, the "value" of these heroes in terms of selling them on for iso/coin is nowhere even close to what you will spend to make them worth anything in the first place. This aside, the developers keep things interesting with many daily and weekly events and it is perfectly plausible to play this indefinitely without spending any money at all. This makes MPQ:DR a must for anyone who can resist the urge to splurge from their wallet. Don't get too caught up with it and treat it as casual gaming and it will give you many hours of entertainment.

												A surprisingly great match 3 game that has a good story along with all of your favorite Marvel heroes. You can (via collecting in game cards through playing the game, or if you really want, by paying REAL money) play as pretty much anyone in the Marvel universe. Daken? sure. And when your heroes get beaten up and need a  health replenish, either use an in game health pack (you can win them in game or buy them, your choice) or just play another game for an hour while they recharge their batteries, ready for another fight.It's not a pay to play game, I've put a good few hours into the game and have not spent a penny. If you enjoy match three puzzle games and are looking for something to play to kill a few minutes here and there, you could do a lot worse than Marvel Puzzle Quest.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2014
												Free to play, pay to win taken to the next level.-Pay money if you lose in a stage or wait until your characters recover, recovery time varies from minutes to HOURS!-To level up your characters and progress you need to pay money or be lucky with random drops-Unlocking hero skills can cost 110 Euros or take a lot of luckI was browsing through the f2p games for a bit and wanted a simple game to kill some time since i didn´t really felt like playing one of my games or wasting some time on the internet. That´s how i stumbled upon this seemingly innocent little puzzle game. I always liked superheroes and so i decided to give it a shot. But what was in store for me was actually just a really mean ways of grabbing money. Don´t get me wrong im more than willing to spend a few bucks on a f2p game if i get the feeling it´s a fun game and some real effort went into it. That´s also the reason i own some skins in League of Legends for example.But this here is just a tired puzzle game programmed to bring frustration. It´s hard to explain without having played it, but imagined that you feel cheated in many of the stages. Since there is no time limit you can and have to plan your moves and the basic concept of lining up 3 pieces of the same color can be expanded by planning where the remaining pieces will drop once you remove 3 of them. In some of the stages you are the only one directly moving pieces while the computer just adds pieces with certain effects that harm you, while in others the computer tries to remove pieces aswell. Now i put some planning into my moves trying to maximize the outcome and even chaining pieces and so on, but no matter what sometimes the computer just decides to drop the right pieces for your opponent deliberately. I know this might sound a little like a sore loser, but imagine you spend a few minutes thinking and you make a move that removes a lot of pieces via chains and then the computer just drops 5 pieces of the same color in his turn, dealing even more damage than you did.Ok, ok you might say this is where the difficulty comes from, but it´s just my subjective point of view that it feels incredibly cheap. Also this isn´t the real problem of the game, remember i said somthing about greed and pay to win. When you loose in a stage your heroes faint and will need time to recover after the battle. How long you might ask? How about 2 FU***** hours? Go do your laundry, plant a tree or beat up a hobo, because you will wait or pay. As you level up your heroes they gain more hitpoints but also if they die/faint in a battle it takes forever until you can use them again, unless you pay money... Wow this is farmville standard bulls*** and pretty much what totally kills the game for me.Of course you can own more heroes in case your team gets defeated but the number of heroes you can own/use is limited, how can you own more heroes? Find ingame currency after certain bossbattles or pay money. This ain´t so bad right? After i acquire a hero i´m all set, right? Nope. All the heroes need to level up before they are actually useful in a stage, they all start with low hitpoints and just 1 skill. Furthermore they have a maxlevel capacity of 6 out of let´s say 85, which means you can´t progress until you unlock their higher levels. They can gain maxlevels and skills by finding comicbookcovers after stages, or by buying them. More rare heroes are more powerful and more expensive and can be leveled up beyond the level of your weak starting heroes. Now lets calculate how much 1 hero costs. Assuming you are lucky and get a 3 star hero after buying a random cover for 2 Euros, let´s say Loki for example. Each of his 9 remaing skill points comes at a whooping 12 Euros, which means you would in theory spend 110 Euros on one playable character... wow just wow. For 110 Euros you can buy the lengendary edition of Skyrim... 3 times. Also don´t forget your stronger heroes still need to gain levels until they reach their unlocked maxlevel via Iso-8 but i spare you from calculating that aswell.I have no idea how IGN.com and the other fu**-ups that call themselves reviewers can find this scam of a game even playable, but i assume they haven´t even played it and just wrote whatever the developing company paid them to do.In my opionion you should stay as far away from this piece of sh** as possible.

content:
ry 25, 2014
												This is a frustrating game because there are so many parts of it that could be so good. But that was months ago for me and the longer I play and the longer I see what the devs are doing to the game the less I even enjoy the parts of it that I once did.  Nearly every change since I started playing has been for the worse.It lulls you into thinking that it might be easy or playable when you first start because the matchmaking and enemy difficulty seems to understand how to scale with you at that point but the longer you play the more all of that goes out the window. It becomes this banal uphill struggle for any foothold to just get a measly amount of ISO to level up. And that doesn't matter anyway, the better you do the harder they make they game so you'll do worse the next week until it evens out to just doing boringly.I did spend money on this game, not a lot but that's not the point. This isn't a pay to win game, I mean it could be but only if you put in hundreds of dollars but before an input of that size you're really not getting that much, if anything, out of putting money into this game, Maybe I'm wrong and all the people that seem to win every tournament or even any PvE event are putting money into the game but I don't think so, I just think they started earlier when there was less competition.That's all this game is, an endless and fruitless competition. I've gotten close to even winning a few tournaments but it was a really hollow thing to do that. You have to throw all your time and effort to come away with anything at all and if you play casually you'll get next to nothing because there is nothing outside of the prologue that isn't played against other people and unless you can throw hours and hours and hours a day into this game then past the prologue you'll just founder and flail.It might seem appealing now but don't bother. It will suck the marrow from your bones and leave you wishing you never started. Just go play some old Puzzle Quest games and look up some Marvel Trading cards online to look at, it won't be as enticing but at least it won't leave as bitter as I am at this mess of a game.

content:
ry 11, 2014
												~100 hours for this game. Recent patches made it a disaster. When earlier it could be both casual and competitive at the same time, now its gone worse than pay2win, it made a severe turn for pay2play. In tournaments the rich get richer and new players get f***** up real good. Earlier the developers were co-operative with the community and the game was fun and even a newcomer could make a significant impact on the tournament standings and get some awesome rewards.Don't you worry! the game has microtransactions and you will NEED to spend money on this monstrosity in order to progress or get any rankings in the tournaments.Balancing has gone a rough way, the first big changes to characters came up from nowhere dimilishing their potential entirely. Once a overused always seen char went to plain common or even bad, changes just were too radical and unexpected. The most balancing issue was doubling the common booster prices and making the best boosts costing in-game currency which is nearly impossible to get without spending real money, so... want to fight with the best ways? Okay, go ahead and pay 50cents for each fight, doesnt sound bad? Yeah for the most part you will need at least 40 matches in a tournament to get to the good positions, thats like 20 bucks for simply trying to play the game! Character's skills can also be boosted! only 3-20$ for each cover which you need 15 in order to make one of your characters most useful, not mentioning the huge money drop (a ridicilous amount needed) for boosting it's levels.TL;DR Once a fun and an exciting game 5/5 went to greedy as ♥♥♥♥ microtransactions simply for playing the game, dont even consider supporting the developers. As a free to play -player you cant get anything done.

You have to buy slots. You have to pay to revive your heroes. You have to pay for consumables. Worst of all, the savegames are local on your MyDocuments folder. This game is not entertainment, it's a cashmachine for the developers that once made a cool game called PuzzleQuest1. The person who ever invented the itemmall games with micro-transactions should be shot !

												If you like Puzzle Quest and Marvel, this game is for you. The problem is, as others are saying, it is a microtransaction heavy game. It could be so much better, if they toned down that aspect of it and made the rewards better. I have some high level "covers" thanks to the DLC sale and getting a little lucky with recruit gambles. I would really like to see fair rewards, and the microtransactions turned down a bit. The music is very repetative, so that needs to be improved. You can always just turn the sound off and rock out to your own tracks via windowed mode. Much of this game is a combination of luck and patience, or if you are willing to shed some $$$ it can get good. Many FreetoPlay games have this same mentality, i have also seen many fail because of this. D3 - if you want your game to be a success, take my advice and tone down the money-aspect of the game. If you set it all on making a profit, this game will be short lived. However, if you show that you are willing to ease up power up costs and give better story mode/tournament rewards, people may be more willing to support you and it will work out in your favor. I know i would buy more if you did this. I recommend this game for puzzle quest fans, but, remember that unless your willing to shell out some cash, you are better off playing vanilla PQ 1, 2, and Challenge of the Warlords.

y 7, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is, at the core, a pretty fun experience. There are quite a few characters to aquire for your team (a number which continues to grow as the developers add more characters to the game) and they generally come with unique play mechanics that make certain combinations more effective than others.Characters aside, however, this game falls off the bus very quickly. The game is inaccurately marketed as free to play when, in fact, the only players who will realisitcally be competitive in tournaments or see the end of the single player campaign are the ones who have shelled out anywhere between 50-100 dollars. If you hope to max out your heroes and keep up with the ever growing roster be prepared to spend even more money (100 dollars is not nearly enough to max out a decent character's level). Unfortunately this is not a game I would ever recommend to any sane person. The costs are just too high and the returns too low. When, if ever, the pay to win mechanic is removed this could easily be one of the better puzzle rpgs. Until then stay far away. Marvel Puzzle Quest is a huge disappointment.

If you enjoy match three puzzle games and are looking for something to play to kill a few minutes here and there, you could do a lot worse than Marvel Puzzle Quest.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 30, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign Marvel Puzzle Quest is the newest game in the Puzzle Quest line of games. This series has seen a lot of iterations and copycats over the years, with none being nearly as successful as the original title. This latest is an officially licensed Marvel title with the Puzzle Quest formula. It has the added benefit of being entirely free-to-play. You may of course purchase bonuses like any other free title, but these purchases are not required to play the full game. Is this latest attempt at a Puzzle Quest success worth a look, or should you just let it speed by and fade into the distance? Keep reading, perhaps I can help you decide.  To begin with, the Marvel universe has been utilized pretty well here. You have a team of three characters, each with three possible powers to be used. Typically you begin with one of these powers and you must find comic covers of the character to unlock or upgrade said powers. This also allows you to level up your character a little bit more each time. It’s a system that constantly keeps you feeling like you’re making some kind of progress and it works very well. Winning battles and missions grants you rewards, randomized from a pool of up to four for each story mission, giving you reasons to play missions again and again until you’ve received every reward available. It’s structured remarkably well for any game, let alone a free-to-play title. It’s a nice change of pace to see a free game with a lot of effort put into it. The content level is more than a lot of full priced games have, and the developers deserve some credit for it.  The presentation is decent. Each character is represented by a comic book cover from any number of different Marvel universes, and has a full 3D model as well as a 2D comic profile. Everything is vibrant and colorful and stands out very well in a sea of photo-realistic browns and grays of more recent games. The music is a bit generic, but it’s suitable for a superhero game. There are lots of highs and thumping bass tracks to drive the combat forward. It can certainly get repetitive, but that’s what the volume slider in the options menu is for. Overall, it doesn’t detract from the experience any and fits in well enough that some may not really notice it. On to the meat of things; the gameplay! I’m pleased to say that the gameplay of Marvel Puzzle Quest is, well, fantastic to be perfectly honest with you. It is a very well implemented use of the Puzzle Quest formula with enough difference and excitement to stand well on its own feet. Each color is representative of one member of your team, and has an icon to indicate which member that is. Wolverine, for example, is represented by scratch marks across the gems, while Storm has lightning bolts. Each icon makes sense and stands out well, making it easy to determine who will be attacking. Collecting gems allows you to use character powers, which can drastically change the way a fight is going. More powerful abilities take more preparation time and cause severe damage, while less powerful abilities can be used more often but do less damage or have fewer utility effects attached. There is a story mode separated into four separate mission groups, which will last you a good number of hours to complete. There are also daily and weekly missions and a PVP mode to keep you playing as long as your interest remains. Each of these modes offers its own rewards and characters, and as a result each also adds a huge amount of content to the game.  As for the dreaded free-to-play purchased content that inevitably unbalances these games? Well…it is present, but it’s not nearly as bad as other games often are. You can purchase the two currencies present in the game in bulk quantities, and use those currencies to recruit more and rarer characters or power up your existing heroes. It does unbalance the multiplayer somewhat if you let it, but it’s not so bad that it ruins the game entirely in that department. In order to counter the unbalancing, you just have to search a bit harder for an opponent on the same level as you. It can definitely be a pain in the backside from time to time but it isn’t something that ruins the overall experience and shouldn’t keep you from giving the game a shot.Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign has far more content and playability than a free game should ever reasonably be expected to contain. If you let it, this game will suck you in and keep you playing into the wee hours of the morning without even realizing it. There are far worse ways you could be spending your free time. Don’t let the price tag fool you; this is one game that doesn’t skimp on the content just because it’s free of charge. Give it a shot and you might be pleasantly surprised.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												This is a fun, free-to-play take on the Puzzle Quest paradigm set in the Marvel universe with most of its most popular characters.  It is designed for bite-size chunks, and offers a lot of progression both in building up individual characters and in building up your roster giving you new options and new combinations to try out.There is a lot of noise and anger within the community here on Steam involving a recent change to healing characters that now keeps people from endlessly grinding out events.  I am adding this review primarily to wholeheartedly disagree with their viewpoint.  Before the healing change, I was about ready to give up on the game.  I have played for a while, and my roster was filled out and developed pretty nicely for a mostly-free player (I have spent some real money to expand my roster size faster, but never to get new characters or develop them -- the characters and XP equivalent come pretty quickly as you play so I never felt the need to spend money to accelerate that).  Unfortunately, I could never devote 8 or more hours a day to an event, so I never had a chance to win.  Players would grind out an event with their #1 best team of 3 characters until their health was low, then grind out a PvE level to heal those characters back to max, and then go back to grinding out the event again.  The enemy teams were almost always the three same characters, the winners' total scores were ridiculously high, and I was about done with the game.Enter the healing change -- any healing during a battle is now temporary to that battle (with a couple of exceptions that can only heal a character back to about 50% of his health).  Now, event winners must play with various combinations of characters and be better at the game (take less damage) than others, rather than simply spend more time than others on the game.  In my mind, this is a significant improvement to the game's health and will make things work much better in the long run.A final word about a game being 'pay2win' -- For most people, when you think of pay2win games, this references some item that gives a player an advantage that can only be bought with real money, not earned by playing the game.  This game includes NOTHING that fits that category.  There is absolutely nothing in the game that you cannot earn directly by playing the game.  The only reason I spent money on it at all was to support the developers for my time spent and because as a collector I wanted to hold on to all the characters I earned in game (they put a 7-day limit on adding a character to your roster to push for money to be spent there, but even the couple of times I lost a character by not adding them during this limit I have always gotten that character again down the road).  In any event, I only play at most about 10 characters, and I have been placing near the top more and more since this healing change occurred.  For reference, you can get 10 character slots with the free real-money currency you earn within the first month or so of playing.tl;dr -- This is a fun, well designed game, and the developers are thinking about the long-term health of the game with their decisions.  As in many free-to-play games, you must spend either money or time to advance and succeed, but both are viable options.  Additionally, you will need to play well and be smart with both your match-3 tactics and your roster decision strategies to have the best chance to succeed in the game and its events.  Thanks to the recent controversial change that many others complain about, you no longer need to devote 8+ hours a day during an event to have a chance to succeed.

When earlier it could be both casual and competitive at the same time, now its gone worse than pay2win, it made a severe turn for pay2play. Character's skills can also be boosted! only 3-20$ for each cover which you need 15 in order to make one of your characters most useful, not mentioning the huge money drop (a ridicilous amount needed) for boosting it's levels.TL;DR Once a fun and an exciting game 5/5 went to greedy as ♥♥♥♥ microtransactions simply for playing the game, dont even consider supporting the developers. content:
er 16, 2013
												I really enjoy waiting for an hour between rounds while my characters heal... It's bearable at the start when it takes a couple minutes and you can play a few rounds, but it gets steadily worse. The difficulty curve is sharp after the introduction missions, that factor combined with the RNG bejeweled style board means that you'll be watching your heal timer a lot after a failed mission. The demand for cash from D3 publisher is inescapable if you actually want to play the game at any level of efficiency you might need to throw cash at this game. The game gets a plus for having fun game play mixed with Marvel characters, but there are just too many drawbacks to make this game worth recommending. There is a loose RPG system in which you level up characters by collecting comic books, but it's marred by the fact that it too is RNG based (unless you use money).  Some iconic characters are given to you at the start of the game, but everything you get afterwards is all random and the majority of heroes I've received thus far are terrible or useless. You need to continually advance in the game if you desire better rewards, but any impression of success is stymied when you get your seventh 'Hawk-Eye' in a row or some equally as rage worthy hero thanks to the RNG rewards. This game would be much better if there was a way to slowly work towards a hero comic that compliments your roster, one that you can chose and grind towards. Success would feel much better and the grind would be worth the effort if you could finally piece together your Marvel Dream Team and smite some foes with righteous fury. Instead you're forced to use valuable experience, recruitment tokens, and gold to expand your roster never knowing who you're going to get. I've got a 5/5/- black widow and I just keep getting her comic books, it's driving me insane...The gameplay is a bit stiff in comparison to previous iterations of the PQ franchise and some attack animations are slow and repetitive. The graphics aren't anything to write home about and everything just feels slow. This game is a step backwards in almost every area and far too frustrating to be worth time or money. Just get Puzzle Quest 2 and enjoy that game, this debacle doesn't do the franchise justice and is a blemish on an otherwise amazing series of games.

content:
4, 2014
												As far as casual games go, this one is pretty epic in it's time-consuming...ness. I enjoy it quite a bit, but I've always been a fan of puzzle games, not excluding the 'match 3' genre. This one isn't as in-depth as say... Puzzle Quest 2 which is made by a totally different company, but I think there's still enough there if you want something more than Bejewelled. I think the best part is figuring out which heroes/villains work the best together and trying to build up their combos and such. As far as downsides go, I really don't like the weak AI, the randomness of drops and the money for power aspect. I'll go into each point by point here. The only real challenge comes from the level of your opponent, which determines how much HP they have and damage they do. When it comes to the actual gameplay, you can easily predict what they're going to do as they have certain priorities. They definitely play worse than a thinking person would. I would like it more if they made better decisions, as frustrating as that could be.As far as getting loot goes, you have very little control over what you get. Essentially you do different missions, most of which have four rewards. The first time you beat a mission, you're guaranteed one of them. Typically, you'll get ISO (the game's main currency) Hero Coins (the game's premium currency), heroes or random hero tokens, or boosts. Each time you repeat the mission, you'll have a chance to get a reward that you haven't already received or 20 ISO (which is a tiny tiny amount) This does get frustrating after a while, especially if you're trying to get a specific reward. Now, in order to get more characters, you need to either complete certain missions, trade in recruit tokens of varying quality or progress/place well enough in events (there's usually something going on every day). The problem here is with the tokens. Some guarantee a certain quality of hero, but it's still random since if there's a character you want, there's next to no guarantee you'll get them. They break down the odds on their website, but it doesn't really help. But that's not the worst thing.The worst thing is of course the bane of most free-to-play games. Paying for power. You can buy two things: ISO and Hero coins, the two currencies of the game. ISO is used to level up your characters and buy more low-quality ones. Coins allow you to buy more recruit tokens of higher quality, level up hero powers, (which aside from their actual effects, allow you to raise the character level higher) protect your characters in PvP mode (>:| ) but most importantly, buy more slots for characters. That last one is really frustrating, because you can only increase your character slots with coins, and if you don't want to spend money, you're going to have to inevitably pass up on recruiting certain characters, or get rid of ones you've progressed on in order to get new ones simply because if you don't buy coins, it's a hell of a grind to get more. The worst of the worst is that the coins/ISO are really expensive for your dollar, and I think don't really give you proper value. If you want to make this one of the only games you play it might be acceptable, but if you want to just play casually, I highly recommend not spending the money on it.Myself, I've put in a fair amount of time, so I begrudgingly purchased some coins to help open up some space for more characters on both my steam account and my iPad. ~sigh~Anyways, if you can overlook all the shortcomings, it's still a fun puzzle game, and you CAN get by without dropping any of your hard-earned cash on it. I recommend giving it a try if you're into the genre at all, especially considering it IS free.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												8/30/14 - Changed review to positive, though I imagine it still would be much more of a burden for people starting out to have to deal w/ massive downtimes when they don't have the roster to pick and choose, and remain competitive, when they run out of lives and have to wait, I still enjoy the game quite a bit.  I don't like the new healing mechanic that limits your healing to in-battle only regeneration, but, it's not as much of a game breaker as I had expected.  But again, that might be due to the depth of my roster and having multiple options to choose from in order to play-on while out of lives/regens.  Give it a whirl though, it is addictive.As you can see I have been intensely addicted to this game for months now.  And the game WAS fantastic.  However, in what I still cannot comprehend, the dev's at D3 have decided that they no longer want people to become addicted to their game.  They no longer want us telling our friends how fun it is, how they should give it a go and become MPQ addicts like we are.  No... now they have taken any sense of allowing their players the freedom to play when they want, how they want, w/ whatever characters they CHOOSE to play and have thrown it all in the garbage.  I am an AVID supporter of games and developers who show that they care for, listen to, and support the player community which gives them a job, a fan base, and a slew of addicts who advertise this game as a wonderful time-sink to all their friends/family/co-workers for free.  But apparently, FREE advertising doesn't figure into their bottom line and they would rather lose 1000's of loyal players if it means that 1-2 people w/ the fortune and freedom to invest money at will into buying extra lives every time the RNG unluckily kills off all their characters.  Loyal players who will NEVER pay for, what would be, an endless need for health-packs to keep playing at the times these players have allotted themselves to play... are GONE.  The only competition new players, or even players looking to experiment and try different character/team set-ups, will face are going to be these whales that invest so much money into the game that they are UNBEATABLE.  NO NEW PLAYER WILL STAND A CHANCE when the only competition left are those with pockets deep enough to make it utterly unfair.I will continue to log on 1x -2x a day, in hopes that the dev's will realize, acknowledge, and correct this unfathomably inept decision to cut the legs out from any player who is new, growing, learning, or trying to figure out if the game is WORTH spending real money on.  It makes 0 sense.  NONE.  AT ALL.  If this isn't fixed in a week, I will uninstall this game and move on w/ my life.  And, if you check the hours I have put into playing, I thoroughly understand the mechanics behind the game as well as the MASSIVE hindrance this change would put into my own ability to play.  And I'm not someone w/ a poor roster just wanting to get a feel for it and decide if it's worth my time and money.By refusing to let players develop their own style, experiment w/ different characters w/o the feeling that, if they lose, they'll have to wait 2-6 hours before they can play again, this product is going to plunge into the depths of being another 'free-to-play' game which is in NO WAY competitive, fair, enjoyable, or worth our time and money.  People who love this game and play it daily are already dropping out, along w/ their free advertising... New players will be faced w/ unbeatable teams funded by players w/ pockets deep enough to not care, and this MASSIVELY UNAPPEALING wall of dead-time where they can do NOTHING but sit and wait for the game to slowly heal them over a 2-6 hour period.  IT IS PURELY BAFFLING TO NOT BE ABLE TO COMPREHEND HOW AWFUL THIS WILL BE TO ANYONE WHO WANTS TO FALL IN LOVE WITH A GAME.  How do you hope to attract, entertain, and KEEP players playing when you DON'T let them play for hours on end?  NO ONE is going to pay money, to a game, that they have 0 chance of being able to jump in, experiment, and get their feet wet in competition that is so far skewed towards players who buy the best characters and level them up w/o any work cause they can afford it.  Those players, like myself, who have put in HOURS AND HOURS of time learning the game, developing strategies to be able to out-last, out play, and still remain highly competitive with those players who cheat their way up using cash are going to be GONE.  I sincerely hoped this is fixed in the next 7 days, or I will feel so dumb for having invested so much time and energy into a game which doesn't consider 90% of their fan-base when making decisions about how to move their product forward.Sincerely, A once loyal and dedicated, and HOPEFULLY FUTURE loyal and dedicated, fan and player.

												Since I like Marvel stuff and I enjoyed Puzzle Quest, I thought this would be a no-brainer and tried to stick it out. Unfortunately, the microtransactions just ruin it. You cannot just play or collect in a way that's very enjoyable - people comment about it being "free to play, pay to win" and this is very true. Probably my chief complaint in this regard is that rather than paying for rewards, you can 'achieve' rewards through your gameplay (which is fine)... unless you don't have room, in which case you need to pay for the rewards you've achieved through gameplay anyway.Could have been great, but very quickly loses its appeal even for fans of both franchises (unless you have money to burn). For those of you that are looking for something to play in short bursts while commuting every day rather than playing for conentrated periods of time, you may have a different experience.

content:
, 2015
												WARNING THIS GAME IS ADDICTIVE! I have spent well over 600 hours in this game so far. It almost consumes my game playing life now. I have gotten friends into the game and they love it as well. We talk about what characters we have, which ones we wish we had, and strategies for fights.  This game is free to play but you can pay for a few things. I DO NOT recommend paying for ISO-8, it can be easily farmed from "The battle of the Baxter building". This is what I do for ISO when I am not getting it through normal fights. I do quite well with this method and can get 2,000 to 3,000 ISO in an hour this way.  If you play a lot you might want to consider spending a little money on Hero Points to get more roster slots. I have spent $40 on this game and I feel that is a fair amount for how much time I have spent and how much enjoyment I get out of the game. However it's not necessary to spend money at all as you will win HP fairly often and you can always switch out who you have in your roster if you get a character you like better. It's just personal preference. I have friends who have spent money and friends who have not and our enjoyment of the game is the same. Overall if you like games like bejewled you will like this game. The RPG element adds a little variety and strategy to the game which I enjoy very much.

5, 2014
												Game has become a negative posterchild for pay to win. Before people who didn't spent any or just some money for slots etc. had a fighting chance. And even more importantly, they had some time to enjoy the game. Now they nerfed healing, so most Characters with healing skills get their healing only temporarily. Before, you could play 1-2 hours w/o a problem w/o having to use so called health packs.Now, w/o proper healing, after you used your 5 free healthpacks per day, which can easily happen after 2-3 games, as EACH hero (you can use 3 heroes at a time) needs to get healed with one pack. So after 3 games (maybe 10 minutes) you can easily run out of health packs and that was it for the day as it takes hours for the healthpacks to replenish. Most people won't have the time play for 10-20 minutes every 5 or so hours, because they work and basically have a life.If you wanted, like I did before, enjoy an hour or the occasional 2 hours on the couch, playing Dark Reign, you are now out of luck. After 30 minutes tops you run out of health packs and heroes to play. And guess how you only (reliably) get them back? Right, by purchasing them with real money. You can't even use the "normal" in-game currency.To level one hero to 50ish (of over 200 levels) costs about 90 € (NINETY), if you do this with currency from the real-money in-game shop.The most infuriating part is, that the devs think us stupid and lie to people, claiming the new system would save them time, because playing a 5 Minute game every few games to heal your heroes to full is much longer than waiting 5+ hours .TL;DR, it's a predatory business model aimed at addicted players who need to continue playing after they ran out of health packs. Keep away till they change that factor. If they do, the game can be fun.

												I love the Puzzle Quest games. So naturally I also loved this new entry based on the Marvel comics. And in a way I do. But it just feels so cheap, and all because it's free. The character designs are well done and if you've played one of the previous PQ games you most definitely know how they play and this one is no different. It's once again all about matching gems. Which is fun obviously.But unlocking new characters, powers and upgrades take a lot of time and you'll be replaying a lot of battles to earn these rewards... or you can use real life currency to save time, which is ridiculous if you ask me. I'm aware of the fact that I own a lot of games and they've cost me tons of money but one thing I will rarely do (never say never) is pay for in-game content. And yes, DLC is a whole different story. But less of a scam because some of it can be truly impressive. But I'm losing focus here.The text in the text bubbles is gigantic which annoyed me. Replaying the levels many times over to get the proper rewards annoyed me. The fact that you can skip through these steps as long as you are willing to spend money on it annoyed me. And it's such a shame, because it can really be a fun game once you're playing a battle.It's free so it's hard to not recommend this game, right ? But I just can't. I can't. Buy PQ2 instead and witness a truly magnificent game. You won't be disappointed.[Rating: 76/100]

content:
er 29, 2013
												I went into this game knowing very well, that "free to play" usually means "pay to win". Still this game made me angry! Why?First off: The base game is great! It's the standard puzzle quest game play. Basically a two player Bejewelled, where each player has life points and each match-3 (or more) is an attack which  reduces the opponents life points. In this game you play a team of 3 classic Marvel heroes and villains, from the starter Iron Man to Spider Man to Doctor Doom. Each has up to three special abilities, which are quite varied. The abilities are fueled with the tiles you matched up.So far, pretty classic puzzle quest. And overall that's done pretty well and is fun to play.What's no fun is everything around it: You get heroes and abilities by gathering "covers". You sometimes get them during the single player campaign or during the so called "player vs player" events. It's pseudo PvP really, since the oponent is controlled by the AI, there is no way to customize your team and there is no in-game way of communication except via Steam itself. And even then, there is no way to challenge a specific player.Since it's "free to play" you can also get covers by spending one of the two in-game currencies, which can be bought in the shop or found by playing: Iso-8 crystals and hero points. The former can be used to level up your heroes or buy the cheapest ones. The latter one can be used to buy the better ones or buy an additional slot for a hero. The heroes are distributed into four categories, 1-star to 4-star, and usually you can get multiple versions of the same character in the different categories. The better the category, the more powerful they can become.To learn a new ability or to make one more powerful, you need to find the cover of the exact hero with that exact ability on it. And did I mention, that you can't choose specific heroes in the shop? Instead you buy them as a kind of booster pack of one. Or you buy them as a booster of 10 and are guaranteed one specific hero. However those are usually even more expensive than the single boosters.And that's basically the problem of the whole game: You have no control what you get, and that little you get is very, very expensive. And don't get me started if you actually plan to spend money on this game: You can actually get the 2 weakest character covers for 50 hero points each. The "cheapest" amount to buy is 200 hero points for 1,49€, so about 0,40€ per cover. You need about 10 to fully power one of them up. This is 4,00€ for a full power character. And that's the weakest ones! It only get's more expensive from here! Sure, you can get a whole lot of hero points for about 70€. But I would never spend so much money on a match-3 game. Especially since you can get the original Puzzle Quests for at most 20€ here on Steam. And even if you spens so much, it only gives a discount of about 50%!  What makes me angry, is that the developers are greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and very obvious about it. Play, if you don't want to spend money, but if you do want to spend: spend it for the originals!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest (MPQ), is a mobile device port for steam. Is that necessarily a bad thing? I don't think so, but it is something that you need to keep in mind when looking at the UI and graphics. It also effects the pay system, and since this is a F2P game, that's something people tend to focus on. So let's start there:Can you play MPQ without spending money? Yes. Will you be competitive... well, mostly. Let's talk about what real money gets used for: You can purchase the two types of in-game currency with real money. ISO and Gold. ISO is used, mainly, to purchase boosts for use during combat and to spend to level up your characters. It is the common currency of the game and is earned pretty easily. Gold can be used for a number of things. You can purchase additional slots to hold more characters (you are limited to 4 characters at the start and the prices for additional slots increases the more you have), you can purchase some "super-boosts", you can purchase health packs, and you can purchase additional covers for your characters. Do you "have" to purchase these things? Nope. You do earn some gold through normal game play, and many people (myself included) have found that if you focuse your purchases you don't really hit a wall for a very long time.Let's move onto the gameplay itself. MPQ is a tile matching game that is themed around the Marvel Comic Universe. You swap tiles on a grid board to make 3 or longer chains of the same color/shape (think Bejewelled), you then score a hit dealing damage and (in most cases) generated Ability Points (AP) of that color. Each character that you have selected (three) will have different abilities both passive and active. These abilities are often fuelled by the AP you generate from your matches. Pretty simple. There is an entertaining amount of depth in selecting which team you want to bring to an event, and finding good synergy between character abilities is important.The characters are leveled up by unlocking their skills. Skills are found by getting random drop "Covers". Each cover has one skill associated with it. Once you have used that cover to train the character in that skill it will increase the "Current Max Level" of the character, you can then use ISO to increase the level of the character. Every level increase raises the max Hit Points of the character, the amount of damage they do and the effectivness of their skills. Once you have unlocked the first level of the skill you can use Gold to increase the skill level (this is the main form of Pay-to-Win that you see in the game, but is limited by the fact that you have to have the base skill first to buy it).Health of your characters is the delaying factor in playing. Not only are you doing damage to your enemies, but they are doing damage to your characters as well. Their health will increase back to max over time, but with high level characters this can take several hours. If you take your three best characters into a match that is over their head and get them all killed, this can mean that you don't get to play again for a few hours... unless you use Health Packs. Health packs allow a character to return to full health immediately. You earn health packs over time, one every 30 minutes, but could buy additionals for Gold.The game provides some basic "PVE" missions to get a feel for the game and earn some basic covers and boosts, but the main part of the game that allows you to progress is the "PVP" duels and "PVE" events. Events rotate every few days and give opportunities for rare and high end rewards, but competition can be tough and some events require having certain characters to participate. Duels are a staple way to put your team against another player. The duels aren't really PVP though, because the same AI that runs the normal missions just uses the team, not an actual player.Long and the short of it: I find MPQ to be very entertaining, something that I have spent many an hour with and am perfectly happy to keep playing. There are issues, some bugs that break events and some exploits that people have found that can let them rank up super fast, and there are concerns about Pay-To-Win, but overall I can say that if you are looking for a casual time waster, this does the job rather well.
