content:
12, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest (in general, mobile and Steam) is nothing more than a petty rich get richer pyramid scheme. People who played from day one got to cruise to a cushy position for free and they are inoculated to the countless nerfs and adjustments that hurt new to mid range players in a petty attempt to force them to pay money for what others got for free just months before. Some fall into the trap and pay while others just tell everyone they know at how (supposedly) great the game is to flood the leaderboards with noobs so that they will be elevated into the top 10% more easily. Everything about the game is catered towards paying to overcome those who had it easier than you because they started at a higher tier in the pyramid scheme.The steam version has several advantages over the mobile version, but with a single colossal flaw. By virtue of having more space the in game interface is vastly superior to the hyper-compact view on mobile. The perpetual link to the server forces the battery to drain 8-12X regular drain rate on mobile, which is not a problem on Steam given that we have that constant connection anyway and we are generally plugged in to a power source that will charge faster than it will drain. The problem is that Facebook cannot be synced, so you cannot carry over your mobile save data to your Steam version. This mortal sin is making me uninstall. 0 out of 100

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 1, 2014
												On the surface, it looks like a fairly decent Puzzle Quest/Match 3 style game. But when you dig deeper you find that the game is designed to squeeze you for money every chance it gets. Your heroes' levels are capped by comic covers. The covers are mostly random, or hard to obtain. Plus, despite there being several different covers available, your slots to place them in are extremely limited. The Single-Player game will thus become overywhemling quickly, and stop providing you with any resources, forcing you into the special quests (which likewise dry up fast) or pvp. Those have exploitable methods to try to get more resources, but it becomes a frustrating game of retrying until you get a suitable opponent and then attacking. Not a lot of balance, difficult to advance, very hard on the wallet for a "freemium" game, just add up to a product that's best left avoided.This review is a repost of one I had made several months before, which appears to have been deleted in that when I visit the store page, it asks me to submit a review.  Though my old review was still listed in my profile.  Since the time of writing this, the developers implimented a change to the way healing was done in-game.  In order to play, you nead heroes who are healthy.  You can get health packs in game, that regenerate in time, or you can pay for them with the paid currency.  This is a tactic used in many Facebook games.  Simply put, it's a way to force you to constantly pay to keep playing.  And if you want to be "competetive", you must keep playing.  Limited time events, both PvE and PvP, require a lot of attention.  That you can't give them if you can't play.  Thus you can't earn the rewards from them.  And thus you fall further and further behind.  The change was that some characters had healing abilities in the game.  This effect let you continue to play, grind for what you needed in story mode etc.  The developers made the change that this in-game healing is temporary.  Once the battle was over, all the damage you received would be reapplied, sometimes killing your character.  Which meant, if you wanted to that character again, you needed to use a health pack.  Otherwise, you would rapidly run out of playable characters.To not believe the "free to play" tag on this game.  This game features the worst in the "freemium" market practices.  There are far, far better options out there, in both the "match 3" gameplay style, and in the Marvel theme.

content:
5, 2014
												Game has become a negative posterchild for pay to win. Before people who didn't spent any or just some money for slots etc. had a fighting chance. And even more importantly, they had some time to enjoy the game. Now they nerfed healing, so most Characters with healing skills get their healing only temporarily. Before, you could play 1-2 hours w/o a problem w/o having to use so called health packs.Now, w/o proper healing, after you used your 5 free healthpacks per day, which can easily happen after 2-3 games, as EACH hero (you can use 3 heroes at a time) needs to get healed with one pack. So after 3 games (maybe 10 minutes) you can easily run out of health packs and that was it for the day as it takes hours for the healthpacks to replenish. Most people won't have the time play for 10-20 minutes every 5 or so hours, because they work and basically have a life.If you wanted, like I did before, enjoy an hour or the occasional 2 hours on the couch, playing Dark Reign, you are now out of luck. After 30 minutes tops you run out of health packs and heroes to play. And guess how you only (reliably) get them back? Right, by purchasing them with real money. You can't even use the "normal" in-game currency.To level one hero to 50ish (of over 200 levels) costs about 90 € (NINETY), if you do this with currency from the real-money in-game shop.The most infuriating part is, that the devs think us stupid and lie to people, claiming the new system would save them time, because playing a 5 Minute game every few games to heal your heroes to full is much longer than waiting 5+ hours .TL;DR, it's a predatory business model aimed at addicted players who need to continue playing after they ran out of health packs. Keep away till they change that factor. If they do, the game can be fun.

content:
er 26, 2013
												I love the Puzzle Quest games. So naturally I also loved this new entry based on the Marvel comics. And in a way I do. But it just feels so cheap, and all because it's free. The character designs are well done and if you've played one of the previous PQ games you most definitely know how they play and this one is no different. It's once again all about matching gems. Which is fun obviously.But unlocking new characters, powers and upgrades take a lot of time and you'll be replaying a lot of battles to earn these rewards... or you can use real life currency to save time, which is ridiculous if you ask me. I'm aware of the fact that I own a lot of games and they've cost me tons of money but one thing I will rarely do (never say never) is pay for in-game content. And yes, DLC is a whole different story. But less of a scam because some of it can be truly impressive. But I'm losing focus here.The text in the text bubbles is gigantic which annoyed me. Replaying the levels many times over to get the proper rewards annoyed me. The fact that you can skip through these steps as long as you are willing to spend money on it annoyed me. And it's such a shame, because it can really be a fun game once you're playing a battle.It's free so it's hard to not recommend this game, right ? But I just can't. I can't. Buy PQ2 instead and witness a truly magnificent game. You won't be disappointed.[Rating: 76/100]

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 1, 2014
												On the surface, it looks like a fairly decent Puzzle Quest/Match 3 style game. But when you dig deeper you find that the game is designed to squeeze you for money every chance it gets. Your heroes' levels are capped by comic covers. The covers are mostly random, or hard to obtain. Plus, despite there being several different covers available, your slots to place them in are extremely limited. The Single-Player game will thus become overywhemling quickly, and stop providing you with any resources, forcing you into the special quests (which likewise dry up fast) or pvp. Those have exploitable methods to try to get more resources, but it becomes a frustrating game of retrying until you get a suitable opponent and then attacking. Not a lot of balance, difficult to advance, very hard on the wallet for a "freemium" game, just add up to a product that's best left avoided.This review is a repost of one I had made several months before, which appears to have been deleted in that when I visit the store page, it asks me to submit a review.  Though my old review was still listed in my profile.  Since the time of writing this, the developers implimented a change to the way healing was done in-game.  In order to play, you nead heroes who are healthy.  You can get health packs in game, that regenerate in time, or you can pay for them with the paid currency.  This is a tactic used in many Facebook games.  Simply put, it's a way to force you to constantly pay to keep playing.  And if you want to be "competetive", you must keep playing.  Limited time events, both PvE and PvP, require a lot of attention.  That you can't give them if you can't play.  Thus you can't earn the rewards from them.  And thus you fall further and further behind.  The change was that some characters had healing abilities in the game.  This effect let you continue to play, grind for what you needed in story mode etc.  The developers made the change that this in-game healing is temporary.  Once the battle was over, all the damage you received would be reapplied, sometimes killing your character.  Which meant, if you wanted to that character again, you needed to use a health pack.  Otherwise, you would rapidly run out of playable characters.To not believe the "free to play" tag on this game.  This game features the worst in the "freemium" market practices.  There are far, far better options out there, in both the "match 3" gameplay style, and in the Marvel theme.

content:
er 11, 2013
												The gameplay is so much fun - a great time killer. The same old Bejeweled/PQ basic mechanic of 'matching 3 gems or more' is there, a huge appeal for its fanbase. Also, with the quests system, there's a sense of progression unlike the old Bejeweled. You actually need to check your opponents level prior to accepting the quest, rearrange your roster, heal your heroes or arming the power ups to make things easier. In addition to great quests, we also have very decent graphic and badass OSTs. Granted that it's not AAA's 3D levels, but the detailed chars and charming designs are more than enough. The actual Heads Up Display is clear and concise, allowing players to reach the menu they want to use. There's also a simple descriptions to each of heroes' powers so you can understand what you're going to invoke before deciding (since the point placement is permanent and not respecable).The video options are barebones, but really there's no need Anti Aliasing and those fancy Physx Tesselation whatever it's called options. You can use your native resolutions - at least that's commonly used nowadays - to prevent screen tearing. Well, in my case, it autodetected everything so it's click and play.Game performance overall is silky smooth even on my mid-end rig. Transitions between scenes are quite short, no boring loading screen that takes ages to finish and so far zero crash.Now after all good stuffs, here comes the problem, microtransactions. In order to upgrade your heroes within reasonable timeframe, you need to either be lucky with rewards rolls, or grind the best rewarding quess repeatedly, or purchasing DLCs. That's where the major problem is. All would have been a little better if the quest rewards can make up for it so free players don't have to bang against the wall out of frustration.Multiplayer is missing, but I'd imagine it'd be great to have a match up against other people real time matching gems together.Great Free to Play game ridden by micro transactions. It's a real shame, the game has a chance to be other FTP killers on Steam, but severely missed it. In the end though, I'd play until I am tired with the brick wall that prevents me from advancing, or bored.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												I used to love this game, as it should be obvious from how many hours I have sunk into this thing, but the game has made a definite turn for the worst.  It is in the Puzzle Quest style of gameplay with a few tweaks that take some getting used to (team formation, different type of leveling, matching more gems for the free turn, new timers on gems that you want to eliminate/protect with timers, etc).  I would think that if you were a fan of the first couple of Puzzle Quest games then you might enjoy this game as it scratches that same itch.  Most of the adjustments to the gameplay are interesting takes on the old formula, which I think are pleasant.However, recently the publisher has made the game more of a chore to play than anything.  They are employing several different tactics to try to squeeze more money out of the players, to the point where it has become a hindrance to my enjoyment of the game.  By aggressively trying to find ways to get money by adding new 'features' that limit the playerbase unless you are willing to pay more (and more and more) they have completely destroyed my enjoyment of this game.  I used to recommend this game to my friends, however I can no longer do that and have stopped playing the game myself.

content:
ry 18
												In a nutshell, its a bad match 3 game as far as the match 3 is concerend, theres just too many varients of the gems and there arnt enough rows or columns...most of the time there is just one move you can make, rarely you can set up a good move with a cascade...the game is about 90% based on your characters, their skills, and building the resources via matching colors.Youll immediately get stung by the old school "whale RMT" mechanics that goes after wallet warriors to compete.  Your instinct will be to drop a small amount of money, which youll spend on the wrong stuff (hero tokens) which will cause you to need to buy more slots (the ONLY thing you should be buying).  Youll get a high level hero, think youve won, then realize it ruins your scaling.You need a LOT of hero slots, and those slots are expensive, the rest of the RMT is 100% RNG.  Rather than making an item you can buy to upgrade your heroes, which are seperated by tier, same skills though just higher level cap, they make the hero RNG the same as the skill upgrades.  So youll need many rare hero covers to upgrade that higher level hero and actually have skills, which are more important than good match 3 luck/skill.That one star or two star hero with all its skills unlocked and upgrade potential is far better than the uber rare hero you just unlocked basically...this isnt told to you early on...and its why most of the complaints are about the cash shop..they set you up to fail in this manner, which means...pull that wallet out...you get very little for your money as well (dont even get me started on ISO the material needed to level up, which you can only do after upgrading a skill via rolling another hero cover of the same tier which may or may not be the specific skill you need or want to upgrade)...you can see how it gets fustrating.Not paying money your able to clear the tutorial pve, then youll be stuck doing one daily and not much else to do for a decent amount of time.The game floods you with low tier covers, that eventually you sell off...and are sort of worthless beyond early game.Alliances are either 100% dead or overly competative with high expectations on participation, youll only be able to join with an expensive roster of high teir heroes upgraded fully...which takes ages for free or costs a hell of a lot of money.I drew the line at $20, opened a ton of slots, got a few "decent" heroes ill probably never find an upgrade for...but come in handy for pve events where characters are powered up (if you have that specific hero) if you dont its more or less a diceroll if youll get stomped and need to log out for an hour or two, or win and have taken so much damage youll need to log out for an hour or two...damage carries over and heals slowly over time or use a heal pack which drop from pve sometimes or pay up.Im stuck in a between spot on progression, much like if you dont pay early on...i log in to see if the events are for any heroes i have, if so i play them, if not i realize theres very little i can get done in a day.  WHen you realize most rewards are a token amount of ISO (like 250-500 when you need 30k to level a hero) it gets tedious... When you keep getting the same cover for the same hero who has that same skill already maxed, rather than ANYTHING else..it gets old...far too much RNG here...seperate hero characters from skills and just put in a skill upgrade token so we can make use of all our heroes....it makes rare heros almost worthless since youll never be able to upgrade them.Just do yourself a favor, dont bother with the game, if you need to....dont pay...see that progression wall? $20 will get you maybe 10 more hours of play until you hit it again, your rewards wont increase much because of it, and dont even think about competing....for a pve event i was ranked #1 for about 8hours (got lucky and i had all essential heros who were boosted) with 20min left on the event i was pretty far ahead, out of content to do for rewards and points donwscale with repetition...i was done but sure i was going to win some decent rewards (well maybe 500 more ISO than had i just participated and not competed and a chance at a rare hero)  i ended up ranking 38th in that 20min...not that i noticed much via reward...but it was like why did i even bother? 500 iso and a standard token for a low tier hero (one star storm or juggernaught it seems is the 99% on their RNG not worth the iso to upgrade for me)If you can play a few hours every day, and play EVERY day, eventually youll build up a decent roster, with some luck at least...and were talking over months...otherwise pay up big...and even then its a pretty boring game.Oh and the pvp isnt pvp...your playing an AI during it...Also the match 3 mixed with their skill system is extremely fustrating, many skills wont work unless they sit on the board for a few turns, and it seems the AI is really...REALLY...lucky on cascades and skills that randomly destroy tiles that always include your big skill that was going to go off next turn...however when the AI does similair it will be on a tile you cannot possibly touch...you you need to choose a character that can accurately destroy rows (hawkeye) which is kinda lame.If you plan to play 30 min to an hour a day, dont mind long slow progression, and will play for many months...youll get some fun out of it if youve never played a proper match 3 game...otherwise...get a real match 3 game...ironcast is far more entertianing and way less over the long run.Oh and i want to be very clear on their terrible scaling system.  Basically if you open a token and get a high tier character, the game assumes you have all high skill characters, fully upgraded, even if its just one and you have just one upgraded skill.  The game is VERY dependant on skills to progress you cannot compete on just match 3 damage alone.  Having one lv70 character means your lower tier heros fully upgraded at lv50 wont be able to hang in the events, which is how you progress and earn more tokens and coin rewards for more slots.  Your option is to delete the rare hero or struggle to do anything.  You have to horde tokens for months before you should actually open them, something not explained to new players and the most common cause of game fustration.  Typically you only find this out after spending money, or getting lucky on a reward token....youll realize this when you cant progress in an event for coin and tokens because the enemy level is too high for all but one character...and that one character cant carry without a full skill slot as youll be doing match 3 damage for most of the match.  If you play for free or dont want to spend hundreds of dollars...dont open anything other than a standard low tier token and make sure you have like 20-30 slots which will takes many months of free play or about $100....and why have that many slots if you dont have characters to fill them.  The sheer number of heroes means youll be at RNG's mercy to get duplicates, and not just duplicates of rare heroes but ones with the right skills so you can win matches....its insane....

In addition to great quests, we also have very decent graphic and badass OSTs. Granted that it's not AAA's 3D levels, but the detailed chars and charming designs are more than enough. 												Great game overall, the best one in Puzzle Quest series. If you ever had any interest in Puzzle Quest then look no further.Characters are closely represented with their respective unique powers, and new heroes are added regularly.Events and storyline are just perfect for newcomers and casual players, but players who spend more than a couple of hours a day may find it thin and repeating. With the addition of health system, the server load should be guaranteed and the ranking ladders will not be owned by marathon players.It is truly a free to play game where you have no obligation to spend anything. As for winning, it's down to how much time spent against other players - just like every MMO games out there. Money can only help making the characters stronger, not the time needed to complete the matches.

content:
y 15, 2015
												I enjoy match-3 games, and this comes with all of the benefits and drawbacks that come with competitive versions. (Matches aren't timed, but opponents take alternating turns against you, with possibilities for long strings of watching the computer play when it gets a lucky combo.) The game makes full use of 4- and 5-matches, giving each a different bonus, and recognizing T-shaped and L-shaped 5-matches. (Games that don't do this drive me crazy.)As a free-to-play game, I like that everything in-game is still accessible without purchase. Progression is a bit slower, of course, but it is possible to win "hero points" (in-game gold) and expand the slots available for heroes.The unique elements of this game are two-fold:1) A collectable card-game like element of choosing which heroes to keep and level up, and which combinations to use in each battle.2) A chance for gamers not already steeped in superhero lore to get to know Marvel characters and interactions a bit better. It's quickly turning me into a fan!There are two modes of play: "story mode" and "versus". * Story mode has in-character intro and outro dialog, pulling you into a comic storyline. It's a fun way to immerse yourself in the lore of the Marvel universe. * Versus mode pits your selection of heroes against heroes from another player's roster. It is worth noting that you are not actually playing the other person, but rather the AI using their heroes and abilities. This is a huge positive for me, because I don't have to deal with connection lags, people who afk for long periods, or trolling in a chat window. But if you're looking to match wits against a human opponent, this might leaving you wanting for more. Over 40 hours in, this continues to be a deeply engaging game!

content:
y 6, 2015
												My first review, i'm so excited. Lets begin:This game is very addictive , it's one of those games where you are always checking back and forward to see what's happened next. There are roughly 11 events per season(a season lasting 24 days give or take) and we are on season 10. Events lasting 3 days, straight after each other.Unfortunately this game has some incredibly frustrating flaws such as an unfair, unbalanced ranking system where you can get attacked for a frustrating 110 points(that's like dying 10 times straight in COD by just spawning) and superiority anxiety meaning the guy with the best characters' wins.While this game has a very large roster, it has very little little access to them. There are roughly 60 playable characters but few ways to get them.You get fan favorites like Deadpool, Nick fury and wolverine, Rocket & Groot, Avengers and many more, you even get obscure characters such as Venom, juggernaut, Daken(wolverines son), beast, black panther, Blade(yip - surprised to) , Daredevil, The hood(see in game) , Ragnarok(there's an upcoming movie - thor's clone) and even a dinosaur called devil dinosaur.You get characters from the x men universe (beast, mystique, storm, magneto etc), avengers (all from 2012 movie), guardians of the galaxy (so far rocket/groot, Gamora), fantastic four and more. While this game is not perfect, anyone who loves marvel and knows nearly everything about marvel should definitely play this game(free).  They currently on "Marvel now" and “Dark reign” story lines. So they very current as these are very recent storylines in the MU.Thanx please comment on my review.Thanks Dragon Priest

It's quite fun actually.Now i have read a lot of complaints about the free-to-play scheme and it more or less forcing you to spend money to progress, but the way i see it is that it gives you a fun time and when you run out of health you just take a break for a while. r 6, 2014
												This version of the game features the flaws of the mobile version. As detailed in reviews below, the mechanic for health is an issue, and then there is the AI, which is designed to cheat. It will be able to use abilities it does not have the points for, and Team Ups are messed up in the AI's favour.The final thing which makes me uninstall the game less than half an hour into playing, is that you cannot link your mobile and Steam accounts together, despite the quote from the developer that "The PC version runs off the same code and servers as the mobile versions. Battle against anyone, regardless of what device they're using", that couldn't be any further from the truth.So, they hope you will double dip, spending money in both versions. Well, not this guy, and hopefully you won't either :) If you're thinking about installing this version and you're already invested in the mobile version, change your mind.

												I wish I could recommend the game with all my hours but I can't really do that. The reason is that the game was fun at the start, but it quickly became apparent how money grubbing the company can be (lowering drop rates of high ranking characters, changing the way healing worked so you have to wait more often, etc.).Another thing I felt was more prevalent here than with other Puzzle Quest games is how much "luck" the AI sometimes has getting the right matches. For me it is simply impossible to win from the AI if both teams are the same level.Although you can play about 4 matches a day if you don't use the healing items you can get/buy, it isn't worth it if you want a full Puzzle Quest experience.

												Im changing my review after some extended play. The issues i originally had with the game were that it seemed intentionally diffucult and designed to make you pay in order to play. In short this game is much  MUCH MUCH better that i initially thought. and its one of teh games i enjoy playing an hour or so a day and likely will play it for a long time to come. content:
, 2016
												I think I've given the game a decent chance. It is kind of hard to rate, though; it's fun enough to play casually, but it makes casual play difficult with its problematic scaling that so often doesn't work and a level system that is completely dysfunctional.It really tries super-hard for microtransactions, which I understand are helpful to the developers, but good grief. When the game itself is made less fun and, more importantly, less functional for the sake of encouraging pay-to-win (or at least, pay to have more of a fun game), I feel there has been a fundamental failure.If a game, in and of itself, is fun, microtransactions can enhance that. But the most crucial part where Marvel Puzzle Quest falls short is that the game so often isn't fun, with a frequently cheap AI, problematic scaling algorithm, and restrictions and level-locking everywhere you look.There are many characters to choose from, which is very appealing, and the art and animations are great for what they are. Unfortunately this also is a double-edged sword, since you'll unquestionably find yourself up against the old and familiar obstacle of never really getting characters you want -- and being unable to just buy the specific character you do, even with real money -- and instead getting no end of characters you really don't.I really wish Marvel Puzzle Quest had a more casual play option, but everything is geared to "encourage" you to spend real money on making the game a more fun experience, which it should have been from the start. I know it's a free game, but it would be a lot more enjoyable, and I think more people would be more willing to give it a better score and recommendation, if it were a game priced reasonably and given a limited cash shop, but crafted better and more enjoyably. It's just a plain fact that they couldn't find a way to monetize a more casual play option, so it's not there. As a result, playing the game often ends up a frustrating reminder that if you'd just pony up the cash, you could probably have more fun.Meanwhile, Juggernaut's getting his fist ready. Better bend over. Some of the characters are plainly broken outright, and Juggernaut? He's one of them. Not only does he have massive health, but all of his moves are devastating. And you guessed it: he will always -- always -- get the combos he needs.

It's just a plain fact that they couldn't find a way to monetize a more casual play option, so it's not there. As a result, playing the game often ends up a frustrating reminder that if you'd just pony up the cash, you could probably have more fun.Meanwhile, Juggernaut's getting his fist ready. Better bend over. Some of the characters are plainly broken outright, and Juggernaut? He's one of them. Not only does he have massive health, but all of his moves are devastating. And you guessed it: he will always -- always -- get the combos he needs.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest (MPQ), is a mobile device port for steam.  Is that necessarily a bad thing?  I don't think so, but it is something that you need to keep in mind when looking at the UI and graphics.  It also effects the pay system, and since this is a F2P game, that's something people tend to focus on.  So let's start there:Can you play MPQ without spending money?  Yes.  Will you be competitive... well, mostly.  Let's talk about what real money gets used for:  You can purchase the two types of in-game currency with real money.  ISO and Gold.  ISO is used, mainly, to purchase boosts for use during combat and to spend to level up your characters.  It is the common currency of the game and is earned pretty easily.  Gold can be used for a number of things.  You can purchase additional slots to hold more characters (you are limited to 4 characters at the start and the prices for additional slots increases the more you have), you can purchase some "super-boosts", you can purchase health packs, and you can purchase additional covers for your characters.  Do you "have" to purchase these things?  Nope.  You do earn some gold through normal game play, and many people (myself included) have found that if you focuse your purchases you don't really hit a wall for a very long time.Let's move onto the gameplay itself.  MPQ is a tile matching game that is themed around the Marvel Comic Universe.  You swap tiles on a grid board to make 3 or longer chains of the same color/shape (think Bejewelled), you then score a hit dealing damage and (in most cases) generated Ability Points (AP) of that color.  Each character that you have selected (three) will have different abilities both passive and active.  These abilities are often fuelled by the AP you generate from your matches.  Pretty simple.  There is an entertaining amount of depth in selecting which team you want to bring to an event, and finding good synergy between character abilities is important.The characters are leveled up by unlocking their skills.  Skills are found by getting random drop "Covers".  Each cover has one skill associated with it.  Once you have used that cover to train the character in that skill it will increase the "Current Max Level" of the character, you can then use ISO to increase the level of the character.  Every level increase raises the max Hit Points of the character, the amount of damage they do and the effectivness of their skills.  Once you have unlocked the first level of the skill you can use Gold to increase the skill level (this is the main form of Pay-to-Win that you see in the game, but is limited by the fact that you have to have the base skill first to buy it).Health of your characters is the delaying factor in playing.  Not only are you doing damage to your enemies, but they are doing damage to your characters as well.  Their health will increase back to max over time, but with high level characters this can take several hours.  If you take your three best characters into a match that is over their head and get them all killed, this can mean that you don't get to play again for a few hours... unless you use Health Packs.  Health packs allow a character to return to full health immediately.  You earn health packs over time, one every 30 minutes, but could buy additionals for Gold.The game provides some basic "PVE" missions to get a feel for the game and earn some basic covers and boosts, but the main part of the game that allows you to progress is the "PVP" duels and "PVE" events.  Events rotate every few days and give opportunities for rare and high end rewards, but competition can be tough and some events require having certain characters to participate.  Duels are a staple way to put your team against another player.  The duels aren't really PVP though, because the same AI that runs the normal missions just uses the team, not an actual player.Long and the short of it:  I find MPQ to be very entertaining, something that I have spent many an hour with and am perfectly happy to keep playing.  There are issues, some bugs that break events and some exploits that people have found that can let them rank up super fast, and there are concerns about Pay-To-Win, but overall I can say that if you are looking for a casual time waster, this does the job rather well.

content:
er 20, 2013
												I usually only post reviews after spending 100 hours on a game but it is sale season and I can help save some money.  This is a great addictive game.  I loved Puzzle Quest 1/2 and this is better than both.  I even like the Marvel stuff, and I am a huge DC fan.  The meat is that you do not have to spend anything to enjoy this game, technically.  Just be prepared to put in lots of time.  I compare it to an online MMO, much like original WOW was for me.  It took me almost 2 years to max out the game.  Here nowhere near that kind of time but it will take some time, and WOW wasnt free either.  I have no problem chipping in a few bucks to support a company and game I like.  Programmers and developers need to eat too.  I do like the way they level up the heroes with random "covers" which is how you get your powers.  You can use in game coins to shortcut this but they are rare and you should spend them wisely.  It is not pay to win, but pay to shortcut I would say.  You don't really compete against anything but the game anyway, even in  PvP.  PvP is handled really interestingly.  You don't fight a person directly but their team run by the AI.  It took some getting used too but gives you loads of opponents to take on.It has tons of events where you can get new and unique characters.  Basically you match colored gems to get action points, which in turn, allow you to use your various powers, e.g. Iron Man's Repulsor Blast costs 10 red AP, so match 10 gems and you can fire off a blast.  If you ever wanted to play with some great characters and fun gameplay that wont tax your dexterity too much, this is it.I have read a few negative reviews and I feel everyone is entitled to their opinions, just remember that many of them haven't even played a full hour on this game so weigh those opinions accordingly.  There are even daily rewards to help you along, in the form of new characters, powers for them, tokens to get characters, etc.  It is a game looking to make money and since I support capitalism, that is fine with me.  I do not have even close the top tier characters but I have 16 at the moment and look forward to levelling them all.If you liked Bejewled, Marvel or even Dr. Mario (yes I am that old), give this game a try, it costs nothing but your time.

content:
er 10, 2016
												(Disregard my time played, I've spent many hours playing this on my phone, and it's basically the same product)A clever twist on the Puzzla Quest/Match 3 formula, Marvel Puzzle Quest is well-designed and interesting. I wish there was more to do in general (it's clear this game was designed for a mobile format...which it was), but the characters are well-designed for a plethora of tactical and strategic uses just waiting to be discovered. I do have my fair share of criticisms of course. Being designed as a mobile game, the monetization is quite aggressive and I would strongly recommend against spending any great amount of money on the game. On the same vein, if you DO manage to get a rare, powerful character - while they are somewhat useful from the start - it can be extremely difficult to power them up without spending money (that's how they get you!). Besides the monetization, as with any random match three game, it can be a little annoying if the RNG doesn't favor you - refusing to give you the colors you need or by dropping an enemy attack tile in a place you have absolutely no hope of matching, for example.But those criticisms aside, this is a great title for Marvel and Puzzle Quest fans alike.

content:
y 13, 2016
												Okay, let's not kid around: This is a barely-adapted port of a mobile game.For the PC port, I can't say the development team went far to optimise it and I won't comment too much on it.However, for the game itself, I just started playing this a day ago but it's pretty damn cool and there's so much to do and collect. It's awesome.I can't say how long the fun will last, but I do love the whole setup of the game.You collect comic book covers and currency to unlock characters and abilities, you can join your friends in a team online and everyone apparently gets bonuses for members of the team playing the game.My only frustration (as with most mobile-related games nowadays) is the time-based restriction of progress and unlockables (I haven't gotten far enough in the game to be sure about this, but I think this is seems like the only easy way to consistently get coins/tokens to unlock slots in your roster. You need this to add new members to your team.). Naturally, you're able to get past these restrictions with microtransactions.Fair enough, if these restrictions weren't in place, every dedicated player would have the strongest possible team in no time. I just wish there was a way to constantly progress without thinking about using real-world money.Aaaanyway, overall, this game is really fun and I'm enjoying it so far.Let's go with 8/10.-1 for the crappy mobile port that still says "tap" instead of "click"and -1 because of the constant need for patience and/or microtransactions if you wanna get everything in the game.

content:
er 28, 2013
												This game gets a bad rep.. and mostly because people are cheap.  Here's my take on it:I know my "time played" only says a little over an hour.  But I've easily put 10+ hours into the iPhone version.  And I've never had to spend a dime.  It's a game you can EASILY play for 30 minutes, then come back to, rinse and repeat.  And you would never need to spend money.  I've done very well in the iPhone version and never bought anything from the store.For the PC players.. the game is free.  FREE.  What do you expect for Free?  Have you ever worked at a software company?  Probably not.  Any developer of software would be out of business in a month if they just gave you free games that never asked for micro-transactions.  All you have to do is click the X and move on.Personally, when I tried the PC version, I enjoyed it.  It's pretty much the exact same game, but without the limiting frames of the smart phone versions.  Very big and bright.  But otherwise identical.  It's Bejeweled, and every once in a while a Marvel Hero artwork jumps out and throws some particle effects around.Cons?  Yeah, there are definitely some.  This is a VERY cash shop oriented game that will remind you at every turn that you can buy tokens, iso-8, characters, covers, etc etc etc.  But like most games of this ilk, you can get around that if you don't suck at it, and use your resources wisely.  Sure, there's a bit of luck involved.. and God forbid you would have to spend $5-10 to support the developer of a game you got FOR FREE.  My only other gripe is that the smart phone version of it doesn't sync with the steam version.. it really sucks having to start over when playing it on PC, when I have a bad ♥♥♥ team on my phone.In the end, I give this a 8/10.  It's no Puzzle Quest 2 (but what is) and all I can say is that if money is that big of a problem for you, then video games shouldn't be your hobby.  Maybe get a better job.  :)

ry 7, 2014
												A lot of people seem to moan about microtransactions, but for me the game really is a blast, and I've spent only about 3 euro (SHIELD's recruit pack, discounted at the time) to get more space for additional characters. While it doesn't seem so at first, there's suprising depth to the strategy - you need to balance your team so that you can use every color of tiles and have the stronger characters cover the weaker ones (so be careful not to overlevel your support, like Storm, to the point where she takes the spot in front of your Wolverine and gets promptly chewed in three turns). Don't expect long playing sessions because of the helath regeneration system, but the deafault heal time plus 5 regenerating health packs usually allow you to play three-four games every two hours or so. And honestly, it's a match three game, so you'd become bored with more. Great for breaks at work and extra nice if you are a Marvel fan, I appreciate the use of comic book covers as skill icons. Shame about the absence of Steam Cloud support, though.

er 18, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is a tipical block combining game that adds to the game the marvel universe/heroes to give some diversity and fun collecting/leveling the heroes.Every heroe has diferent habilities and you can fight in 3v3 battles combining the strenghts of your heroes to progress through the game. You start with 3 basic heroes after doing the tutorial and you have to manage to lvl up using the ISO points you obtain by winning battles. Some battles on the campaign gives you extra heroes or hero points (hero points are the ones you need to have extra slots for more heroes).Its a bit slow at the beginning because every time a hero takes damages, it needs time to restore his hp, so whe you have only 3 heroes it can be a bit slow to advance. But as soon as you have 5+ heroes and reach lvl 10+ with some of them, you can keep playing almost indefinitly without having to spend real money on the game. Paying real money on this game only gives you a faster progression, but you can manage to do everything just by playing the game.If you like puzzle games its worth to try this one, just have in mind the first few hours are a bit slow if you dont invest real money.

content:
y 24, 2014
												Very fun puzzle quest variant! The puzzle mechanic is excellent, and team creation is dynamic and enjoyable. Rewards are meaningful, and collecting the "comic covers" (i.e., leveling your Heros) is very fun.It is also an excellent implementation of both free to play and micro transactions. Spending real money is by no means necessary, and although it speeds up your progress it does not make you more powerful than equal leveled players who have not spent money. The primary use for real money is to buy extra character slots, but you can earn the necessary currency by playing in the campaign or the semi-PvP daily and weekly events. Although a number of other reviewers have voiced dislike for the time based healing system, I actually really like it. Taking damage to your Heroes is bad, and the game is more enjoyable because of this difficulty backed up with a real penalty! I have yet to spend any real money on the game, and yet have played a ton and enjoyed it.

ry 20, 2014
												If you have any interest in super heroes, and collecting stuff then this game is for you. Don't heed people who say it's micro transactions galore. You can play without paying. Everyday there are several multiplayer events in which you can participate for free and win lots of Iso-8 and HP (game's more valuable other currency) if you are successful enough. There is also a huge single player campaign with lots of rewards. I don't know what people are complaining about. There is one thing though. If you are very competitive then you might feel you need to pay to get ahead of others. It will only save you game play time. Others will catch up to you if you pay, but it will take a while. Since I enjoy the game as it is and I'm a casual gamer at heart, I enjoy it a lot. The game is addictive. I also played old Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. I had enjoyed that one though I didn't finish it. This is a bit different from that one in how leveling works and the fact that you don't have a single character to play with. From what I heard, game's support team is very efficient. I didn't have any problems with the game so far though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 12, 2014
												I'm having fun. On the surface, it's a simple colour matching game. Easy, right? Anyone can do it. As a Hard Core Casual gamer, I really appreciate that. No timer, no hand eye coordination and instant decision making required. Yeay!It's also "Free to play" or supposed to be. Don't believe it! It's addictive. Like... like... shopping for a shopaholic. I'm a shopaholic. Having said that, I'm well aware of my gaming budget limitations. So i've spent enough on this game to buy a PS4 or so my friend tells me. I don't really care since there are no games on a PS4 that I can actually play and my PS3 works just fine. The games on my Playstation watchlist are all coming out on PS3 anyway. So, my game budget can handle this. I just wish Steam would stop blocking me, all the time. I'm nowhere near $2000.00 in 24 hours.Anyway, back to the game... Past the surface there are strategies and tactics that make the battles interesting. Different enemies change the feel and style of play required to win and so it keeps being fun. It's very grindy if your gaming budget or Steam doesn't allow you to buy what you need to level up your characters. BUT if you're not a PVP ♥♥♥♥♥ it doesn't really matter. Take your time, wind down after work with a game or two and eventually in a few... errr... years... ^_~ you'll get there eventually. I've only been playing for a few weeks, but I've paid for my character levels in cash. You get a present everyday you do play a game or two and if you care to play in the PVP arena, the rewards are more consistant than in the PVE games where the reward randomiser can give you the minimum reward heaps before surrendering the good stuff. It seems to be getting better, but that might just be my imagination. I didn't collect any data to compare last week's drops to this week's.The only downside at the moment is that the PVE content seems very limited. There's a Prologue which I have completed, though not obtained all the rewards and no sign of "Chapter 1". There are PVE Events, but because they are of limited time... go on holidays without your computer and you miss them.  If your team isn't at a sufficiently high level, you may only be able to complete the first few fights before the opponents get too hard to fight. Then you're stuck grinding those same few fights, your team can manage, to get enough points to reap the rewards on offer in the time that the Event is on for. There's even PVP Events - lots more of these, with Lightning Rounds and Tournaments you have to pay to play in.  I'm not much of a PVP player and once the teams I have to fight get too hard as my ranking climbs, I lose interest until I can level up my characters to get a chance at winning again. BUT by then the PVP Event, is over. Hmmm....I'm much more interested in Chapter 1 and the continuation of the Story started in the Prologue. Don't tell me they continued the story in past Events, cause I wasn't there to play them and when do they become Chapter 1?That's the MAJOR downside of this game. There doesn't seem to be anything beyond the Prologue.So you ask yourself why I'm recommending this game? Because I'm having FUN! Read a few other reviews and the forums and there are all kinds of grumbles about its inadequacies. BUT when all is said and done, it is a FUN game. It is an easy game to pick up and play, and once you get started, the character and power combinations become intriguing. It gets addictive simply because someone like me whats to collect them all and see how well, or not, they work together.I might wish for more permanent content... maybe there will be. I can only hope. In the mean time I'll be having fun with what is there.

												Marvel Puzzle Quest is a very fun game.  I downloaded it the day it came out on iOS and I have played the PC Version since beta.  I have been a fan of Puzzle Quest since playing the original on my PSP, and well that plus Marvel really got me interested.  The gameplay is fun, really dig the UI (especially on PC), and there's a fun variety of characters and abilities.  That said, I feel since launch the developers have put in a lot of walls that were not previously there for the sake of them making more money.  I understand that game development is a business and making money is good, but the game was much more fun in previous versions.  That doesn't stop me from playing it like a no good junkie, though.

content:
ry 7, 2014
												A lot of people seem to moan about microtransactions, but for me the game really is a blast, and I've spent only about 3 euro (SHIELD's recruit pack, discounted at the time) to get more space for additional characters. While it doesn't seem so at first, there's suprising depth to the strategy - you need to balance your team so that you can use every color of tiles and have the stronger characters cover the weaker ones (so be careful not to overlevel your support, like Storm, to the point where she takes the spot in front of your Wolverine and gets promptly chewed in three turns). Don't expect long playing sessions because of the helath regeneration system, but the deafault heal time plus 5 regenerating health packs usually allow you to play three-four games every two hours or so. And honestly, it's a match three game, so you'd become bored with more. Great for breaks at work and extra nice if you are a Marvel fan, I appreciate the use of comic book covers as skill icons. Shame about the absence of Steam Cloud support, though.

content:
er 20, 2013
												I usually only post reviews after spending 100 hours on a game but it is sale season and I can help save some money.  This is a great addictive game.  I loved Puzzle Quest 1/2 and this is better than both.  I even like the Marvel stuff, and I am a huge DC fan.  The meat is that you do not have to spend anything to enjoy this game, technically.  Just be prepared to put in lots of time.  I compare it to an online MMO, much like original WOW was for me.  It took me almost 2 years to max out the game.  Here nowhere near that kind of time but it will take some time, and WOW wasnt free either.  I have no problem chipping in a few bucks to support a company and game I like.  Programmers and developers need to eat too.  I do like the way they level up the heroes with random "covers" which is how you get your powers.  You can use in game coins to shortcut this but they are rare and you should spend them wisely.  It is not pay to win, but pay to shortcut I would say.  You don't really compete against anything but the game anyway, even in  PvP.  PvP is handled really interestingly.  You don't fight a person directly but their team run by the AI.  It took some getting used too but gives you loads of opponents to take on.It has tons of events where you can get new and unique characters.  Basically you match colored gems to get action points, which in turn, allow you to use your various powers, e.g. Iron Man's Repulsor Blast costs 10 red AP, so match 10 gems and you can fire off a blast.  If you ever wanted to play with some great characters and fun gameplay that wont tax your dexterity too much, this is it.I have read a few negative reviews and I feel everyone is entitled to their opinions, just remember that many of them haven't even played a full hour on this game so weigh those opinions accordingly.  There are even daily rewards to help you along, in the form of new characters, powers for them, tokens to get characters, etc.  It is a game looking to make money and since I support capitalism, that is fine with me.  I do not have even close the top tier characters but I have 16 at the moment and look forward to levelling them all.If you liked Bejewled, Marvel or even Dr. Mario (yes I am that old), give this game a try, it costs nothing but your time.

content:
0, 2014
												So, MPQ.. yeah.  It's a game that comes in a lot of stages and as a result is very deceptive about what it is.For the most part it's like any other Puzzle Quest game.  At the very beginning you'll progress through a story mode, where about half of the fights are against minions (characters that do not match gems).  It takes a while but eventually you'll be fighting against villains that  match and use skills.After you build up a few of the starting characters you'll start participating in the player vs player and player vs environment events.  In these events you'll compete against other players for ranking (prizes).  An event ends almost every day, so you'll probably end up playing every day to maintain a high score.  How you play will change a lot as you transition from starting characters (one stars) to mid level ones (two stars) and then into high level ones (three and four stars).  Having a roster of three stars allows you to more easily compete in the tournaments.The game itself is well designed in that it will hit every one of those points that keeps a player playing (events that have a definite ending, a pokemon-esque roster that keeps you intrigued, timers on healing and health packs, and a currency used to level said roster).  Transitioning from one stars into two stars and then two stars into three stars is a fantastic feeling and the gameplay really changes when you do.However, because of how the game is designed, there are a bunch of flaws.  For one, it's almost never ideal to enter an event until just before it ends due to  bracket placement and rubberbanding (your nodes will score a lot more later in an event than earlier, so you'll catch up to a top rank player very very quickly).  Of course, rubberbanding doesn't exist in all of the PvE maps but it's in most.  As for bracket placement: when you enter an event you're put into a bracket with other players that entered around the same time.  Entering late usually guarantees that the top players of your event will not score as high, making it far easier to place higher (and thus get better rewards).The biggest problem, though, is with the system called "MMR."  MMR is effectively an invisible score attributed to your account that more or less compromises your win/loss ratio, pitting you against other players with similar MMR.  This sounds like it would balance the game a lot -- and it sort of does -- but in actuallity it makes climbing early stages of brackets much more difficult than it should be, since you'll be fighting similarly leveled rosters for marginal point gains (so you'll be taking tons of damage).Since I've started playing, the transition into two star rosters was made negligible, as two star covers are given out very, very frequently.  Transitioning into three star rosters was also made easier, but it still takes more than a couple of months to break into them after you've made a strong two star lineup.While I greatly enjoyed this game while playing, I ended up leaving due to it taking up a significant amount of my time (minimum of an hour a day, sometimes up to 4 or 5) just to stay competitive.  That, alongside of a fairly venomous (if you arent scoring well enough in any event, most alliances will just kick you on the spot and take in a new member: I was threatened three or four times with removal from my alliance over a point total in a PvE event with rubberbanding.  Low and behold I score a ton of points right at the end and place in about the middle of the alliance, this over the course of about two hours compared to the 6 to 8 each other person in my alliance was putting in, but they were still talking about kicking me lol) end game community just pushed me away and made me say "Yeah, I'd rather play other games with my friends than devote time to this."Anyway, hey, the game is well designed but I'm not so sure the developers really care about it being fun so much as making money out of it.  Your mileage may vary and it takes a significant amount of time to get anywhere, but yeah, I had a really good time with it.  Shame that the community really pushed me out, but whatcha gon' do?

												A lot of people seem to moan about microtransactions, but for me the game really is a blast, and I've spent only about 3 euro (SHIELD's recruit pack, discounted at the time) to get more space for additional characters. While it doesn't seem so at first, there's suprising depth to the strategy - you need to balance your team so that you can use every color of tiles and have the stronger characters cover the weaker ones (so be careful not to overlevel your support, like Storm, to the point where she takes the spot in front of your Wolverine and gets promptly chewed in three turns). Don't expect long playing sessions because of the helath regeneration system, but the deafault heal time plus 5 regenerating health packs usually allow you to play three-four games every two hours or so. And honestly, it's a match three game, so you'd become bored with more. Great for breaks at work and extra nice if you are a Marvel fan, I appreciate the use of comic book covers as skill icons. Shame about the absence of Steam Cloud support, though.

content:
er 18, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is a tipical block combining game that adds to the game the marvel universe/heroes to give some diversity and fun collecting/leveling the heroes.Every heroe has diferent habilities and you can fight in 3v3 battles combining the strenghts of your heroes to progress through the game. You start with 3 basic heroes after doing the tutorial and you have to manage to lvl up using the ISO points you obtain by winning battles. Some battles on the campaign gives you extra heroes or hero points (hero points are the ones you need to have extra slots for more heroes).Its a bit slow at the beginning because every time a hero takes damages, it needs time to restore his hp, so whe you have only 3 heroes it can be a bit slow to advance. But as soon as you have 5+ heroes and reach lvl 10+ with some of them, you can keep playing almost indefinitly without having to spend real money on the game. Paying real money on this game only gives you a faster progression, but you can manage to do everything just by playing the game.If you like puzzle games its worth to try this one, just have in mind the first few hours are a bit slow if you dont invest real money.

content:
y 24, 2014
												Very fun puzzle quest variant! The puzzle mechanic is excellent, and team creation is dynamic and enjoyable. Rewards are meaningful, and collecting the "comic covers" (i.e., leveling your Heros) is very fun.It is also an excellent implementation of both free to play and micro transactions. Spending real money is by no means necessary, and although it speeds up your progress it does not make you more powerful than equal leveled players who have not spent money. The primary use for real money is to buy extra character slots, but you can earn the necessary currency by playing in the campaign or the semi-PvP daily and weekly events. Although a number of other reviewers have voiced dislike for the time based healing system, I actually really like it. Taking damage to your Heroes is bad, and the game is more enjoyable because of this difficulty backed up with a real penalty! I have yet to spend any real money on the game, and yet have played a ton and enjoyed it.

ry 20, 2014
												If you have any interest in super heroes, and collecting stuff then this game is for you. Don't heed people who say it's micro transactions galore. You can play without paying. Everyday there are several multiplayer events in which you can participate for free and win lots of Iso-8 and HP (game's more valuable other currency) if you are successful enough. There is also a huge single player campaign with lots of rewards. I don't know what people are complaining about. There is one thing though. If you are very competitive then you might feel you need to pay to get ahead of others. It will only save you game play time. Others will catch up to you if you pay, but it will take a while. Since I enjoy the game as it is and I'm a casual gamer at heart, I enjoy it a lot. The game is addictive. I also played old Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. I had enjoyed that one though I didn't finish it. This is a bit different from that one in how leveling works and the fact that you don't have a single character to play with. From what I heard, game's support team is very efficient. I didn't have any problems with the game so far though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 12, 2014
												I'm having fun. On the surface, it's a simple colour matching game. Easy, right? Anyone can do it. As a Hard Core Casual gamer, I really appreciate that. No timer, no hand eye coordination and instant decision making required. Yeay!It's also "Free to play" or supposed to be. Don't believe it! It's addictive. Like... like... shopping for a shopaholic. I'm a shopaholic. Having said that, I'm well aware of my gaming budget limitations. So i've spent enough on this game to buy a PS4 or so my friend tells me. I don't really care since there are no games on a PS4 that I can actually play and my PS3 works just fine. The games on my Playstation watchlist are all coming out on PS3 anyway. So, my game budget can handle this. I just wish Steam would stop blocking me, all the time. I'm nowhere near $2000.00 in 24 hours.Anyway, back to the game... Past the surface there are strategies and tactics that make the battles interesting. Different enemies change the feel and style of play required to win and so it keeps being fun. It's very grindy if your gaming budget or Steam doesn't allow you to buy what you need to level up your characters. BUT if you're not a PVP ♥♥♥♥♥ it doesn't really matter. Take your time, wind down after work with a game or two and eventually in a few... errr... years... ^_~ you'll get there eventually. I've only been playing for a few weeks, but I've paid for my character levels in cash. You get a present everyday you do play a game or two and if you care to play in the PVP arena, the rewards are more consistant than in the PVE games where the reward randomiser can give you the minimum reward heaps before surrendering the good stuff. It seems to be getting better, but that might just be my imagination. I didn't collect any data to compare last week's drops to this week's.The only downside at the moment is that the PVE content seems very limited. There's a Prologue which I have completed, though not obtained all the rewards and no sign of "Chapter 1". There are PVE Events, but because they are of limited time... go on holidays without your computer and you miss them.  If your team isn't at a sufficiently high level, you may only be able to complete the first few fights before the opponents get too hard to fight. Then you're stuck grinding those same few fights, your team can manage, to get enough points to reap the rewards on offer in the time that the Event is on for. There's even PVP Events - lots more of these, with Lightning Rounds and Tournaments you have to pay to play in.  I'm not much of a PVP player and once the teams I have to fight get too hard as my ranking climbs, I lose interest until I can level up my characters to get a chance at winning again. BUT by then the PVP Event, is over. Hmmm....I'm much more interested in Chapter 1 and the continuation of the Story started in the Prologue. Don't tell me they continued the story in past Events, cause I wasn't there to play them and when do they become Chapter 1?That's the MAJOR downside of this game. There doesn't seem to be anything beyond the Prologue.So you ask yourself why I'm recommending this game? Because I'm having FUN! Read a few other reviews and the forums and there are all kinds of grumbles about its inadequacies. BUT when all is said and done, it is a FUN game. It is an easy game to pick up and play, and once you get started, the character and power combinations become intriguing. It gets addictive simply because someone like me whats to collect them all and see how well, or not, they work together.I might wish for more permanent content... maybe there will be. I can only hope. In the mean time I'll be having fun with what is there.

content:
12, 2014
												Recommend with a strong caveat:I enjoy this game on my mobile device, but am disappointed to find that it does not allow you to sync your steam and mobile version together in order to share progress (especially since progress is a big part of the game).  If this is the only platform/device you want to play on, it can be very fun.  However, running multiple play-throughs on different devices does not really add anything since the progression is based on chance rewards rather than customization choice.Also, I had issues running it in full screen mode.  ymmvEdit: I should also note that the game is quite grindy and uses delay-based mechanics to entice players to spend money to play faster.  If you play casually a couple of rounds per day it isn't bad (though I have heard later levels are more taxing), but you will be impeded if you want to play for long sessions.I wish I didn't have to choose between a binary recommend and not recommend.  This game is great for killing 10 minutes between other things, but suffers from abusive design.

												Cons:~ Monetized, and not well. Darn near everything costs and you will never have enough of whatever to do the job. ~ Rewards you cannot use until you pay or earn premium currency for the space to claim it.~ Time-Based System would be acceptable if it were shorter.Pros:~ Puzzle Quest Series' infamous "Stacking the Deck against you in place of intelligent opponents" difficulty system seems to have been abandoned. You get lucky drops of new gems just as often as the CPU does. Defeat is not decided for you in advance.~ Interesting improvement system, despite monetization angle.~ Guild system and game modes that reward you for acting together, though apart (sharing powers, guild-wide rewards in their special events). Makes many good things you get into benefits you can share (such as your great high-level card being sent out as a backup to allies).Play it. Cautiously.

content:
er 21, 2013
												Fun game, but it feels better suited to tablets and shouldn't have been ported to PC. A lot if issues that other people are having can be lessen by playing in short sessions, such at 10 to 30 minutes at a time, especially with free heroes that the game will give you every few days, as well as cash shop currancy. With this game being on PC, we're acustomed to playing an hour or more, and this game penalizes that without using cash.One new game mechanic added to the Puzzle Quest system are abilities that effect tiles on the board. Such as Iron Man placing Protect Tiles, that turn the normal gems in to shielded gems to reduce damage to your heroes, or Storm's Attack Tiles that damage your opponent. They still behave like normal gems, in that you can match them to other colors and they'll go away. Some of your enemies also place gems that have a count down timer, and will activate after a number of turns have pasted. Like HAMMER Assassins that will place Sniper Tiles on the board, and will deal heavy damage to your heros after a few turns have passed. This helps you as a player, since you can prevent the enemies abilities by matching those countdown tiles, and removing the ability before it has a chance to go off.The worst part about this game, is that when your heroes are damaged or knocked out in a game, they will have to recover and this can take up to an hour or more without using heal packs. You start out with a dozen or so, but once you run out, you'll have to pay cash for more. Also, improving your hero is terrible. Instead of earning experience in battles, you earn this ISO-8 currancy, and you spend that on heroes to improve their base health and a few other stats. To improve their abilities, you have to either spend a ton of the premium currancy or hope that you get another copy of that hero. Say you have Captain America, and he only has one ability. To unlock his other 2 abilities, you'll need another Captain America, with that ability, and add his to your hero. It requires too much luck to improve just one hero, and Puzzle Quest's bosses are betting that will pay tons of money to do so.Yes, this game has a lot of options to get ahead with cash purchases, and these purchases won't go very far, since most of them are completely random. Say you really want Spider-man on your team, then you have to option of fighting Venom to win a Spider-man with a Fantastic Four suit or throw a few dollars at random hero packs and pray he turns up.I do recommend this game for tablets, since it's best suit to short play sessions.

content:
8, 2014
												Very fun, and not very pay-to-win like all the reviews say.The PvE story roughly follows the Dark Reign comics, with Norman Osborn, the Green Goblin, creating the subtlely-named Dark Avengers, of which Bullseye is the best by far, in order to do something for someone, I don't know. He is opposed by Iron Man, Black Widow, Storm, Hawkeye, Wolverine, and Thor. It ends with a fairly high level boss fight, which can be easily beaten with stuns or heal abuse because it's a three-on-one curbstomp.After that, you can go through weekly events against other players to earn more ISO-8, which is your experience, or Hero Points, which can get you more slots for more characters. Most of these events have restrictions or characters that get bonuses in stats, encouraging you to use them in your team and keep the characters you're not as interested in.I haven't seen the pay-to-win much in my time of playing. Even if you buy ISO-8 and Hero Points, you're still going to have to keep up against people who have more experience with their characters than you and can set up teams with better gem coverage. And even if you get a full party of rare characters, they don't all work together as well as the lower level characters, and many of the three star characters have weaknesses to their powers, such as Iron Man Model 40's Recharge, which provides gems to use on other attacks, but stuns Iron Man for two turns.Overall, I enjoy this a good bit, and recommend it to others.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
r 3, 2014
												Okay, so this clearly isn't a Triple A title but it can still be good right? Right?The answer is no. It isn't. It has good elements of fun. It's fairly entertaining as you gather new heroes, upgrade the ones you like, have cool and sometimes very useful special attacks. So what's the issue then? It's boring and poorly made.Well first off, the game is basically a Mobile Game ported to PC without ANY of the things a PC port should have. It doesn't have a resolution that would be fitting for a PC and instead looks like you're playing a Tablet game on your monitor. While that may not sound that bad, I've noticed even some of the UI choices are still touch screen like. It overall feels down right aweful to look at for extended periods of time.Next is the gameplay itself, it's very barebones as the best animations you will see is the little Gems going POOF from chain completions. The special attacks consit of your character of choice flying into the center of the screen and waggling a bit with some flashing lights and sounds.Once you figure out if you can enjoy the gameplay or not comes the ways you upgrade your heroes. It's basically random lottery as you have to get another copy of your hero to upgrade their skills, after which you then need to use ISO-8 the magical nonsense item to then increase their level. You also can only have so many heroes before you need to purchase more slots. Now that isn't too bad as it's normal, the problem is you can only use what is basically a "Money" currency which is limited as you only get some per day unless you wish to pay for it. The same currency is used for pretty much everything and they will try their damnedest to get you to waste it on heroes, upgrades, level increases, etc. Then they shoehorn in some Healing character nonsense that basically ripped off from Facebook games.The story missions try ever so hard to entertain and keep you interested but the lack of voices, new images and basically an interesting story that hasn't been heard over and over again, brings it down on its knees. The more interesting and rewarding stories are locked out until you play and gather Strong/OP heroes. It's not even recommended that you try them WHATSOEVER until you're very well off into the game as they will not only stomp you out but cause you to need "Health packs" just to recover and continue playing the game. The next part of story missions is that they often can be replayed for different loot, the problem is even though it says 1/4 things to be looted you can still gain something that ISN'T an option as loot. I've gotten ISO-20 which wasn't an option instead of ISO-100 or another Iron Man. When all you do is want to have 4/4 in loot and you have to replay the same, easy, boring level repeatedly just to make sure you have everything useful from that mission, it gets very boring.The art direction is okay at best; you have art work that doesn't look the best on these big screens as it's made for much smaller ones. The characters don't have the best animations as they seem more and more like paper cutouts than they do powerful superheroes. It's pretty underwhelming watching them play out an unskippable animation.The sound is basically the same as the art direction, bland, boring and not that interesting. I was really hoping for some good Marvel action tunes.In short, the game starts off okay but slowly turns into a long road through Pay to Play. Not too bad if played in short, short bursts but very boring if you're going to play for hours at a time.3 Broken Gems out of 10.

content:
y 28, 2016
												I'm not one to be suckered in my free games usually, but having enjoyed games like Bejewelled and Puzzle Quest in the past, I figured I'd give it a try. At first, I played a few times, and then stopped playing for a few months as I wasn't sure if it was really my thing or not. I'm not sure what made me decide to try it again one day, but as you can no doubt tell from the hours I've got recorded playing this game, I kinda liked it... just a little ;) It's likely that it was the whole 'feemium' thing that turned me off to start, but this game is generous enough to make you want to keep playing without NEEDING to spend money.I've never been a comic fanatic or anything, but I've always enjoyed the characters from the Marvel universe, and loved watching the old cartoons like X-Men. Over the years I've been playing this game, I have spent the odd bit of cash here and there, but I don't think the amount I've spent would only come to around $30 I'd say. The team at D3 are continually adding new features and characters which keep my interest, and I am a member of an alliance with a group of firends who play, which makes it a little more fun, being able to discuss things with the group. It also allows you to get extra bonuses, as when your alliance members do well in events, the whole alliance will get rewards.This is a great game to play while having my morning coffee, as it's quick, yet rewarding, but at times during certain events, can be brutally difficult (Damn ninjas!! *shakes fist*). It wouldn't be much fun if it was a walk in the park though!It's also great that they have daily events, which keeps me coming back to see what's new and what else I can get! (This unlocks after you've played through a certain amount of the single player, so don't give up too soon!)If you've ever played match 3 games, and enjoyed them, I can't recommend this one highly enough. Building up an ever expanding roster of characters as fun as the game itself! In my opinion, it's by far the best of all the Puzzle Quest games that have been released, and I even though I have spent many years playing this game, I can't see myself stopping any time soon!I notice a lot of people don't recommend this based on their not being able to sync with their mobile version, but I've only ever played on Steam, and as such, I haven't come across any of those issues. They seem to say that they're given in game currency for free (Hero Points), but you can also get that in the PC version. Perhaps the amounts you get are different or something? I don't know as I've never played the mobile one, so if you only plan to play on PC, don't let that deter you, as you can get free HP in this version too.
