content:
3, 2014
												Whether you will like this game depends on what you are looking for in it. Most of the criticism of this game revolves around the 'pay to win' accusations, and in a sense they're true, you're unlikely to win most of the main events if you don't sink some money into buying new heroes, health packs or slots for new heroes, so if you're the kind of person who wants to open it up and play for hours non-stop without paying a thing this game will likely frustrate you. For me I didn't want to spend much on this game, I've spent a total of £6 after 100 hours playing and I don't intend to spend anymore. When I play I'm not in a rush and am happy to slowly build up my heroes over time, I play in shorter bursts to do certain events and can play in windowed mode to rotate it around with other things. Some people get annoyed because if you lose and have run out of health packs the only way to get more is to buy them or wait to win more in certain events. As for the actual gameplay, there's not much to say. You pick three of your heroes against opposition and match the colours up to best suit the abilities of your selected heroes. It's puzzlequest and free to try out if you're unsure. Also note that for the multiplayer you are not actually playing against other people, it is against three of their heroes that the ai controls.

												Let me get this out of the way: this is a very nice game. It combines match-3 with cardfight (not sure what they are called) games where you level up your cards. Here you level up your (Marvel) heroes by earning Iso-8 and by earning their skills.There are events that give you big prices (lots of Iso-8 or recruit tokens for more heroes).More heroes. You guessed it, gold is real money.Four hero slots is nothing. I played less than a day and already had 10 heroes (5 rostered and 5 waiting to be recruited).If that part of the game was any different or if buying with real money doesn't bother you: play this game. It's nice. Good graphics, nice sound effects, good skills and there's even a storyline.For me however that's a dealbreaker. You will not progress enough if you do not buy extra roster space.So...byebye MPQ.

content:
er 12, 2015
												Typical puzzle game with a twist. Each super hero has special abilities that are charged up by matching gems of each color. For instance, a super hero may have a power that requires 12 "red" gems to charge, so you must match 4 sets of 3 red stones, then that power becomes available to use. There are some interesting strategic combinations that affect the outcome of the game, and the Marvel characters are beautifully rendered.It doesn't take long, however, before you doubtlessly realize that you have hopelessly screwed up your game, either by buying heroes when you should have been buying hero slots or leveling up your existing heroes. This will basically make the game a fun sucking grind early on. The obvious solution would be to start over from scratch. This is easy... if you are playing this game on a phone. If you are playing on a PC, you're basically screwed, because the developers haven't bothered to allow players to reset their progress on PC (at least not a way that's as easy as "start new game").Go ahead and look up how to reset the game, and you will find a lot of conflicting opinions, and very little that is likely to work, since the solutions are all from 2013. The quick and expensive way to make your game playable again is to buy tokens to fix your FUBAR game save... so, of course, that's where they want you to go... when phone users can just delete their file and start over from scratch.This game is hopelessly flawed on PC. It's literally stops being fun as soon as you hit the brick wall of battles the game says "are trivial" difficulty. Unfortunately, it's yet another underwhelming Marvel title on PC. Stick to the phone if you're going to play it at all.

content:
ry 25, 2014
												I am not the biggest fan of freemium games since most requrie that you spend money to progress through the game. I wouldn't say that this one is the exception to the rule, but you can certainly enjoy the basics of the game without having to pay money to continue playing. I put in around 30 hours before I decided to pay 9.99 to add some ways to preserve some characters that I started winning. If you're willing to grind or play smart then you can certainly put the time in without spending a dime. I highly recommend playing the multiplayer section in the Danger Room to add some quality upgrades in a relatively easy manner. A couple quick cons - the newest update added a penalty for skipping hard multiplayer battles. It's not a huge penalty, but if you're in management or free mode then it's going to take a bite out of upgrading. I'd also like to see some of the prices come down a bit to make it easier to save your rewards if you don't want to spend money. Otherwise, this can be something to enjoy between FFVII or Metro:Last Light games.

content:
, 2014
												I read up on a lot of reviews before playing this and they heavily recommended against the free to play game because of the Pay-To-Win methods. Microtransactions are present and I can see where they're all coming from however this game is still a good game.For being free it provides the basic advantage of being there for you to play if you've got nothing better to do. The game isn't really one where you can sit and spend hours upon hours playing but it is great for a few minutes between things if you need to burn the time. For example, I play league of legends with my friends and always find the wait between matches about 5-10 minutes long with champion select and the loading screen included. Therefore I can get a few matches of Marvel in and still enjoy the game for what it is.After playing this game for almost a month I can finally see some serious problems as to why people wouldn't want to play this game. Even after a months time I'm unable to really collect higher level characters due to their rarity and the slow process of collecting coins to buy roster points. The game heavily presses for the purchase of coins however they're so damn expensive it would have been better for me to just buy the damn game for $60 to unlock everything. Which to be honest wouldn't even get you everything in this game since everything is given to you by chance.Either way after this month of playing I've still found myself getting one for a few matches and putting it away. Having fun and still progressing through the game even if it is slow. I recommend everyone to pick it up as a game to have on the side but it is definitially not a game I would spend all day playing.

												Great game of puzzle 3 match style.When it came on steam I played to be first in the versus events. I change my mind after a few months.Too much time to give to become competitive.I realized its more fun to play casualy doing the Deadpool Daily and playing versus 3-4 fights while collecting heroes.Description of the game :You get covers who represent a character with one of is powers.You can use a second cover of same character to boost the  maximum level of the character and level up the power 1/5 -> 2/5 , or give a new power among a new color. The heroes has 3 powers.There is 6 colors on the board and you need to make matches to fill your AP reserve that your heroes will consume for their powers. The more powerfull the ability , the more it will consume.You also make matches to give damage to the enemie heroes. The powers of your heroes will help doing damage, steal AP, add bonus damage, add protection, scramble the board ... etc.Every hero has 3 colors preference.Select a team of 3 heros for your battles and make them use all colors while keeping a sinergy between them.When they get damage, the damage stays for the next fight.You can wait until they heal by themselves or use Heal Card who can be gain from events or Hero Points.As you gain many heroes and play casual it will not bother anymore.Hero Points can be gain from events by reaching the high scores at the end of events.Mostly easier to gain them by using the Real Money with micro transaction.Same for Isodium (purple quartz). You gain little quantities from any fights. Mainly use for the level up of heroes. If you play casual , you will just accumulate and sell covers of new heroes for those you will gain a preference.Such as Wolverine > Hawkeye.The versus system will get you angry, and frustation once you realise how it really work.You play against AI with team made by dev or players.You gain point by winning, Bigger the difference of points make you gain more points.While your team get attack and lose .. the difference make you lose more points.When you want to do retalation. Their points are lower, so you retaliate for 10 points from a 50 points lost.  You need to wait for them to get more points ... if they go for it.You can buy shields with Hero points. And realise you can't attack anyone from your ladder, which should make you realised you are fighting other ladder who will attack you fault of knowing how aggressive the other ladder groups actualy are.Conclusion , great casual game to play.There no timer in fights and always play an AI, so you can play while other game loading maps.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is effective at generating a false sense of achievement.  There are many different metrics by which you can make easy, regular progress.  Acquiring new characters, levelling them up, progressing through story missions, and reaching new reward tiers during the events all make it feel like your are gaining something.  Ultimately, though, it feels like a continuous grind with no real end goal.  Like many micro-transaction based games, it is more interesting to see how far you can progress without making a purchase than to buy either of their in-game currencies, so this may truely be a free-to-play game for you.

content:
y 13, 2014
												For the first couple of days I played this game I was a little frustrated.  It seemed that the items were very overpriced (and they are), and that I couldn't get anything I wanted.  However, If you are smart at how you spend your money, use your items, and which characters you play, you can do very well in this game with little or no cash.  The real game is in the PvP, which isn't PvP at all really.  The Prologue, is just that, a starting to the real game.  Once you get 3 characters around 25-30 you can actually start playing the game which is all in building various teams who's abilities compliment each other.  I started out with Iron Man Model 35, Storm Modern, and Black Widow Modern.  This team will take you very far.  Now the anchor of my team is Black Widow Original.  She can heal and steal AP so I almost always end a fight with full health.  She does very well with Wolverine or Thor.  As you can see I've spent many hours playing this game on my PC (although half or more was probably AFK time.)  I've spent $10 on this game and I've felt it was a good choice.  My husband also plays and he spent $5.  We both spent the money to buy hero coins which we used to open slots for more characters. You will need at least 12 to get started and I currently have 18. 18 slots is enough to keep my favorites.  I never felt the need or pressure to buy for anything else.A note on the PvP, you get to choose who you play.  If you don't like the team, press skip, and you will be presented with another choice.  You can find teams you can beat at any level and since the very dumb AI is controlling the opposing team you can generally beat teams much higher level with smart play.  You get either 70 or 140 ISO-8 for every match you win, and you should be winning nearly all of them since you get to choose who you fight.  With an average of 105 ISO-8  per match and matches lasting about 3 minutes  you can level up characters very quickly in RPG terms.  However it probably seems slow for a casual mobile app.  You get points in tournaments based on the ranking of the team you fight, not their level, so with smart picks and persistence you can rank well and get good rewards early on, but if you have to come in first, you're going to have to work hard and wait a long time.  In addition to the end of tournament rewards, there are frequently progression rewards which you get regardless of your final ranking.  As there are frequently multiple tournaments hapening simultaneously and shield trainer always available, even after you've exhauseted the story line rewards there is always plenty to do and more characters to collect.  I find Marvel Puzzle Quest fun and surprisingly addictive, yet not at all pay to win.  In fact, the items are so expensive that several hundred dollars wouldn't get you very far. So those who do spend mony don't have any real advantage beyond saving a few minutes.  In summary, if you can get over the slow grind to level 30, this game really takes off and becomes much more fun.  Don't spend hero coins or money on anything other than opening up more roster slots until you fully understand what you are getting in return (i.e. hardly anthing). Participate in the tournaments early and often as this is where the ISO-8 you need to level your characters comes from even if you don't place well.  I'm not surprised that the people who only played an hour don't like it, though.  It's not really a play for a few minutes kinda game.  It's much better suited to long sessions on the PC.  It's the most fun I've had for $10 in a while.

content:
ry 4, 2014
												Interesting twist on bejeweledThe game play was mostly intuitive, although how exactly the enemies move/fight back is not very obvious, as there are different types of enemies that use different game mechanics to fight you. Also, choosing which ally is in front isn't very obvious either, even tho it's critical sometimes to know exactly who's in the front line and who will get the hit.This game, being free to play, has a leveling system that requires coins, which you can buy in the in-game store or otherwise purchase with real money. I'm not a big fan of free to play games for this reason, so it took away from my enjoyment of the game.The art and animations are pretty good, and the "storyline" is ok for a Marvel storyline. It's mostly just a big excuse to put all the Marvel characters together, but it does enough to provide a background for the game.Only not recommending this game because I dislike free to play. However, it is a solid bejeweled spin-off other than that.

content:
ry 19, 2016
												It's a match-3 puzzle game that lets you bring your choice of characters, each with their own special abilities, into the match. Depending on the characters, rules will be altered or added to that will alter how the match plays and can have a massive effect on the outcome of matches.Damage suffered is per-hero. Damage carries over between matches, so you can barely win one match and start another only to lose after your first turn if you don't wait for any suffered damage to your heroes to be restored. You can pay real world currency to hurry the healing along, but there's no requirement to do so.The publisher makes money from a cash shop, selling healing items, hero roster space, and random hero draws. You can get more heroes and ingame shop currency from playing the game, but even paying players feel an inventory squeeze if they're even slightly packrat-like.Think Puzzle Quest with a mostly optional microtransaction business model.

er 26, 2016
												Simpl the best Match-3 game out there, because it adds a new depth to the eternal classic by way of up to three Marvel heroes or villains battling over that board. Each of these characters has an amount of HP, three colors they deal a good amount of damage when they match them, and three abilites that can deal damage, create special tiles, rearrange the board, heal your team, or steal AP (colored tiles matched generate those to power said abilities).You can spend money on this to speed up the leveling or acquisition of new characters, but I haven't spent more than 10$ on this and have won first place in both Versus and Story events before.I can't believe I spent so many hours on this...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 4, 2014
												if you've ever played puzzle quest (1,2, kindgoms or galactrix, idk if there are others) then you'll find the gameplay similar (swap stones to match 3 vertically/horizontaly to cause damage to opponent & gain resources used to employ secondary abilities). this iteration of the series strongly borrows from free-to-play mmos/facebook games in the form of microtransactions. characters are upgraded through cards purchased through in-game currency which is gained through rewards for completeting missions or events, or bought through the in-game shop. it also suppliments the typical puzzle quest battle system with a 3v3 marvel vs capcom style team fight, which adds another level of complexity to the game.disregarding the whole play-to-win aspect, the game itself is fun, with great artwork and an interesting variety of iconic marvel characters. at times i find the pace a bit sluggish for a casual game, and the difficulty can sometimes spike unexpectedly, but overall it is a very fun game, without needing a huge investment of time to be fun.

content:
, 2015
												I had a BLAST with Iron Man while trying to unleash FURY back into the world. I cast a web with Spider Man and fought valiantly against familiar and deadly villains and foes. This is a fast and FURY-us game with many surprises and power-ups.  I had to use SHIELD to lower the H.A.M.M.E.R while searching for the optimum match-ups to enhance my powers.  You earn rewards along the way and bolster your hero's super powers while staying alive to fight another day. All this while dodging sniper bullets and wondering what new heroes and villains are yet to be discovered.  This is a MARVEL to me and it broke the monotony from my much tamer and more usual game play.

content:
, 2014
												This ain't your Candy Crush Saga...Like any of the other Puzzle Quest games, this is a match 3 score puzzle game with the theme of Marvel Heroes. It has a story mode competeting off against the AI in various story scenarios, now with weekly special events allowing players a variety of PvE puzzle games to choose from. And there is also PvP arena, while also simulated by the AI, you'll face off against other player's team, composed of three of their heroes and/or villians. Competeting in these events (PvE and PvP) will place you upon a ranking system in brackets of other players around the world. In these brackets, there are milestones providing various bonuses as incentives to duel creating an addictive puzzle grind for glorious rewards.Generating in-game currency named, "ISO" you'll use this to level up your heroes and villians once you've unlocked (recruited) them either by purchasing the booster cards or earning them from playing the game. It's quite exciting earning cards, as each time you'll have a random chance - while some higher %'s than others - of obtaining that elusive hero or villian you've been after.It's a fantastic Puzzle Quest game, and I am a fan of the previous PQ games as well... so perhaps I'm biased, but it's definitely a fantastic match 3 puzzle game and highly reccommended by me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Addicting.  Having played Puzzle Quest on my PS3 I was familiear with the RPG/Match 3 hybrid mechanic.  If not, you soon will be, because the game is free, so there is no excuse to not try it out.  That being said, I'm sure the largest criticism will be that it is pay to win, which is not  *entirely* true.  If you play daily, participate in tournaments, join an alliance that is active and stay active....you will naturally earn gold coins (premium currency) and the ISO that is required for leveling characters.  You will end up selling premium covers (2 stars +), because roster slots cost gold coins, and you don't want to pay.  However, if you stick it out, keep playing, you will get those slots and then you just have to pray for good drops from cover pulls.The top players clearly pay or they have more hours in the day than God to play.  The game is meant to be casual, but can be cutthroat, give it a try, its the perfect game when you only have 15 minutes here and there.EDIT 9/10/14So being a player with 33 roster slots, Ive had some more time to reflect.  Clearly, as you progress without spending money, you are easily trumped in most high level encounters in tournaments, but success is not impossible with a little strategy and luck.  Most notably, I've noticed that as the developers continue to add new characters (covers or powers) to the possible roster, the chances that you will draw the same 3 star character necessary to level the one you already have becomes lower and lower.  For example, I've had a level 69 Hulk forever, because I have not drawn another cover due to the low 1% chance in most instances.  In the meantime I've accrued 5 or 6 other three star characters that are basically useless with only one cover outside of special circumstances during rare tournament opportunities.What this means simply is, if you can't afford new roster space to increase room for new characters, you will almost never level those three star characters necessary for higher level challenges.  The devs clearly use this to milk more money and stiff the consumer.  They need to add more two star characters and make three star character opporunities more plentiful.I still play, but with little opporunity for progression at this point, it is getting tedious and boring to play.

content:
ry 19, 2016
												It's a match-3 puzzle game that lets you bring your choice of characters, each with their own special abilities, into the match. Depending on the characters, rules will be altered or added to that will alter how the match plays and can have a massive effect on the outcome of matches.Damage suffered is per-hero. Damage carries over between matches, so you can barely win one match and start another only to lose after your first turn if you don't wait for any suffered damage to your heroes to be restored. You can pay real world currency to hurry the healing along, but there's no requirement to do so.The publisher makes money from a cash shop, selling healing items, hero roster space, and random hero draws. You can get more heroes and ingame shop currency from playing the game, but even paying players feel an inventory squeeze if they're even slightly packrat-like.Think Puzzle Quest with a mostly optional microtransaction business model.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 14, 2015
												I've played this game for roughly two years on the iPad & iPhone, and although I've taken a few breaks, I generally play it every day.  I find it to be a somewhat repetitive but still enjoyable game.  Mechanically the battles are done using a match-3 mechanic, like a bejeweled game.  It's not hard, but I'd say it's more challenging than Candy Crush or other similar games.  The tricky part is that there's a paper-rock-sissors element to the characters, and you need to match enough a certain color gem to enable a hero's power to be used.  Like many other free-to-play games, there are two currencies, one common and another rare.  (plus a third, command points, which was recently introduced and can unlock much stronger four or five star characters).The real key to success in this game is patience and persistance.  It's somewhat pay to win, but the truth is that I'd say it's pay-regularly-to-frequently-win, or play-frequently-and-do-ok. If you just keep plugging away, your characters will continue to improve, and you'll stay reasonably competitive for a long time.  It's fairly easy to play entirely for free, though I'll admit I found there was a point somewhere around the mid-two-star level where I coughed up some actual money in order to not lose characters. In retrospect, this was unnecesary, but I didn't realize it at the time. I'd recommend reading through some of the great guides on the marvel puzzle quest forum for advice on which characters to keep and which to get rid of.I think the most fun part of this game, over time, is that the developers truly seem interested in keeping it alive and interesting. I like how they keep introducing new mechanics.  I feel like sometimes they don't entirely think through the result of their actions on the way that people play the game.  For example, right now with new command points, rewards for people like myself working on their four-stars is definitely skewed to PvE rather than PvP.  I don't know if the developers did this intentionally, or just don't realize it.  But whatever. It's still fun, and somehow it's more fun for the fact that they're not entirely polished and thoughtful in their actions.   Some people get bent out of shape about this, but I actually think the chaos that comes with each new game mechanic or meta-change keeps things fresh.  I'd recommend it for the tablet or phone.  It's the perfect game to play once or twice a day over lunch break.

												What could be a fun puzzle game ruined by the same cash schemes and artificial time gates of many IOS ports.Between the forced real time recovery of any hero when  they take any damage, to clear grind or pay to win keep buying covers to power up heros aspect, any fun the game has is eroded by it's petty restriciton mechanics. the game makes the more frustrating aspects of puzzle quests even more frustrating because one bad match can make an entire day effectively moot.Worse still is that while stages have multiple rewards to earn, The game will more often than not randomly decide to reward you the item you already earned, and since you cannot re earn said reward you will be given the same pitance you'd get from replaying a stage fully cleared. i've had strings of six+ fights consecutively where the reward I was given was the only one i 'earned' every single time.Without the terrible healing restriction and a way to level up heroes outside of using the same currency you must earn to buy covers the game would be a fun, if inferior sueprhero version of the classic Puzzle Quest. content:
y 13, 2014
												For the first couple of days I played this game I was a little frustrated.  It seemed that the items were very overpriced (and they are), and that I couldn't get anything I wanted.  However, If you are smart at how you spend your money, use your items, and which characters you play, you can do very well in this game with little or no cash.  The real game is in the PvP, which isn't PvP at all really.  The Prologue, is just that, a starting to the real game.  Once you get 3 characters around 25-30 you can actually start playing the game which is all in building various teams who's abilities compliment each other.  I started out with Iron Man Model 35, Storm Modern, and Black Widow Modern.  This team will take you very far.  Now the anchor of my team is Black Widow Original.  She can heal and steal AP so I almost always end a fight with full health.  She does very well with Wolverine or Thor.  As you can see I've spent many hours playing this game on my PC (although half or more was probably AFK time.)  I've spent $10 on this game and I've felt it was a good choice.  My husband also plays and he spent $5.  We both spent the money to buy hero coins which we used to open slots for more characters. You will need at least 12 to get started and I currently have 18. 18 slots is enough to keep my favorites.  I never felt the need or pressure to buy for anything else.A note on the PvP, you get to choose who you play.  If you don't like the team, press skip, and you will be presented with another choice.  You can find teams you can beat at any level and since the very dumb AI is controlling the opposing team you can generally beat teams much higher level with smart play.  You get either 70 or 140 ISO-8 for every match you win, and you should be winning nearly all of them since you get to choose who you fight.  With an average of 105 ISO-8  per match and matches lasting about 3 minutes  you can level up characters very quickly in RPG terms.  However it probably seems slow for a casual mobile app.  You get points in tournaments based on the ranking of the team you fight, not their level, so with smart picks and persistence you can rank well and get good rewards early on, but if you have to come in first, you're going to have to work hard and wait a long time.  In addition to the end of tournament rewards, there are frequently progression rewards which you get regardless of your final ranking.  As there are frequently multiple tournaments hapening simultaneously and shield trainer always available, even after you've exhauseted the story line rewards there is always plenty to do and more characters to collect.  I find Marvel Puzzle Quest fun and surprisingly addictive, yet not at all pay to win.  In fact, the items are so expensive that several hundred dollars wouldn't get you very far. So those who do spend mony don't have any real advantage beyond saving a few minutes.  In summary, if you can get over the slow grind to level 30, this game really takes off and becomes much more fun.  Don't spend hero coins or money on anything other than opening up more roster slots until you fully understand what you are getting in return (i.e. hardly anthing). Participate in the tournaments early and often as this is where the ISO-8 you need to level your characters comes from even if you don't place well.  I'm not surprised that the people who only played an hour don't like it, though.  It's not really a play for a few minutes kinda game.  It's much better suited to long sessions on the PC.  It's the most fun I've had for $10 in a while.

content:
ry 8, 2014
												The most fundamental problems with this game are:1) While Free To Play doesn't always equal Pay To Win etc, the main problem with this title is that they give you a heap of extra random characters (and in fact specific ones too!) as rewards, but you can't keep them without paying money... and the rewards have a time limit.  You are able to win some of the precious purchasable tokens as rewards, but nowhere near enough to keep up with the characters you receive.2) While the game lets you play on a variety of places, and in fact makes you sign up with a random external system... there are no in game links to the external system, and they seem to have removed the ability for this Steam version to properly synch with the other devices. I believe some people can and have done this, but either it's been removed from this version, or if you didn't immediately agree then your one opportuniy to do this is never repeated.3) Lack of in-game support.  Sure - everyone who has played PQ or even anything like it knows the basics.  And there is a tutorial mode which is ridiculously hand-holding, but... later when you want to look up stupid technical things, it is quite difficult to navigate.4) Everything suddenly gets tied to PvP, which causes everything to be heavily Pay to Win.  There's not enough story of appropriate level to keep people playing on a PvE level... so you either fork out cash to level, or you ... stop playing?Problem: I love superheroes.  I love Puzzle Quest.  This... is... almost? ish? what people should expect from a free-to-play game that works on phones and tablets (at least these days) but I have objections to games that make you stop playing them as a game mechanic... especially on a PC.  Sorry - it's a stupid design.

												At first this game was fun and addicting, I played it on Steam, and then I got it on my Android phone too. Eventually, the problems started like being a free to play game, it's built around the concept of spending money now or wait a while. The further you get, the more the waiting times add up, and the game wants you to buy health packs with real money. It also doesn't carry over from version to version so if you did spend money on microtransactions on Steam, it wouldn't show up on a mobile version that you own. It's a big waste of time, and potentially money if you go that route. It doesn't offer a great deal of free content before it tries every last resort to bleed you for money.

												What could be a fun puzzle game ruined by the same cash schemes and artificial time gates of many IOS ports.Between the forced real time recovery of any hero when  they take any damage, to clear grind or pay to win keep buying covers to power up heros aspect, any fun the game has is eroded by it's petty restriciton mechanics. the game makes the more frustrating aspects of puzzle quests even more frustrating because one bad match can make an entire day effectively moot.Worse still is that while stages have multiple rewards to earn, The game will more often than not randomly decide to reward you the item you already earned, and since you cannot re earn said reward you will be given the same pitance you'd get from replaying a stage fully cleared. i've had strings of six+ fights consecutively where the reward I was given was the only one i 'earned' every single time.Without the terrible healing restriction and a way to level up heroes outside of using the same currency you must earn to buy covers the game would be a fun, if inferior sueprhero version of the classic Puzzle Quest. As it currently is the game is just going out of it's way to force you to give them money, instead of making a product you want to pay for.

content:
y 15, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is meant to be a puzzle game with RPG-ish elements where you can level up your character and increase the damage of their attacks by spending points on them. The thing is that you rarely get these points (coins in-game). You can tell that this game is the typical free-to-play game when they hit you with the fact that you either have to waste health packs on your heroes to recharge their health or wait 10 minutes to heal your heroes. Marvel Puzzle Quest is really designed as the average mobile game where you come back after your characters are able to be used (i.e. Injustice Mobile). So this is a Marvel version of puzzle quest, which is basically bejeweled except your actions control characters' attacks. There is a cool factor to this where you can increase the powers of your heroes by using resources you collect (Iso-8 Crystals) BUT you can't even purchase these upgrades until you purchase another "layer" of your character... AND THE THING IS that you can't do that without COINS, YES RARE ♥♥♥ COINS!!! Level 1 upgrades are 125 coins and I just want to point out that 200 coins costs 2 DOLLARS!!! Why do the creators try to screw us like this? But besides this In-Game-Purchase BS, the story really isn't even interesting, and the dialogue is quite boring. If only the heroes and villains had voices behind them it would be more interesting. This game does have some pros to it buy mostly cons. Not recommended...maybe to puzzle quest fans and very patient people but it doesn't change the fact that this game has tedious recharge times, boring dialogue and an uninteresting story.

content:
y 30, 2014
												Originally it was a moderately entertaining F2P game that was still enjoyable without spending much real money on. The in game economy was always horribly broken. The 100 to 1 Hero Point ratio was not bad, but what it bought you was ridiculous. For an example unlocking one level of a skill in a three star(Rare) character is 1250 HP. Or $12.50. They want $12.50 to unlock one level of one skill of which there are 13 per character. Or around $150 if you want to completely unlock one character. Fine, I was happy to play alound with the covers I could get through tournament rewards and the daily drops. Then came along the latest patch. Instead of fixing the rampant cheating or other various broken portions of the game, they decide to nerf some of the better characters that are relatively easy for the free players to get. No Devs, they weren't overpowered, they were accessible and most of the other accessible characters suck. Again, nerfing happens, most devs have still yet to realize it's better to balance up than down, but any relatively experienced gamer is used to that. But they also decided to start charging HP for the +3AP to all boost. They're now charging the equivalent of $1 for a stack of three boosts that will last maybe 10 to 15 minutes of game time and is very necessary for the casual players. The devs basically too a look at the game stats, saw what the casual players used most, and either made them less effective or started charging for them. I had intended on buying $15 or so worth of HP to support the game and buy some roster slots, but I am definitely glad I waited and they will now never see a dime from me.

ber 2, 2015
												I neither recommend or dislike this game for a simple reason, and that is that you CAN get a lot of it without paying. What you cannot do is compete at the higher levels without paying or expand your character space.There are issues with the gameplay, it does seem rather annoying that whatever you do as a player the AI always get the jewels they want. And it is also very, very frusrtating that when you are fighting bosses who need certain colours for thier attacks they miraculously drop for them regularly but not for you, and the only way to beat them is to grind and compete in daily events to potentially win better characters.And therein lies the nub of this game, to use better characters and not scrap the ones you have invested time and ISO in you have to purchase character slots and these go up in price aswell as size as you play daily. So now I need 300 gold to purchase 3 slots, rather than being able to buy 1 for 100.This is all very clever from a P2W point of view, but will simply mean I will move on if I cannot win enough gold to use these characters. But the very, very sad part of that is that the characters have a time limit on their availability, tempting you to spend money. I find that rather manipulative and poor.I have seen players with six pages of characters, and goodness knows how much they have spent. That more than outweighs those of us who play for fun, so let them do it and enjoy a simple game for nothing.

content:
er 29, 2016
												Great game of puzzle 3 match style.When it came on steam I played to be first in the versus events. I change my mind after a few months.Too much time to give to become competitive.I realized its more fun to play casualy doing the Deadpool Daily and playing versus 3-4 fights while collecting heroes.Description of the game :You get covers who represent a character with one of is powers.You can use a second cover of same character to boost the  maximum level of the character and level up the power 1/5 -> 2/5 , or give a new power among a new color. The heroes has 3 powers.There is 6 colors on the board and you need to make matches to fill your AP reserve that your heroes will consume for their powers. The more powerfull the ability , the more it will consume.You also make matches to give damage to the enemie heroes. The powers of your heroes will help doing damage, steal AP, add bonus damage, add protection, scramble the board ... etc.Every hero has 3 colors preference.Select a team of 3 heros for your battles and make them use all colors while keeping a sinergy between them.When they get damage, the damage stays for the next fight.You can wait until they heal by themselves or use Heal Card who can be gain from events or Hero Points.As you gain many heroes and play casual it will not bother anymore.Hero Points can be gain from events by reaching the high scores at the end of events.Mostly easier to gain them by using the Real Money with micro transaction.Same for Isodium (purple quartz). You gain little quantities from any fights. Mainly use for the level up of heroes. If you play casual , you will just accumulate and sell covers of new heroes for those you will gain a preference.Such as Wolverine > Hawkeye.The versus system will get you angry, and frustation once you realise how it really work.You play against AI with team made by dev or players.You gain point by winning, Bigger the difference of points make you gain more points.While your team get attack and lose .. the difference make you lose more points.When you want to do retalation. Their points are lower, so you retaliate for 10 points from a 50 points lost.  You need to wait for them to get more points ... if they go for it.You can buy shields with Hero points. And realise you can't attack anyone from your ladder, which should make you realised you are fighting other ladder who will attack you fault of knowing how aggressive the other ladder groups actualy are.Conclusion , great casual game to play.There no timer in fights and always play an AI, so you can play while other game loading maps.

Having tried the game, I can say that even though there is a lot of microtransactions, they do not restrict you in any way. Of course, you won't be able to own everything by playing, but you also don't have to buy anything.As far as gameplay goes, the game offers a fine experience, some strategy, and a lot of puzzling, and I find myself enjoying it, especially considering that it's free.The best thing I can say is that you try the game yourself and see if you think that microtransactions bother you or not. content:
ber 2, 2015
												I neither recommend or dislike this game for a simple reason, and that is that you CAN get a lot of it without paying. What you cannot do is compete at the higher levels without paying or expand your character space.There are issues with the gameplay, it does seem rather annoying that whatever you do as a player the AI always get the jewels they want. And it is also very, very frusrtating that when you are fighting bosses who need certain colours for thier attacks they miraculously drop for them regularly but not for you, and the only way to beat them is to grind and compete in daily events to potentially win better characters.And therein lies the nub of this game, to use better characters and not scrap the ones you have invested time and ISO in you have to purchase character slots and these go up in price aswell as size as you play daily. So now I need 300 gold to purchase 3 slots, rather than being able to buy 1 for 100.This is all very clever from a P2W point of view, but will simply mean I will move on if I cannot win enough gold to use these characters. But the very, very sad part of that is that the characters have a time limit on their availability, tempting you to spend money. I find that rather manipulative and poor.I have seen players with six pages of characters, and goodness knows how much they have spent. That more than outweighs those of us who play for fun, so let them do it and enjoy a simple game for nothing.

												I read most of the reviews, and saw how negative people were because of the microtransactions. Having tried the game, I can say that even though there is a lot of microtransactions, they do not restrict you in any way. So far, I have been able to get most things just by playing, and have been awarded a decent amount of coins just because of playing. Of course, you won't be able to own everything by playing, but you also don't have to buy anything.As far as gameplay goes, the game offers a fine experience, some strategy, and a lot of puzzling, and I find myself enjoying it, especially considering that it's free.The best thing I can say is that you try the game yourself and see if you think that microtransactions bother you or not. In my opinion, I think they are not and that you can enjoy this game decently without paying anything.

												Key notes here:  1:  The cash shop is pretty hard in this game, and new players will feel left out if they can not get into an alliance.That said.  If your alliance can rank in the top 500 or so consistently you can all but avoid the cash shop with all the free goods and recruit tokens you can earn.  Taco vault 10 packs are super good if you wont want to drop 50 bucks for a 40 pack.  Team slots are point efficent untill you can only get single slots, and even then you do need alot of them.EVEN WITH THAT!  I love the smooth intuitve game play (well, as intuitive as a tile matching game gets)  there is a good sense of balance when you go against equally ranked teams.  And best of all, it is mostly effort that wins.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2013
												Horrible, Greedy, Lopsided GameI want to like this game. I want to like it so much. And there are times I do. This is a rant, pure and simple.And then the overhwleming amount of the time I see it for the money grab it is. One battle where the underpowered AI pulls off a random cascade of combos puts my strongest characters out for three hours and there is nothing I can do.I can't wain tournaments to get 2 star, 3 star or 4 star characters because I'm put in tournaments with people who have strong characters. Even if I do manage to win one, I then have to wait for my heroes to heal. And in that time I'm attacked so many times I'm back to no points in the tournament.I'll admit I have no life recently, so I've spent a whole day trying to get to the top in an event. And it just isn't possible. While I can devote every hour, I will always lose to someone with a few high level 3 stars who is put in the same event as me.It must be really fun for someone who has a lot of money, because as soon as you have good characters, the game rewards you with more through the tournaments and events. I'm beginning to see that no matter how long I play, I will always be behind because the devs give no chance for me to catch up. Those who already have 3 star characters are pulling away and getting more. By the time I have one, who I can decently level with covers, they will have 20.And why can't we turn covers into a free level for our character, rather than have to sell them? I'm sick of getting the same 1 star cover for characters with maxed powers. The only rewards I can get are standard tokens, so at least make them useful in some way.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2013
												I've been playing this game on my android since it was released, I've easily put 50 hours into the game, I have 25 roster slots, over ten heroes that are Lv30+ all without spending a dollar. Don't put this game down for microtransactions since you don't need to spend a dollar with all the rewards the tournametns and the PvE gives you.-Update-I still see people are complaining about the Microtransactions. 1) If you play the game daily roughly 2 hours a day and do all the missions in the PVE events and PVP a couple times a day you should get roughly 3,000-5,000 Iso-8, the tool to level up your characters. It costs roughly 20k Iso-8 to max out any 1* Hero and roughly 80k to max out a 2* hero. You will be able to max out any 1* or 2* character within weeks of just playing a couple hours a day. 2. You will also roughly get a few hundred Hero Points in the process, if you are starting out the game. Use them on the 100 Daily Deal Heroic pack. That is how you max out your 2*s. If you have played the game for a while, save the Hero Points for Alliance slots, or join an open alliance. I created a 20 person alliance and only spent twenty bucks on it, I could have waited a month for the same ammount of Hero Points. ((Some people spent a hundred))3. Now for the 3* covers, playing a lot in any tournament or event will nail you 1-3 3* covers of one hero. You will also get covers through the Heroic Packs and any other special pack that you spend your free hero points on. They require alot of Iso-8 to max out. 170k for a rough estimate. HOWEVER the final level still requires only 2500 iso-8, which is something you can easily get within an hour. 4. Guys this isn't a game that you get Lv100 of all the strongest characters within hours of playing. This game is set up more of an MMO where you have to do the slow grind to get to that point. I don't mind it. I currently have 5 maxed out 2* Characters at Lv85, 3 maxed out 1* characters and I have a handful of other 2 and 3* characters over lv50 with two that I just need to grind all the way to max level. I've only spent fifty bucks on this game because I actually felt like it. I didn't feel like I needed to in order to continue this game. To compare with other games I've played, I put almost a thousand bucks in to League of Legends and I had put six hundred bucks into Dungeon Fighter Online before that got shut down. I probably could spend more money into this game, but I don't.

content:
er 26, 2013
												8/10This is a free-to-play Match 3 game.There are MANY others like it, but I'm a comic book fan, (Slightly more a DC/Vertigo fan but still love some of the Marvel lines.) and this isn't the worst thing to happen to the franchise, or even the top 3 terrible things. *If they got Halle Berry to VO the game, it could get there...)The game itself is adequately executed (as the producers of "Electra" should be...) It's ... well, it's Puzzle Quest, with a few Marvel bits thrown in so your power-ups share the names of your chosen heroes' powers (Iron man's Repulsors, etc)The "Story" arouond the game... They try, and didn't destroy a load of canon to beat a storyline around the missions.The Free-To-Play bit...Obviously they're going to try to take your money, but they don't throw it in your face constantly, nor do they ask you to "Share your victory with a friend" every 5 minutes. If you play a little bit every day you can easily get enough rewards to make up for not paying for stuff, but if you want you can speed up your success. Just remember to save all your "Hero Points" for when you actually need them, and you'll have them when you do come upon a need.
